propertySubType: Retail, Land / Development, Takeaway, Bar, Restaurant, Alternate Use, Public House, Leisure, Investment, Cafe
detailedDescription: The Eagle is a two and single-storey detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The Eagle opened in 1979-80 and was extensively refurbished in 2015. The property briefly comprises front entrance hall, with tiled floor, providing access to two open plan bars. The lounge bar has approximately 50 covers and a timber bar servery, upholstered perimeter seating, raised area with feature fireplace and door to rear entrance hall. The other bar has timber bar servery, wooden flooring, darts throw, space for pool table and door to the front outdoor terrace. The Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s are accessed from the main entrance hall. The Eagle also benefits from a compact commercial catering kitchen, office, large ground floor beer cellar, bottle store and storage room. The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and briefly comprises three double bedrooms, lounge, domestic kitchen, safe room and bathroom with separate W.C. To the exterior, the pub sits in a plot of 0.566 acres encompassing an outside seating area to the front with picnic bench seating for c.40, a 30+-space customer car park area to the rear, laid to tarmac and a private rear yard with off road parking, boiler room and garage. The Eagle is prominently situated on the corner of Howbeck Road and Cornell Drive in a largely residential area of the Nottinghamshire town of Arnold. The pub is located approximately 1 mile from the town centre. Arnold is a market town in the Borough of Gedling, situated to the north-east of Nottingham's city boundary. Arnold has the largest town centre in the Borough of Gedling and the most important town centre in the northeastern part of the conurbation of Greater Nottingham. Gedling Borough Council is headquartered in Arnold. Since 1968 Arnold has had a market, and the town used to have numerous factories associated with the hosiery industry. Nottinghamshire Police have been headquartered in Arnold since 1979. At the time of the 2021 United Kingdom census, Arnold had a population of 39,995. The population within a 1 km radius of the pub is 11,245. The local authority is Gedling Borough Council. We understand the Property is neither Listed nor located inside a Conservation Area. The Eagle does not appear on the Local Authority’s AVC Register. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment Ground Floor GEA - c. 4,297 ft² Total site area – c 0.566 acres (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). Offers in the region of £550,000 are invited for the Freehold Interest. A Free of Tie Leasehold Option is also available. Rateable Value – Public House: £13,500 (2023).

displayAddress: 43 Church Street, South Normanton, Derbyshire, DE55 2BT
propertySubType: Public House, Retail, Takeaway, Land / Development, Bar, Alternate Use, Restaurant, Cafe, Leisure
detailedDescription: Previously known as the White Hart, the School House is a 19th Century two and single storey property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The accommodation briefly comprises a well laid-out ground floor trading area, split into two well-appointed rooms providing  approximately 50 covers in total. The Bar area has approximately 20 covers and benefits from an attractive brick-built bar servery with brick built feature fireplace and wood-burner stove, timber floor and beamed ceiling. An archway leads to the main Restaurant area, a characterful spacious room with vaulted ceiling, exposed brickwork with wood burning stove and timber flooring. The Ladies and Gents W.C.s are accessed via an inner hallway, which is also utilised for disabled access into the venue and provides access to the rear garden. The School House also benefits from a good sized commercial kitchen, with a 'desert' and 'starter' area, walk-in freezer store and a wash-up area. The restaurant also benefits from a basement cellar and store room, and office space.  The domestic accommodation is located over the first floor. The accommodation has been refurbished and provides an attractive living space, briefly comprising two double bedrooms, a spacious lounge, domestic kitchen and bathroom. The flat also has access to a private decked area, overlooking the rear garden.  The flat is currently let out on an AST at £900 / month. To the exterior, the business benefits from a wonderful enclosed rear garden that adds an extra 30 covers in good weather. The 'secret garden' was developed in 2017 and is mainly laid to lawn with shrub borders, a raised decking corner area and further decked area beneath a timber pergola. The venue also benefits from a covered rear yard with smoking shelter, brick built stores and a car park, laid to tarmac, providing parking for c. 5 cars.  The School House Restaurant & Bar is positioned on the edge of the ever-growing Derbyshire village of South Normanton. The venue is located on the main road running through the village, set close to McArthur Glen Retail Park and within easy reach of the M1 and A38. South Normanton is a village and civil parish in the Bolsover District of Derbyshire. The population at the 2021 Census was recorded as 10,135. An ex-mining village, it lies approximately 1 mile from Junction 28 of the M1 motorway,  two miles east of Alfreton, 8 miles from Mansfield,  11 miles south of Chesterfield and 15 miles north of Nottingham. We understand the property is not Listed or situated within a conservation area. Interested parties should make their own enquiries via Bolsover District Council. All vendor owned trade fixtures and fittings will be included in the purchase price. Ground Floor Footprint - c. 2,680 ft² Total site area – c 0.142 acres (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Rateable Value of The School House has been assessed at £4,000 (2023).The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

displayAddress: Market Place, Shildon, County Durham, DL4 2DP
propertySubType: Alternate Use, Restaurant, Cafe, Bar, Takeaway, Guest House, Other, Public House, Land / Development, Retail
detailedDescription: The property is a mid terrace brick built property rendered and painted to the front elevation. Internally the trading area is a ‘L’ shaped bar area to accommodate approximately 40 persons on fixed seating and chairs with a bar servery to the left hand side. The property has the benefit of a separate games room housing a pool table and again having fixed seating around the perimeter of the room. The ladies and gentleman’s toilets are located towards the rear of the property. To the rear of the property are 2 outbuildings, one of which gives access to the basement beer cellar. Currently Closed. The upper floors are unhabitable in their current form. This area covers the first floor and briefly comprises former function room, 3 bedrooms, office, lounge, kitchen, separate WC and bathroom. Externally there is a yard to the rear and an external trading area to the front of the property. The property is located on Market Place in a residential cul-de-sac close to Shildon Town Centre. Shildon is located in County Durham in the north east of England, it is known for its railway heritage being the 'cradle of railways' due to its significance in the development of steam locomotives.   We are advised that the property is not listed or in a flood zone. The Fixtures & Fittings that remain on the premises at the time of completion will be included in the sale. Any third party owned items, such as beer raising and cellar cooling equipment, branded items, gaming machines etc, will be excluded. An inventory will not be provided. The vendors will not be required to remove any such items that remain on the premises. Total site area is 0.082 acres with a building footprint of 2,312 Sq Ft. (Measurements have been taken from a digital mapping platform) The property is in an area administered by Bury Council. The Rateable Value has been assessed at £1,700. We advise any interested parties to make their own enquiries.

propertySubType: Restaurant, Guest House, Bar, Public House, Retail, Investment, Leisure, Other, Alternate Use
detailedDescription: A mid terrace property of brick construction under a pitched slate roof. Inner entrance porch leads through to a split level bar area, the lower lever having part exposed brick walling and providing seating for circa 40 persons on fixed perimeter seating and low stools. Feature open fire with stone surround. Large bar servery with access to the beer cellar. On the upper level is a pool playing area with additional seating for approximately 12 persons leading through to the ladies and gentleman's toilets. Externally there is a flagged beer garden to the rear which is partly covered. The living accommodation is located on the first and second floors and briefly comprises of 2 bedrooms, kitchen, bathroom, lounge and office. The Ship Inn is located on Frenchgate, a lovely cobbled street just a short stroll from the Town Centre. Richmond is a historic market town situated on the edge of the Yorkshire Dales National Park with good road connections via the A6108 and A66, the town is set above the River Swale and is renowned for its well preserved georgian market place and norman castle. The property is not listed but sits in a conservation area. The Fixtures & Fittings that remain on the premises at the time of completion will be included in the sale. Any third party owned items, such as beer raising and cellar cooling equipment, branded items, gaming machines etc, will be excluded. An inventory will not be provided. The vendors will not be required to remove any such items that remain on the premises. Total site area of 0.074 acre. Building footprint of 1,792 Sq Ft (166 Sq M). Measurements taken from an online digital portal. Virtual Freehold - The property is held on a 999 year lease from 01/05/1745 expiring on 01/05/2744 having 718 years unexpired. The Rateable Value has been assessed at £5,000 increasing to £10,600 from April 2026. We advise any interested parties to make their own enquiries to Richmondshire Council non domestic rates department.

propertySubType: Cafe, Other, Bar, Restaurant, Alternate Use, Land / Development, Leisure, Public House, Takeaway
detailedDescription: Entrance leading to main bar, with servery and open fireplace. Still retaining traditional decoration throughout, seating for approx 30 customers. Leading to dining area for approx 25 covers. Unused Lounge Bar area, which could be used for a further 10-15 seats. Ladies and Gents facilities. Basement cellar with office space. Good size trade kitchen with prep area. 2nd front entrance into hotel lobby area, with internal access to main bar. Leads to 2 x letting rooms with en-suite bathrooms on the ground floor. Stairs leading to 2 further letting rooms (both with en-suite bathrooms) on the 1st floor.  Stairs behind bar leading to private accommodation on 1st floor, consisting of lounge, 2 x double bedrooms, lounge and kitchen. External areas consist of 3 double letting rooms with en-suite bathrooms, directly accessed from the font of the building only. Parking available for c30 cars. Storage units in garden to the rear. Extensive trade garden laid to grass, ideal for holding festivals and functions throughout the year. The space could also be considered for further letting rooms, subject to planning.  Rake is nestled in a serene setting in the heart of the South Downs National Park. Some eight miles to the west of Midhurst, it sits in one of the most affluent parts of the region, with the average property price at £687,500 according to Rightmove. The village astrides the border of Sussex and Hampshire, at the very north-west of Sussex and the east of Hampshire. In fact the county line runs right through the middle of the pub! The South Downs area around Chichester and Petersfield boasts some of the finest views on offer across the English countryside with its rolling and rugged landscape appearing untouched in many places. The village lies approximately 3 miles from the A3 between Portsmouth (22 miles) and Guildford (20 miles). Other pubs nearby include The Jolly Drover at Hill Brow (1.4 miles), The Templi Inn, In Liss (2.2 miles) and The Rising Sun at Milland (3.6 miles).  The property is not listed and is not situated within a Conservation Area. Please note that the title plan does not include 2 sets of parking areas (11 spaces in total) at the front of the pub. These areas fall under Highways, but have permission for parking for the pub.  An area of land to the West of The Flying Bull has been sold off and is earmarked for residential builds, subject to planning. Any works access will not affect the day to day running of the business. LAND INCLUDED IN THE SALE IS OUTLINED IN GREEN ON TITLE PLAN ON NEXT PAGE Those seeking alternative use are requested to make their own enquiries with the local authority -  East Hampshire District Council No inventory will be supplied or warranted. The purchase price excludes fixtures & fittings, although the purchaser will inherit any remaining items owned by the Vendor at the property on the day of completion. Site Area - Approximately 2.022 acres Total Floor Area - 5,220 sq ft *All measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping systems Freehold with benefit of vacant possession looking for unconditional offers in the region of £625,000 plus VAT. The property is being 'sold as seen' and all parties are asked to carry out their own due diligence before submitting an offer. Offers that are 'subject to planning' will not be considered. Viewings arranged through sole agents - Everard Cole. Rateable Value - £16,000 (As of 1st April 2023)

propertySubType: Bar, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Whitehouses is a Grade II Listed three and single storey detached property of painted brick elevations beneath pitched pantile and flat roofs. The internal accommodation briefly consists of an entrance hall leading from London Road into the Public Bar area, with c. 40 covers, timber bar servery, part tiled flooring and a feature fireplace. The Ladies and Gents W.C.s are accessed from the bar area. The Restaurant area is situated to the rear of the pub, with a separate entrance directly from the car park, a timber carvery servery, raised dining area with c.48 covers and glazed doors to the rear garden.  The Whitehouses also benefits from a commercial kitchen and wash-up room off, and a ground floor beer cellar. The domestic accommodation is situated over the upper floors with the first floor consisting of a lounge, two bedrooms, office, domestic kitchen and bathroom. The second floor is accessed via a retractable loft ladder on the first floor landing and comprises three additional rooms.  To the exterior, the pub has a large carpark to the side, providing more than 30 spaces; a small garden to the rear, private rear yard with bin store, various store sheds and walk-in chiller.  The Whitehouses is prominently located opposite the junction of London Road and Whitehouses Road just to the south of the north Nottinghamshire market town of Retford. Retford is a situated in the Bassetlaw District of Nottinghamshire and is an important commercial centre for the local area, with large supermarkets, many independent shops and a market every Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Retford has a strong economy mainly consisting of services with some light industry. Retail, health, manufacturing, education and accommodation are major employers. There is also a high representation of arts & recreational, finance & insurance jobs. The town has a very low unemployment rates compared to the national average Retford is located 26 miles (42 km) east of  Sheffield, 23 miles (37 km) west of Lincoln and 31 miles (50 km) north-east of Nottingham. The population at the 2021 census was 23,740.  The local authority is Bassetlaw District Council. We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed (List Entry : 1178867). Fixtures and fittings are to be purchased separately at valuation The total site area is approximately 0.698 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) extends to 3,170 ft2. Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate Rental offers are invited for a new Free of Tie commercial lease. The rent is payable quarterly in advance and subject to VAT. The new lease will be 10 or 20 years, on a Fully Repairing and Insuring basis with 5 yearly upward only reviews and annual RPI increases. The Lease may be assigned after the end of the first two years. Deposit - The equivalent of three months’ rent is required as a deposit. Interest is payable upon this.  The current Rateable Value of the Whitehouses has been assessed at £21,000.

displayAddress: Oldham Road, Ripponden, West Yorkshire, HX6 4DP

detailedDescription: A 2 storey property under  pitched slate roof being rendered and painted to all elevations. Our client has recently fully renovated and refurbished the property to a very high standard which has resulted in a high quality Bar/Restaurant trading over 2 floors. On the ground floor seating is provided by way of booth seating, low and high tables for a total of 75 customers with additional standing room, large focal central bar servery with small open kitchen area with double deck pizza oven and extraction canopy, separate wash up area and level beer cellar. To the first floor is a similar style bar area providing seating for approximately 50 customers and feature exposed ceiling timbers, exposed stone walls and again a good size bar servery, door leading through to the games room of good size and providing a pool playing area, dart throw and space for additional gaming machines. The first floor is only currently used for functions but should be incorporated into the main trading area of the business. Externally there is a small beer garden to the side of the property. The property occupies a prominent position fronting the A672 Oldham Road in the village of Ripponden surrounded by other licensed outlets, local and national retail outlets and a high degree of residential housing. Ripponden is a village in Calderdale, it lies in the Ryburn Valley approximately 5 miles west of Halifax and easy access to the M62 Motorway giving good links to both Leeds and Manchester. The property is not listed or in a flood zone. All trade fixtures and fittings are included in the sale. Total site area extends to 0.093 Acres with a floor area of 380 Sq M. Please note measurements have been taken from a digital mapping system.  The current Rateable Value has been assessed at £22,250. From April 2026 there is a slight increase to £24,500. Enquires should be made to Calderdale Council.

displayAddress: 130 Coggeshall Road, Marks Tey, Essex, CO6 1LT
propertySubType: Public House, Land / Development, Other, Alternate Use, Leisure, Bar, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Red Lion is a detached, Grade II Listed building which is predominantly arranged over two storeys under a pitched tiled roof. The property requires refurbishment throughout. The bar area is accessed from the front of the main building and provides around 36 covers. Male & female WCs are also present. The restaurant area is adjacent and serves a further c. 24 covers. To the rear of the property, there is a commercial trade kitchen and cellar, located at ground floor level. The private accommodation is all situated at 1st floor level and consists of 2 double bedrooms, office and bathroom. A separate lounge/bedroom is accessed via a dedicated staircase. To the eastern side of the property is a large trade garden, replete with children’s play area. To the rear of the property is an outbuilding which has been used for storage along with a fenced private garden. Car parking, for up to 25 vehicles, is available to the front and side of the property. Overage The sale of the freehold interest is subject to an overage provision placed on the title by a previous owner, expiring in August 2027 , providing a 15% uplift in value, applying only to new build residential development on the whole site and excluding conversion of the existing building. The overage liability to occur either on the implementation of the permission or sale of the land with the benefit of permission. Marks Tey is a large village, located 6 miles west of Colchester. The village itself benefits from a variety of facilities including a Post Office, bakery and butchers. The Red Lion is located in a prominent, roadside position on the trunk A120. A Shell petrol station is positioned nearby. We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed but not situated within a Conservation Area. Pre Application has been sought which favours continuation of commercial uses, not necessarily to be retained as a public house, opposed to residential use. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries to Colchester Borough Council  There are no fixtures and fittings in the sale. The property is being offered in 'shell' condition, on a 'sold as seen' basis. The area of the public house site is approximately 0.9 acres. The ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house extends to 222m² (2,389ft²), including the rear outbuilding. Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Freehold offers sought in excess of £375,000, exc VAT, subject to vacant possession, sold as seen. We understand the business should qualify for 100% small business rate relief (based on a Rateable Value of £5,200) Council Tax: £1,341 per annum (Band A)

propertySubType: Investment
detailedDescription: Previously the Royal British Legion, the three-storey, Grade II Listed mid-terraced property, is believed to date back to c.1830. Now trading simply as 'The Legion', the trading areas are split into two distinct areas. Since taking occupation the tenant has completely refurbished the trading areas which briefly comprise, a front bar, with bar servery and a larger bar area to the rear, now utilised as a 'pool hall' area and stage with three darts throws. The ancillary areas include the refitted Ladies, Gents and disabled W.C.s. a basement beer cellar and store room. The domestic accommodation is located over the first and second floors and briefly comprises a spacious lounge, domestic kitchen, dining room/third bedroom, bathroom and store room over the first floor. The second floor, which can be accessed via two separate staircases lead to a further two double bedrooms. The Property has been occupied by the current tenant on a 10 year lease commencing September 2024.  The asking price reflects a net initial yield of 7.03%. The property is situated on Market Street in the centre of the market town of Atherstone, in the historic centre based around St. Mary’s Church and the Market Square. Located in the far north of the county, Atherstone forms part of the border with Leicestershire along the A5 national route, and is only 4 miles from Staffordshire. It lies between the larger towns of Tamworth and Nuneaton and contains the administrative offices of North Warwickshire Borough Council. Atherstone has a long history dating back to Roman times and St Mary's Chapel dates from the 12th Century. At the 2011 census the population of the civil parish of Atherstone was 8,670, which increased to 9,212 at the 2021 census We are advised the property is Grade II Listed (Ref No. 1365161) and situated in teh Atherstone Conservation Area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries with North Warwickshire Borough Council The trade Fixtures and Fittings are owned by the Tenant. The overall site size is c. 0.077 acres and the property has a ground floor footprint of 3,045 sq ft. (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate) Offers in the region of £370,000 are invited for the Freehold interest subject to a 10 year Free-of-Tie Commercial Lease commencing September 2024. The rent commenced at £25,000 (plus VAT) for the first year, increasing by £1,000 per annum to year five. A Rent Deposit Deed is in place and the landlord is holding a deposit of £10,000. The Rateable Value has been assessed at £11,500 (2023). The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business

propertySubType: Public House, Restaurant, Bar, Cafe
detailedDescription: Prominent 2 storey and 2 tier property on main junction with painted elevations under pitched tiled roof. All trade areas refurbished and redecorated in 2021 and kept to excellent standard. Main entrance to lobby. Access to main bar and upstairs private accommodation. Spacious and bright bar area with dormer bay window seating. Wooden flooring throughout with gas fired coal effect stove, leading to a carpeted lounge area with separate servery. Both areas can seat approx 50 customers. Ladies and Gents WCs. Stairs down to a further lounge/dining area, with side entrance from car park. Seating for approx 25 customers. Further Ladies and Gents WCs. Immediately adjacent is a modest sized private dining room, ideal for small intimate gatherings/dinners. Fully equipped trade kitchen. Basement cellar, accessed from behind main bar.  1st floor private accommodation consists of 3 double bedrooms, lounge, kitchen and bathroom (all areas are part furnished and will remain in situ). External areas consist of a well presented covered decking seating area (20) leading down to an enclosed beer garden laid to grass (25). Further seating along the railway arches for approx 50 customers. Large car park for approx 25 cars.  Wymondham is an idyllic market town in South Norfolk with a picturesque marketplace, intriguing shops, medieval lanes, ancient meadows, museum, steam train station and the magnificent Wymondham Abbey, all within a few minutes walk between each spot. Wymondham is one of the fastest growing towns in Norfolk with a population of  17,495 to 19,272  as of 2024. The Railway is located on the outskirts of the town on a main junction. Just a few minutes walk from Wymondham Station with trains running between Cambridge and Norwich. The A11 (Norwich, Newmarket & Cambridge) is located just under a mile away.  The property is not listed, but is situated within a conservation area.  An extensive and well kept trade inventory is available to purchase for £20,000 (exc VAT). Site area - 0.377 acres Total building footprint of 3,114 sq ft. New 'Free of Tie' lease available. Term to be agreed. Rent £39,448 per annum. Deposit of 3 months rent (£9,861) required up front. Business plan will be required along with proof of funds to cover ingoing costs and the purchase of fixtures and fittings, legal fees, deposit, working capital & stock at c£50,000. If lease is to be agreed under a 'New Co' then a guarantor will be required.  EXPERIENCED OPERATORS ONLY-   to retain as a Pub/Restaurant. Rateable value - £16,750 as of 1st April 2026

displayAddress: 63 Kingsway, Stoke on Trent, Staffordshire, ST4 1JB

detailedDescription: The Kings Way is an attractive three storey corner property of painted brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The Kings Way benefits from an open plan ground floor trading area which briefly comprises a front entrance hall leading to the Bar, with a central timber bar servery, feature fireplace, part timber and tiled flooring, raised booth eating, pool area and a raised seating area to the rear, with perimeter and easy chair seating. Disabled and Ladies W.C.s are located off the main trading area. A staircase to the rear of the bar servery provides access to the Function Room on the first floor. The Function Room benefits from it's own timber bar servery and is currently set up for c. 30 covers. The Ladies & Gents W.C.s are also located off the first floor landing. The Kings Way also benefits from a commercial kitchen and fridge/freezer store room on the fist floor, serviced by a dumb waiter to the ground floor; a basement beer cellar and store with separate keg and cask cellars. The spacious domestic accommodation is situated over the second floor and briefly comprises, four double bedrooms, one single bedroom, bathroom with separate W.C. domestic kitchen and utility room.  The Kings Way sits in the city of Stoke-on-Trent, in a prominent location adjacent to the Stoke town hall and Kings Hall. The site is a short walk away from Stoke train station with parking available at the Kingsway Carpark immediately adjacent to the pub. The Kings Way is centrally located, being just a short walk to the shops, boutiques and local transport hubs. Stoke-on-Trent is a city and unitary authority area in the county of Staffordshire. Stoke had an estimated population of 259,965 in 2022 making it the largest settlement in Staffordshire and one of the largest cities of the Midlands. We understand the Kings Way is not Listed but is situated in a Conservation Area. The local authority is Stoke on Trent Council and prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. propertySubType: Guest House, Retail, Land / Development, Takeaway, Hotel, Cafe, Restaurant, Leisure, Other, Public House, Bar, Alternate Use
detailedDescription: Main front entrance provides split access to The Mill Restaurant and Carbon Nightclub with lift to the first floor. The restaurant also benefits from a courtyard garden for approx 50 covers. Carbon Nightclub is an extensive open space with notable light and sound system, several bar serveries, Photo-booth, Cloakroom, VIP balcony area (with bar), private booth seating and DJ booth. Capacity is around 760 standing but the venue can also be used for dinners, seating around 150 guests on round tables. There are plenty of storage areas to the rear for conference equipment and tables and chairs. There are two Kitchen areas with ample prep space to help cater for the club space and restaurant. The Sports Bar can seat approx 60 customers and has ladies and gents facilities. The property also benefits from an office, staff WC and break out room. The car park has ample parking to the front of the property for 18-20 cars. The split layout of this property makes it an ideal opportunity for those looking for change of use to alternative commercial, office, retail or residential as a whole, or as a split usage. Due to the property’s proximity to Stowmarket station, there is a notably high footfall, as well as making this easily accessible for staff and residence. The Maltings Complex is conveniently located in the heart of the thriving Suffolk market town of Stowmarket and immediately next door to the mainline railway station. Stowmarket is the largest town in the district of Mid Suffolk with a population of approximately 22,000 and it sits conveniently on the major trunk road of the A14 equidistant between Ipswich and Bury St Edmunds, With excellent rail links to London Liverpool Street (1h 25mins), Cambridge (1h 10mins) and Norwich (35mins), the town is expanding fast with the population predicted to reach in excess of 60,000 within a 10 mile radius in the next few years. The Old part of kiln (Mill) is Grade II Listed. The property is located within the Stowmarket Conservation Area. Mid Suffolk CC. Year 20111 - Reference, Description 20110764/11 - Granted.  Now Lapsed. for Conversion of nightclub into 14 dwellings and 1 replacement dwelling. Demolition of single storey extension. Formation of new private courtyards and parking within existing courtyard with associated landscape works. Our client is only willing to accept ‘Unconditional’ offers. Therefore, anyone seeking a change of use will need to make their own enquires with the local council in the first instance before presenting an offer. Our client will not consider offers that are ‘subject to planning' being agreed. All trade fixtures and fittings are included in the sale price, except for a few third party items. An Inventory can be provided once solicitors have been instructed. detailedDescription: The Derwentwater Arms is an attractive two storey detached property of stone and rendered elevations beneath pitched slate roofs. The front entrance hall provides access to the front bar area, with c.18 covers, timber bar servery, part tiled floor and double glazed patio doors providing spectacular views over the Derwent Valley. The 'Dog House' side bar has space for 40 covers, timber bar servery, tiled floors, fixed perimeter seating and darts throw. The rear Lounge bar has 24 covers, timber servery and fixed perimeter seating. The pub also benefits from Ladies & Gents W.C.s, a commercial kitchen and wash-up room, basement beer cellar Three letting rooms are situated over the upper floors. The spacious rooms are appointed to a high standard and benefit from ensuite shower rooms.   A stone-built cottage is attached to the property.  Whilst the cottage would benefit from some modernisation the accommodation briefly consists of a domestic kitchen and lounge on the ground floor, a bathroom and two bedrooms over the first floor and a further bedroom on the second floor.  A further detached stone-built property is situated to the rear of the pub. A flight of steps provide access to a small function/meeting room, with a garage at ground level.  To the exterior, the pub has a seating terrace to the front, lawned garden and childrens' play equipment. A car park is located over the road. Note - A section of the car park will be retained by the vendor (please see indicative plan), or could be available subject to negotiation. The Derwentwater Arms is prominently located in the Derbyshire village of Calver. The pub is situated in an elevated position in the centre of the village and enjoys panoramic views. Calver is a small village situated in the Hope Valley, Derbyshire. The village is bordered by the River Derwent and intersected by the A623 trunk road, which links Manchester to the west, Sheffield to the north and Chesterfield to the east. The area is popular with tourists visiting the Peak District, with strong all year round trade, and many popular walking routes radiate from Calver.  The Derwent Valley Heritage Trail runs through the village, which also benefits from a busy craft centre with shop, gallery and café, various outdoor retail shops, a garden centre and café.  Calver is approximately 12.5 miles south west of Sheffield, 10 miles east of Chesterfield and 13 miles east of Buxton. The local authority is Derbyshire Dales. We are advised the property is Grade II Listed, (Ref:1088214) and is situated in the Calver Conservation area and within the Peak District National Park. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries.  No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment.  Current rateable value (from 1 April 2023) of the Derwentwater Arms has been assessed at £13,000.

displayAddress: Bromsgrove Road, Droitwich Spa, Worcestershire, WR9 8LL

detailedDescription: The Freemasons Arms is a two storey detached property of painted brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs.  The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall from Bromsgrove Road providing access to the open plan  bare area with a central timber bar servery, part wood panelled walls, feature fireplace, part wooden flooring and darts throw.  The Ladies and Gents W.C.s are accessed from the trading area. The pub also benefits a basement beer cellar, store room, a glass wash-up area to the rear of the servery and a small kitchenette area. The domestic accommodation is located over the 1st floor, accessed via a private staircase, and briefly comprises a large lounge, kitchen-diner, three bedrooms and a bathroom.   To the exterior the pub pub benefits from a large car park, laid to tarmac, providing parking for approximately 26 cars, a lawned beer garden with picnic bench seating for approximately 60 a paved patio area, covered, with fixed timber and freestanding seating. A private rear yard provides access to a garage and store room. The Freemasons Arms is prominently located on Bromsgrove Road, the B6045, just to the north of Droitwich Spa town centre. The pub is  less than 0.5 miles form the A38 which, in turn, provides quick and easy access to the M5 motorway. Droitwich Spa (often abbreviated to Droitwich) is a historic spa town in the Wychavon district in northern Worcestershire. The town is located on the River Salwarpe approximately 22 miles (35 km) south-west of Birmingham and 7 miles (11 km) north-east of  Worcester. Droitwich shopping is mainly focused in the traditional town centre around Victoria Square, leading to the St Andrew's Square shopping centre and down to the original High Street, with its local pubs and an eclectic mix of traditional shops. As at the 2021 census, the population of Droitwich Spa was 25,027. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated within a Conservation Area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. propertySubType: Alternate Use, Land / Development

Many buildings date from the 15th century through to the 19th century. The town lies roughly half-way between Maidstone and Hastings, about 38 miles southeast of central London. 25 miles from Junction 5 on the M25 and A21 at Sevenoaks. propertySubType: Restaurant, Leisure, Investment, Public House, Bar, Hotel, Alternate Use, Land / Development, Cafe, Retail
detailedDescription: Believed to date back to 1717, the Boycott Arms, formerly called the New Inn, is a detached three and single storey property of painted brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The main bar area is accessed via the porch and through the entrance hall, with tiled floor, to the front of the building. The bar area has a traditional timber bar servery, beamed ceiling and attractive open feature fire place with brick surround. The main trading area extends through to the left providing approximately 30 covers. The property also benefits from a separate Restaurant/Function Room, that can be accessed from the main bar, whilst also having it's own separate entrance from the front, which is also used as a disabled entrance,. The room has it's own timber bar servery, two feature fireplaces and wooden flooring. The pub also benefits from Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s, and a commercial catering kitchen. The domestic accommodation is split over the two upper floors and briefly comprises five bedrooms, lounge, domestic kitchen and bathroom. To the exterior, the pub sits in a large plot of over 1.5 acres, dissected by the road. One one side, there is a large tarmac car park with brick built garage, abutting a large lawned beer garden with picnic bench seating for 60+.  A further enclosed beer garden with children’s play equipment is situated to the left hand side of the property and the remaining plot of largely undeveloped land extends to the rear and right hand side of the property. The Boycott Arms is located just off the B4176 in Upper Ludstone, Shropshire. The property is located between the historic market town of Bridgnorth and the city of Wolverhampton. Upper Ludstone is situated approximately 3 miles north-west of Bridgnorth and is surrounded by beautiful countryside. The village is home to a small community of around 200 people and has a rich history dating back to the 11th century. The village benefits from a convenience store and farm shop, the near-by picturesque village of Claverley provides further amenities including a Church, Primary School, sports clubs and a doctors surgery with the villages of Pattingham and Wombourne hosting further schooling and shopping facilities. The local authority is Shropshire Council. We are advised the property is not Listed but is regarded as a non-designated heritage asset. It is also situated in an area of designated Green Belt. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items. The Rateable Value of The Boycott Arms has been assessed at £14,500 (2023).

Accessible WC. Rear door to small, enclosed courtyard area. Emergency access to alleyway to the side of the property. Internal customer staircase to 1st floor. 1st Floor -  Ladies and Gents WC. Internal staircase leading to accommodation on 2nd floor. 2nd floor - Consisting of cellar, boiler room, storage room. Access to private accommodation (Flat 2) consisting of 3x double bedrooms, kitchen, lounge and bathroom with shower. The property is surrounded by a number of independent and national retailers, bars, cafes and restaurants. Andover is approximately 18 miles north west of Winchester and 18 miles west of Basingstoke. The town benefits from excellent communications with the A34 and M3 to the east and A303 providing access to the south west. Andover Station (1 mile) provides direct rail services from Andover to London Waterloo in approximately 1 hour and 10 minutes. The property is Grade II listed and is situated within the Andover Conservation Area. No inventory will be supplied or warranted. displayAddress: High Street, Castle Camps, Cambridgeshire, CB21 4SN
propertySubType: Restaurant, Leisure, Other, Public House, Bar
detailedDescription: The Oak is a charming detached public house presented in immaculate condition. The pub itself benefits from 2 bars serving 3 main trade areas. The front bar is carpeted with a mix of loose and banquette seating for c 24 covers, including a log burner. To the left hand side is a Lounge Bar with exposed timbers, fixed and loose seating for c 26 covers, leading onto a rear pool room, which could be utilised for dining, providing c 18/20 covers. In total there is space for c 60 internal covers. Servicing these area is a substantial commercial trade kitchen and dry stores to the rear, cellar, plus customer WC's.  The 1st floor provides a 4 person apartment (1 twin & 1 double), with kitchen, large lounge and bathroom. The Nest,  is available for short stays. To the rear is dedicated shingle car park, covered rear smoking shelter, front patio (12-18 covers) and substantial grassed trade garden (40+ covers). In addition there is a single storey residential dwelling to the rear, The Brewhouse, comprising large lounge diner, double bedroom, bathroom, private patio & storage sheds. Castle Camps is a village and civil parish in the South Cambridgeshire district, in the county of Cambridgeshire. It is 15 miles south-east of Cambridge and near to the borders of Suffolk and Essex and to the town of Haverhill. Although a small village, Castle Camps boasts an excellent school, a village pub, sports facilities, two churches, a village hall, plus various clubs. The area is also well served by footpaths, offering first rate walking within easy reach of Cambridge, Haverhill & Linton. The local authority is South Cambridgeshire District Council . The property is not Listed but does sit within Castle Camps Conservation Area.  Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries of the relevant authorities. The freehold business is available as a Transfer of a Going Concern, fully fitted, inclusive of trade inventory and full working commercial trade kitchen. The total site area is 0.27 acres.  The ground floor footprint extends to 3,080 ft2 (286 m2).    *All measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping. A proportion of the grassed trade garden is made available to use from the local farmer, at a peppercorn, for use as a pub garden, with a restrictive covenant not to build on the said land. Freehold offers are sought in the region of £430,000, excluding VAT, if applicable, inclusive of trade inventory, IP & goodwill. propertySubType: Cafe, Alternate Use, Public House, Takeaway, Leisure, Bar, Investment, Land / Development, Other, Restaurant, Industrial, Guest House, Retail
detailedDescription: Designed and built by Cecil Howitt & Partners for Home Brewery between 1964 and 1966 the Wheatsheaf is a two and single storey detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched copper and flat roofs. The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall fronting Sneinton Road, which leads to the main public bar with timber bar servery, tiled flooring, fixed perimeter seating and space of pool table and darts throw. The Wheatsheaf also benefits from a lounge Bar and snug, both with bar serveries and fixed perimeter seating. The property also benefits from a Ladies and Gents W.C.s, a small prep kitchen and a basement beer cellar. The spacious domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and briefly comprises lounge, five bedrooms, box room, bathroom with separate W.C. and domestic kitchen. To the exterior, the pub benefits from an enclosed rear yard/car parking area leading to a garage; and a 'crazy-paved' terrace to the front and side providing a good sized outdoor drinking area overlooking Sneinton Road. The Wheatsheaf is prominently located at the junction of Sneinton Road and Haywood Street in the Nottingham suburb of Sneinton.  The area is bounded by Nottingham city centre to the west, Bakersfield to the north, Colwick to the east, and the River Trent to the south. Sneinton lies within the unitary authority of Nottingham City, having been part of the borough of Nottingham since 1877. The pub is located on busy road within the large mixed residential area. The Wheatsheaf lies on the western edge of the suburb, close to the city centre and is little over a 5 minute walk to the Nottingham Arena, the Lace Market area and the wider city centre. The local authority is Nottingham City Council. We are advised the property is not Listed nor is it situated in a Conservation Area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. Enter through the front porch leads to a traditional open plan bar area of character, having part polished wooden floor, exposed ceiling beams, open fire with feature surround and an impressive central bar servery. The whole bar area can seat approximately 50-60 persons on fixed perimeter seating and an assortment of chairs around polished timber top tables. The private accommodation is spacious and comprises three bedrooms, lounge, kitchen and bathroom, all of which are in good condition.   The property occupies a prominent position in a plot of 0.443 Acres some 1.5 miles from Berwick Upon Tweed town centre in the village of East Ord. Berwick-upon-Tweed, sometimes known simply as Berwick, is a town and civil parish in Northumberland, England located approximately just 2 miles south of the Anglo-Scottish border, it is the northern most town in England. displayAddress: London Road, Great Missenden, Buckinghamshire, HP16 0DG
propertySubType: Bar, Other, Leisure, Restaurant, Hotel, Public House, Guest House
detailedDescription: The Nags Head is a charming 15th century historic pub, nestled in the beautiful village of Great Missenden set amongst the rolling Chiltern Hills. It is one of the oldest pubs in the area, known for its rich history. It offers AA Rosette dining, beautifully appointed accommodation, and benefits from exposed wooden beams and an open fireplace. The traditional ground floor trade areas provides a largely open plan area with central bar servery and a mix of loose and fixed seating for c 60 covers. A substantial and well fitted commercial kitchen, wash up and storage is situated to the rear. A large cellar is situated at basement level. Customer WC's are located close to the rear lobby entrance. The 1st floor provides 7 en-suite letting rooms, all individual and unique, presented to a high standard. Externally there is dedicated tarmac parking, with c 30 spaces, as well as a rear overflow parking area.  To the rear is a large grassed trade garden, with feature teepee, popular with customers all year around. Service yard, bin and storage areas. Great Missenden is a very pretty and affluent village in the Misbourne Valley in the Chiltern Hills, Buckinghamshire. It is situated between the towns of Amersham and Wendover and adjoins the village of Little Kingshill. The Nags Head is located in the centre of the village, not far from the Roald Dahl Museum. Bekonscot Model Village & Railway is also close by. The Nags Head is situated on London Road, close to the A413, between Great Missenden Tennis Club & Chiltern Hospital. We are advised that the Nag's Head is Grade II Listed.  Listing No. 1124959. The local authority is Buckinghamshire Council The area of the site is 0.8 acres with a total floor area of 1,837 ft² (171 square metres) (Title No. BM403160 & BM333800) * Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Freehold offers are sought in the region of £750,000 (excluding VAT) to include all fixtures, fittings, goodwill and IP.  Stock at Valuation. Rateable Value, as of 1st April 2023, is £65,000.

propertySubType: Bar, Takeaway, Leisure, Retail, Restaurant, Public House, Other, Alternate Use
detailedDescription: The character property benefits from a prominent roadside position, being a two storey brick built property under pitch slate roof. Access via central doorway leading into a lobby entrance, collection and takeaway areas, with space for tables and chairs leading onto a rear bar. To the right hand side is a largely open plan dining room with space for at least 50 covers. To the rear is a further sizeable storage area. To the left-hand side is a commercial kitchen, dry store and wash up area. The 1st floor provides domestic accommodation, comprising three bedrooms (two double and one single) bathroom and separate WC, along with large lounge area. Externally the property provides a dedicated side parking area, with space for c 10 cars, along with two brick outbuildings and rear service yard. The market town of March is in the county of Cambridgeshire located only 34 miles North of Cambridge and 20 miles East of Peterborough.  The local railway station connects directly to Cambridge, Ely and Peterborough.  The town centre boasts a mix of independent shops, eateries and some national chains and holds a weekly market.  The population of March as of 2021 census is around 22,970. The Diana Tandoori is located in a prominent roadside position, facing Dartford Road (B1099), in a predominantly residential area. propertySubType: Other, Public House, Leisure, Bar, Restaurant, Cafe
detailedDescription: Internal Trade Areas - Main lobby entrance to front of property, with access to main bar and restaurant area. Main bar with wooden top severy. Carpeted throughout with fixed bay seating. Coal burner and access to Ladies and Gents WC. The area can seat approx 40 customers. Leading to function or sports room to the rear. Large open plan space which is ideal for pool table and showing live sports. Alternatively the room could be used as a function space to seat approx 40-50 customers. Immediate access to the trade kitchen. Patio door to the beer garden. Turning left in the main lobby provides access to a restaurant/dining area with separate wooden top servery. Wooden flooring throughout. Fireplace for wood burner. Access to rear beer garden. Area can seat approx 50 customers. Basement cellar accessed from behind the main bar servery. Trade kitchen with wash up/prep area and dry store. Private Accommodation - 1st floor (internal access only) consisting of 2 double bedrooms, lounge, bathroom and kitchen. Further stairs leading to access to ground floor flat roof.  External Areas - Extensive car park to the side and front of the property, for at least 50 cars. Large beer garden laid to grass with raised patio seating area, which can seat approx 70 customers.  The Norman Warrior is located on a main roundabout intersection between Lowestoft town centre (1.2 miles) and Oulton Broad North railway station (1 mile) with bus stops nearby and ample parking. The pub itself is set in a residential area, with plenty of local footfall. There is also a convenience store, fish & chip shop & kebab shop located next door.  Oulton Broad is a busy tourist and sporting centre with many beautiful sights to take in, a range of activities to try out and places to visit, shop, eat and drink. Lowestoft is famous for being the most easterly town and the first place to see the sunrise in the UK, it's also the birthplace of composer Benjamin Britten. With its alluring sandy beach and the beautiful Broads, Lowestoft is a place that connects with and celebrates the sea. The town is a favourite with families, and there's plenty to see and do; with two piers, a wildlife park, an award-winning theme park, museums and a busy theatre which is home to the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra. The property is not listed and is not situated within a conservation area. Ingoing tenant will purchase the loose trade inventory from the landlord at an agreed valuation on completion of the Lease (or Agreement for Lease if sooner). The Lease will be protected by Part II of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954. The in-going tenant will also be responsible for all rates and any other outgoings that may affect the property including but not limited to utility charges and they must notify all continuing suppliers to the property of their occupation at the beginning of the Term. The rent will be subject to annual increase in line with the Retail Price Index and also an upwards only open market review will be conducted every 5 years and also on the penultimate day of the Term. displayAddress: 56-58 Main Street, Etwall, Derby, Derbyshire, DE65 6LP
propertySubType: Restaurant, Public House, Bar, Guest House, Land / Development, Alternate Use, Hotel, Cafe, Leisure
detailedDescription: The Blenheim House Hotel is a Grade II Listed property constructed in the early 18th Century with early C19th additions and alterations. The property benefits from a large pub and dining area to the ground floor with multiple dining, and/or separate function, rooms available. The ground floor accommodation briefly comprises the main pubic house area with c. 50 covers, timber bar servery, perimeter and freestanding seating, two feature fireplaces, feature wine cellar, timber and quarry-tiled flooring;  Function room, two dining rooms, hotel reception area and Ladies, Gents and disabled W.C.s.  The property also benefits from a good sized, well equipped commercial catering kitchen, with wash-up area, walk-in refrigerator, ground floor beer cellar and stores.   The Property benefits from 10x letting rooms in total (one currently used as staff quarters), arranged over the ground and first floors.  The letting rooms comprise 2x suites, 2x single rooms and 6x double rooms. The domestic accommodation is located over the second floor and comprises a master bedroom, 2nd bedroom with en-suite, lounge, office, dining room and domestic kitchen.   A small car park to the right of the building provides c. 6 spaces. A single storey detached outbuilding in this area includes two ensuite hotel rooms and a beauty salon, which is let separately on a yearly licence. An attractive paved outdoor terrace, with wooden decking is located to the front of the venue and a larger outdoor space, laid to tarmac, on the other side property provides an outdoor drinking area, (with seating for c. 20) and bin storage area.  The Blenheim House Hotel is prominently situated on Main Street in the Derbyshire village of Etwall. Etwall is a village and civil parish in the South Derbyshire district and is located southwest of Derby on the A50. Etwall dates from the 7th Century AD and ‘Etewell’ was recorded in the Domesday Book of 1086. Since 1970 the annual Well Dressing Festival has taken place on the third weekend in May, attracting visitors from far and wide. Etwall is located between the A516 bypass - which draws heavy traffic heading for the M1 north, and the A50. The village has its own public library, several schools including a state pre-school, state primary, an independent day school and the large secondary school, John Port Spencer Academy.  The population of Etwall parish at the 2021 Census was 3,412. The property is positioned just over seven miles south west of Derby City Centre. It is centrally located for the Derbyshire countryside and a short distance from other notable locations including; Alton Towers, Toyota, the A50 leading to the North West of England and M1 junction 24a. displayAddress: 15 Farndon Road, Newark 0n Trent, Nottinghamshire, NG24 4SA

detailedDescription: The Spring House is an attractive Grade II Listed, three and single storey detached property of painted rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The Spring House benefits from a single open plan trading area over the ground floor, which briefly comprises a front entrance hall leading to the Public Bar, with a central timber bar servery, brick-built feature fireplace, part timber flooring, darts throw and exit hall and doorway leading onto Mill Gate. The trading area can accommodate c. 60 covers in total. The rear hallway provides access to the Ladies and Gents W.C.s. The Spring House also benefits from a commercial kitchen and wash up area, store room and basement beer cellar. The domestic accommodation is situated over the first and second floors and briefly comprises: 1st floor - Three good sized rooms, domestic kitchen, office and bathroom. Second floor - Three further rooms. The accommodation is not currently occupied and is in need of remedial attention.   To the exterior the pub has a drinking area laid to tarmac at the front of the pub with picnic bench seating for 30; a rear car park providing parking for approximately 10 cars and a private yard and store.  The Spring House is prominently located at the junction of Farndon Road and Mill Gate in the popular Nottinghamshire market town of Newark on Trent. The pub is situated on the edge of the town centre, opposite both Newark Marina and the Sconce and Devon Park, a Scheduled Ancient Monument and Nature Reserve. Newark is an attractive Nottinghamshire town that sits close to the Lincolnshire border some 20 miles northeast of Nottingham. Newark has a population of about 27,000 and throughout the year there is a thriving visitor & tourist trade attracted to its historic medieval castle which dates back to 1135 AD, aircraft museum & busy showground which hosts numerous markets & events throughout the Summer months. With its pleasant environment, including the surrounding villages, and its good transport links, the town is becoming a popular commuter town for the expanding city of Nottingham and increasingly for London due to its direct rail link The Spring House is Listed Grade: II (List Entry Number: 1196407), and situated in the Newark Conservation Area. displayAddress: 115 Belle Vue Road, Shrewsbury, Shropshire, SY3 7NJ

detailedDescription: The Belle Vue Tavern, believed to have been originally three cottages and converted into a pub in the mid-1800s, is a two and single storey end of terrace property of brick and partially rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The comfortable and friendly public house has an entrance hall from the road providing access to the trading areas. The pub has a linear trading area which can be separated into four areas which function as public bar, snug and lounge. The trade area has c. 64 covers in total and is served by a timber bar servery, with an open feature fireplace, beamed ceiling, darts throw and some fixed perimeter seating.  The Belle Vue also benefits from Ladies & Gents W.C.s, store room housing boiler and a basement beer cellar.  The domestic accommodation is located over the first floor and briefly comprises two double bedrooms, lounge, kitchen, store room, family bathroom and separate W.C. A small raised area to the front provides an outdoor smoking area and seating for c.6. The property is located in the Belle Vue area of Shrewsbury. Built up during the 19th and early 20th Centuries, it is now mainly residential, with Belle Vue Road (the A5191) running through the middle of the are. Shrewsbury  is a market town and civil parish in Shropshire. It is the county town of the ceremonial county of Shropshire, located 9 miles east of the England-Wales border.  Shrewsbury serves as the commercial centre for Shropshire and parts of mid-Wales, with a retail output of over £299 million per year and light industry and distribution centres, such as Battlefield Enterprise Park on the outskirts. The A5 and A49 trunk roads come together as the town's by-pass and five railway lines meet at Shrewsbury rail station.  It is sited on the River Severn, 33 miles northwest of Wolverhampton, 15 miles west of Telford, 31 miles southeast of Wrexham and 43 miles west of Birmingham. At the 2021 census, the parish had a population of 76,782. Supporting these areas is a large ground floor cellar, service yard, accessible, male & female WC’s, plus a relatively small commercial trade kitchen capable of extending. The generous private accommodation is all situated at first-floor level and consists of three bedrooms (two single & one double), lounge and bathroom. It is one of the largest towns in Cambridgeshire with the 2021 census recording in excess of 33,000 residents. The Bulls Head is positioned to the east of the town centre on Cambridge Street, approximately 0.6 miles from the river in a largely residential area. displayAddress: High  Street, Hagworthingham, Spilsby, Lincolnshire, PE23 4NA

detailedDescription: The George & Dragon is a two and single storey detached property of painted rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. Entering the pub from the main front door, you arrive in a cosy and snug trade space, with a central timber bar servery, beamed ceiling and fixed perimeter seating. The area accommodates approximately 60 covers in total. The 'dog-friendly' bar area seats approximately 24 and benefits from a timber bar servery, feature fireplace with wood burner and beamed ceiling. A double glazed conservatory to the rear of the pub overlooks the rear garden and provides an additional 24 covers, which can also be used as a function room. The pub also benefits from Ladies & Gents W.C.s, a good sized commercial kitchen with wash-up room, food store and fridge-freezer store.   The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and briefly comprises three bedrooms, lounge, family bathroom and domestic kitchen-diner. To the exterior, the pub sits in a generous plot of 1.011 acres and comprises a bench seating area to the front, lawned beer garden with childrens play equipment to the rear; and a lawned paddock with parking and electric for 7 camper vehicles as well as an additional 5 non-hook-up pitches. There is also a recently refurbished shower and facilities block for the campsite and an additional 25 car parking spaces. The George & Dragon is prominently located on the A158 in the Lincolnshire village of Hagworthingham. Hagworthingham is a quaint, historic village, surrounded by an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty in the Lincolnshire countryside. There are two main market towns close by, Horncastle and Spilsby, which are both very popular with tourists and residents. Transport links into these towns from the village are mainly via bus and are particularly frequent, following the main arterial road of the A158. This road also takes you straight to the coast and the ever popular seaside town of Skegness is only 15 miles away. Horncastle and Spilsby are both fortunate to have an abundance of history surrounding them, making them interesting places to visit and spend time and Hagworthingham itself is the ideal location for walkers, ramblers and hikers to set up camp or settle down for the night. The local authority is East Lindsey council. We are advised the property is not Listed but is situated in an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. propertySubType: Restaurant, Leisure, Other, Bar, Public House
detailedDescription: The Montagu Arms is an attractive 2 storey stone property, which overlooks the local brook and bridge. This 16th-century stone-built inn has been extensively refurbished and extended during the private owners 15 year tenure. The property provides a characterful public bar to the front, snug and large restaurant to the rear. The traditionally decorated bar area has original exposed beams on the ceiling and walls, stone flooring and log burners. The conservatory restaurant overlooks the rear garden, providing a dining area away from the main bar with space over 40 covers. The extensive car park is behind the inn and accessed via the village hall entrance, via Hemington Road, with space for 50 cars. At the rear is a patio, trade garden and children's play area. There is disabled access from the rear to the restaurant only. Recent alterations have enlarged the bar area with the relocation of the cellar to the front outbuilding.  Additional outbuildings and storage is arranged to the northern boundary. The 1st floor provides generous domestic accomodation (4 beds), office space and storage. The village of Barnwell is located in North Northamptonshire and is 2 miles south of the town of Oundle, 78 miles north of London and 14 miles south-west of Peterborough, just off the A605 The River Nene runs north of the village, separating it from Oundle. The Montagu Arms Barnwell  is unopposed and is situated in a central corner position in the picturesque village of Barnwell, directly facing Barnwell Brook. Rockingham Forest & Barnwell Country Park are on the doorstep with Rutland Water and Titchmarsh Nature Reserve a short dive away. The property is administered by North Northamptonshire Council  and further enquiries should be made directly. The Montagu Arms is Grade II Listed (Entry No- 1040283) The business is available as a going concern, inclusive of comprehensive wholly owned trade inventory, fixtures & fittings. Total building footprint 5,614ft2 (522m2).  Site area- 4,040m² / 1 acre, with an additional area, outlined blue, being on a free loan arrangement, measuring 320m²/ 0.08 acres. Stock at valuation in addition, on completion.   Rental £90,000 per annum. Rateable Value is £37,500 (as at 1st April 2023)

propertySubType: Leisure, Restaurant, Public House, Guest House
detailedDescription: The King Williams IV is originally a c.17th detached character property which has been extended to the rear and maintained to a high standard throughout. The internal trading areas comprise an open plan restaurant, bar and snug area, sectioned off with character beams and exposed timbers. In total it caters to c.125 covers and incorporates large open fire with seating area and numerous period features, including feature bar servery. It is ably supported by a large, very well-equipped commercial kitchen and adjoining prep space. In addition there are staff, ladies and gents WCs along with an ample ground floor cellar. The private accommodation, situated at 1st floor level consists of: 4 double bedrooms (1 ensuite), 2 singles, laundry room and bathroom. Externally, there is a very large rear car park (c 50 cars) and grassed overspill area along with front and rear trade gardens, laid mainly to lawn and with bench seating c 60 covers in total.  The King William IV is a unique pub located in the beautiful village of Heydon, which lies south of Cambridge, between Royston and Saffron Walden.  Situated on the edge of the Essex, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire borders, easily accessible from the A505, within easy reach of junction 10 of the M11 motorway. The village has a number of amenities including a primary school, shops, a post office, village hall and a doctor's surgery. Elm farm Country House Hotel is located in a prominent position in the desirable village, directly fronting Norwich Road.   This building is not listed, but the property lies within Horsham St Faith Conservation Area. displayAddress: Rockwell Lane, Pant, Oswestry, Shropshire, SY10 9QR
propertySubType: Bar, Restaurant, Land / Development, Alternate Use, Public House, Leisure, Cafe, Investment
detailedDescription: The Cross Guns is a two and single storey detached property of rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The Cross Guns is an expansive pub that was renovated in 2022. The well maintained pub is accessed via entrances from the front conservatory. The ground floor accommodation briefly consists of a Bar area, with corner bar servery, part tiled floor and space of pool table. The Lounge bar benefits from a timber bar servery, timber flooring and feature fireplace with stone brick surround. The conservatory provides a formal dining area with space for c. 22 covers. The pub also benefits from Ladies and Gents W.C.s, commercial kitchen, ground floor beer cellar, bottle store, utility room and freezer room.  The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and briefly compromises of two bedrooms, living room, domestic kitchen and bathroom. To the exterior the pub sits in a plot of 0.729 acres and benefits from a car park to the front, with c. 20 spaces, an outdoor drinking area to the front with picnic bench seating space for c.50, and a large, lawned beer garden to the side with space for over 100 and a further private lawned are to the rear. The Cross Guns stands as a prominent landmark in the picturesque village of Pant, Oswestry. The property is situated at the junction of the busy A483, that connects Oswestry to Welshpool, and Briggs Lane. Positioned on the English-Welsh border, this location enjoys a steady flow of visitors, ranging from tourists staying at local caravan parks to day trippers and other passing travellers. Pant is a quaint village in Shropshire which lies near the border with Wales.  Pant means 'hollow' in Welsh: it is located directly below the disused mines at Llanymynech Rocks Nature Reserve. The population of the village as at the 2021 census is 1,172. Pant has a few notable features: Llanymynech Golf Club is unique as the only 18 hole course in the UK to straddle the border between two countries and Llanymynech Ogof, a copper mine where many Roman artefacts have been found.  The local authority is Shropshire Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. The site lies partially in an area potentially at risk of flooding, designated as being in flood zones 2 or 3. The Cross Guns does appear on the Local Authority’s AVC Register. It was successfully entered onto the list on 07/07/2024. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries.
