propertySubType: Bar, Restaurant, Public House
detailedDescription: The White Hart is a dominant corner semi-detached property over 2 floors, which has been linked over the years via a single-storey extension (with loft area at the far end) to the rear outbuilding. Trading areas consist of a large two-section split level bar around a central bar servery with large fireplace and access to ladies and gents WC's. The area could accommodate up to 80 seated customers. Office area and ground floor cellar (with access to courtyard) behind the servery as well as internal access to private accommodation on 1st floor. The main ground floor has been extended and previously used as a dining space (with disabled WC) with dance floor and separate servery, which leads through to a prep or storage area, commercial kitchen, storage space with door to patio garden and stairs to a 1st floor loft area above the kitchen over 2 rooms, which could be converted to a self-contained one bedroom flat for live in managers or chefs’ accommodation. External area consists of an enclosed patio garden with gate access to side road. The area could comfortably sit 40 customers. The private accommodation is located on the first floor, all rooms are located off a main landing consisting of a lounge, three bedrooms (one with an en-suite), kitchen/diner and main bathroom. The White Hart occupies a prominent corner position within the large traditional Norfolk market town of Swaffham, overlooking the marketplace and close to the town's main two parking areas. Swaffham is situated just off the main A47 trunk road, which links the Midlands through to Norwich and the east coast resorts of Great Yarmouth and Lowestoft. The major conurbations of King's Lynn and Norwich are around 15 miles west and 30 miles east respectively, whilst the A1065 links the town south to Newmarket and the A14, with the north Norfolk coast around 25 miles north. The local authority is Breckland Council. We are advised the premises is Grade II Listed and falls within a Conservation Area. The area of the site is 0.1 acres with a total floor area of 5,231 ft² (486 square metres) * Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. The property is available by way of a new, 20-year 'free of tie' lease with an initial rent of £27,500 per annum, exclusive of VAT. There is no premium payable for the benefit of the new lease. The new lease will be on a Full Repairing and Insuring basis with Annual RPI increases (min 2.5% / max 5%) and 5 yearly open market rent reviews. Ingoing rental incentives may be offered, subject to the tenant’s assessed covenant strength and overall business plan. Applicants must have sufficient capital available to cover 3 months' rent, along with building insurance, standard £1,750 legal fees contribution and working capital. Proof of funding and a business plan will be required, along with a deposit equivalent to 6 months rent + VAT. Rateable Value - £13,500. Council Tax – Band B

propertySubType: Land / Development, Alternate Use
detailedDescription: The property is sited on the grounds of a former workshop, which is believed to have been demolished around the mid-1990s. The current property, comprising a mid-terrace 4 storey house with three integral ground floor garages, was constructed of cavity blockwork with brick facing elevations under a pitched and tiled roof incorporating some Velux windows. The property comprises a ground floor entrance hall, with storeroom housing the computer server off, and a staircase leading to a first floor. The first floor comprises an open plan area incorporating a staff dining area, kitchen with a good quality range of units and appliances and an external timber decked balcony area. The first-floor landing provides access to a W.C. and staircase leading to the second floor. The second floor is an open plan office area and a landing with staircase leading to the third floor. The third floor comprises an office/room, a second office room and separate store room, with a shower room. The office accommodation is a mix of stud and masonry partitioned offices and the accommodation is uniform throughout having solid floors overlaid with carpet.  The property is located on Ristes Place, in the ‘Lace Market’ area of Nottingham city centre. Ristes Place is a cul-de-sac road, in the city centre. The property lies in a mixed residential/commercial area lying close to the City Centre. The surrounding neighbourhood comprises a mix of converted and purpose-built flats and offices. In addition, period buildings have been converted to offices and other alternative uses including residential. To the rear the subject property overlooks St Mary’s Rest Garden. Nottingham is a tourist destination, receiving the second-highest number of overnight visitors in the Midlands and the highest number in the East Midlands. In the Census 2021, Nottingham had a reported population of 323,632. The wider conurbation, which includes many of the city's suburbs, has a population of 768,638. It is the largest urban area in the East Midlands and the second-largest in the Midlands. The metropolitan economy of Nottingham is the seventh-largest in the United Kingdom with a GDP of $50.9 billion. Aside from Birmingham, it is the only city in the Midlands to be ranked as a sufficiency-level world city by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network. The local authority is Nottingham City Council. We are advised that the property is not Listed but is situated within the Lace Market Conservation Area. Current Use Class E, although an application for proposed conversion from Class E office to C3 Residential dwelling (Ref. No: 22/00623/PACPD) was granted in a decision notice dated 13th July 2022. The property has a total Net Internal Area (NIA) of 230m2 or 2,476 ft2 over all floors (excluding standard facilities), plus the balcony of c. 431 ft2 and occupies a plot of approximately 0.028 acres. Rateable Value of the Property has been assessed at £14,500.

propertySubType: Retail, Alternate Use, Bar, Leisure, Public House, Investment, Restaurant, Cafe, Other, Takeaway
detailedDescription: Inner entrance porch leading through to a recently refurbished open plan, split level bar area with large screen TV's accommodating approximately 65 persons on fixed perimeter seating and low stools around wooden topped tables, part stripped wooden floor and part tiled floor with a central timber fronted bar servery under a solid wooden counter. On the lower level in the main bar is a games area with dart throw and seating approximately 12 persons. Ladies and Gentleman's toilets are located to the rear of the bar area and are furnished to a good standard. The beer cellar is located in the basement. The catering kitchen is located on the first floor and has a range of commercial catering equipment and stainless steel benches all of good quality and condition. 3 Bedroom owners accommodation, lounge, office and bathroom, fully decorated throughout and re-carpeted.    Otley is a bustling market town located off the A660 11 miles north west of the city of Leeds, 11 miles south west of the spa town of Harrogate and 6 miles south east of Ilkley. This extremely popular town oozes character with is narrow cobbled streets, historic buildings and being located on the banks of the River Wharfe. The Otley Tavern is located on New Market which is off the B6451 Bondgate in the centre of the town. The property is Grade 2 Listed. The current fixtures and fittings are owned by the current tenant and will be taken on completion but will be replaced with simular items. Total site area of 0.028 acre. Building footprint of 1,176 Sq Ft (109 Sq M). Measurements taken from an online digital portal. Freehold Rateable Value:  £6,100.

propertySubType: Alternate Use, Retail, Leisure, Cafe, Takeaway, Public House, Other, Restaurant, Guest House, Bar
detailedDescription: Inner entrance porch leading through to the main bar area which has character having exposed ceiling beams, part stone flooring, cast iron multi fuel burner in a feature exposed brick surround to one end of the bar area and an open fire with stone surround to the other end. The bar can accommodate approximately 45 persons on fixed perimeter seating, chairs and low stools with a central bar servery. There is a small commercial catering kitchen to the rear. Ladies and Gentleman's toilets. The living accommodation is located on the first floor and briefly comprises of 3 bedrooms, lounge, kitchen and bathroom. Externally there is a cobbled area to the front of the property furnished with picnic style benches and a small yard area to the rear. Please note the rear yard has a vehicle right of way to the neigbouring property.   The property occupies a prominent position on the Main Street through the centre of Helperby. Helperby is a picturesque village situated close to the serene landscapes of North Yorkshire. Known for its charming rural atmosphere, Helperby offers a perfect getaway for those seeking tranquility and natural beauty. The village is surrounded by lush greenery, with numerous walking trails that invite visitors to explore the scenic countryside and enjoy the peaceful environment. The local authority is North Yorkshire County Council. We are advised that the property is Listed (Ref 1189460) . Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. We are further advised that the property is listed as an Asset of Community Value (ACV). No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint measures 2,154 sq ft and the overall plot is 0.085 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The current Rateable Value has been assessed at £3,000 (2023). The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

displayAddress: Main Street, Edenham, Bourne, Lincolnshire, PE10 0LL
propertySubType: Restaurant, Public House, Bar
detailedDescription: The Five Bells is a delightful 2 and single storey detached property of stone elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The Five Bells enjoys an inviting layout with two separate trading areas that are full of traditional charm and character, with a modern twist. The ground floor accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall providing access to the L-shaped Main Bar, with approximately 40 covers, a timber bar servery, well equipped for the trade, two open fireplaces with stone surround, separate pool area, darts throw and upholstered perimeter seating. The Restaurant is located to the rear of the pub and can also be utilised as a separate function room. The Restaurant briefly comprises a timber bar servery, feature fireplace, timber flooring, upholstered perimeter seating, exposed stone walls and beamed ceiling. The Restaurant has a capacity of approximately 70 covers in total.  The property also benefits from Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s, with baby change facilities, a fully equipped commercial catering kitchen, with fridge-freezer store and wash up area and a basement beer cellar. The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and can be accessed from within the pub, or via a private door fronting Main Street. The accommodation briefly comprises three double bedrooms, one with ensuite facilities, lounge, domestic kitchen and bathroom. To the exterior, the Five Bells benefits from an attractive rear lawned beer garden with a paved rear terrace and seating for c. 20; picnic bench seating for a further 40 and an attractive decked area overlooking the East Glen river. A car park, laid to tarmac, envelops the pub to the side and rear, providing approximately 30 spaces, with a timber smoking shelter, shed, garage and outdoor store housing boiler.  The Five Bells is prominently located on the A151, Main Street, in the centre of the picturesque Lincolnshire village of Edenham. Edenham is a village and civil parish in the South Kesteven district of Lincolnshire. It is located approximately 3 miles (5 km) north-west of Bourne along the A151. The Five Bells is positioned a mile away from Grimsthorpe Castle, which is a country house within a 3,000 acre park of rolling pastures, lakes, and woodland landscaped by Capability Brown. The castle is a popular tourist destination drawing visitors from all over the country. The population of the civil parish at the 2011 census was 291. The Local Authority is South Kesteven District Council. We understand the property is not Listed but prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. We understand all Trade fixtures and fittings are owned outright and will be included in the sale. The ground floor footprint is 3,811 sq ft and the overall plot measures 0.534 acres.(Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Property is offered by way of a brand new leasehold interest. The agreement will be a Free of Tie, full repairing and insuring lease, for a term of years to be agreed. The commencing rent will be in the region of £25,000 per annum.  The 2017 Rateable Value has been assessed at £1,800. The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

displayAddress: Cautherly Lane, Great Amwell, Ware, SG12 9SW
propertySubType: Public House, Leisure, Restaurant, Guest House, Cafe, Bar
detailedDescription: George IV is a prominent two storey brick built public house under pitch slate roof in a desirable area, south of Ware. The entire premises is presented in immaculate condition, having been well maintained with comprehensive investment during the private owner's tenure. The ground floor provides open plan trade areas, including bar and dining space (38 covers). Serving these areas is a substantial commercial trade kitchen and wash up area with side access and service yard, along with cellar and storage areas. There is a large function room/restaurant area regularly used throughout the year accommodating 40 – 50 covers. The 1st floor provides excellent residential accommodation, comprising two bedrooms, bathroom and kitchen. Externally there is a terrace to the front with heated parasols and space for 50+ covers while the lower ground floor provides a further terrace with space for 40+ covers and internal interactive darts area. Great Amwell is a picturesque village located in East Hertfordshire, sitting 1.5 miles southeast of Ware and approximately 20 miles north of London. The nearby towns of Hoddesdon, Harlow and Hertford are all within a short drive.   A strong community spirit underpins village life with annual festivals and summer music concerts, the George IV pub is a social hub and a prominent part of the village. The public house is located on a corner plot in the middle of the village and offers a warm, welcoming and charming atmosphere combined with a cosy interior.  The beer garden and outdoor seating area provide a wonderful summer dining experience.  The local authority is East Herts District Council. We are advised that the property is not listed, but is does sit within the East Herts Conversation area. Use class Sui Generis (old class A4). The business is full fitted with comprehensive wholly owned trade inventory, including commercial kitchen. The area of the public house site is approximately 0.143 acres. The ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house extends to 291 m² (3,128 ft²). Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Freehold offers are sought in excess of £675,000 (excluding VAT), inclusive of comprehensive trade inventory, goodwill and IP. TUPE will apply.  Stock at valuation on completion, in addition. The rateable value as of 1st April 2026 will be £42,500.  The owners are currently challenging the 2026 rateable value.

propertySubType: Alternate Use, Land / Development, Retail, Public House, Leisure, Restaurant, Investment, Bar, Guest House, Cafe
detailedDescription: The Plough Inn is a three storey detached property, of part brick, part rendered elevations. The pub dates from circa early 19th-century, and was part of the original Thorpe Acre village. The property has an unusual look is due to a change in road layout that has resulted in the 'back' of the pub adjoining the road. The lounge bar is accessed via steps leading from the road, via an entrance hall. The L-shaped room has a timber bar servery, fireplace and exposed brickwork, part tiled flooring, upholstered perimeter and freestanding seating. The 'front' bar has a timber bar servery, open feature fireplace, part tiled floor and fixed perimeter seating.   An inner hallway provides access to the Ladies and Gents W.C.s. The property also benefits from a commercial kitchen and basement beer cellar and store. The spacious domestic accommodation is situated over the upper floors and briefly comprises a domestic kitchen, bathroom and two large rooms over the first floor and three large bedrooms over the second floor. To the exterior, the pub has a large lawned beer garden, previously incorporating a childrens' play area, brick built outbuildings and store, and a car park with space for 17 vehicles.  The Plough is prominently located on Thorpe Acre in a residential area of Loughborough.  Thorpe Acre is situated in the north-west area of Loughborough was a hamlet of about twenty dwellings until the mid-20th century. The pub has a strong population density surrounding with almost 5,000 people within 500 metres and 11,343 within 1km radius. Loughborough is a popular market town in the Charnwood Borough of Leicestershire. It is the administrative centre of Charnwood Borough Council. At the 2021 census the town's built-up area had a population of 64,884. Loughborough University is regularly ranked in the Top 10 British universities and has the largest sports scholarship in the UK. It is the second largest settlement in the county after Leicester and is close to the Nottinghamshire border, being roughly equidistant to Leicester, Nottingham, and Derby. Loughborough is also very close to the East Midlands Airport. Loughborough is also home to the world's largest bell foundry, John Taylor Bellfounders, which produced Great Paul at St Pauls Cathedral.  The local authority is Charnwood Borough Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint of the property is 2,563 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.604 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate) Current rateable value (from 1 April 2023) of the Plough Inn has been assessed at £5,000. The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

displayAddress: 21 High Street, Doncaster, South Yorkshire, DN1 1DW
propertySubType: Land / Development, Takeaway, Retail, Alternate Use, Public House, Leisure, Bar, Cafe
detailedDescription: Fifteens is a three storey mid terraced property of rendered stone with painted stone dressings and pitched roof hidden behind parapet. Initially built as public meeting rooms the building is believed to date back to 1841, with 20th Century alterations at ground floor level. The Grade II Listed property has three semi-circular headed first floor windows in pilastered surrounds and comprises an elongated open plan trading area over the ground floor and two largely unused floors above. The trading area briefly consists of an entrance hall providing access to the Bar with a long timber bar servery, part wooden and tiled flooring, a mixture of upholstered perimeter and freestanding seating and DJ booth and secondary bar servery (no longer in use).  The bar also benefits from Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s, and a large ground floor beer cellar. Stairs from the bar lead to the extensive first floor with a number of rooms currently used for storage and office.  The equally spacious second floor has not been used in many used and in a state of dereliction. To the exterior, Fifteens benefits from a small rear yard with covered smoking area. To the front, the bar has the benefit of a pavement licence providing approximately 16 covers.  Fifteens is situated in High Street, right in the centre of the south Yorkshire city of Doncaster. Named after the River Don, it is the administrative centre of the City of Doncaster Metropolitan Borough and is the second largest settlement in South Yorkshire after Sheffield.  Doncaster received city status  as part of the Platinum Jubilee Civic Honours in 2022. The built up area had a population of 87,455 at the 2021 census, whilst the wider metropolitan borough had a population of 308,100.Fifteens is situated in the centre of the city's bustling bar and nightlife scene. The Silver Street, Cleveland Street and High Street areas have over 40 bars and clubs within a 2–3-minute walk of each other and other bars can be found on Priory Walk, Lazarus Court, Bradford Row and around the Market Place.    We are advised the property is Grade II Listed (Ref No. 1286659).  Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries with Doncaster Metropolitan Borough Council. We are advised that the trade Fixtures & Fittings will be included in the sale. The overall site size is c. 0.125 acres and the property has a ground floor footprint of 4,599 sq ft, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Rateable Value has been assessed at £37,250 (2023).

propertySubType: Bar, Restaurant, Other, Public House
detailedDescription: For further enquiries please contact Tom Nichols on tom@everardcole.co.uk / 07715 054959. Please Note:   Postcode is an indication only and not the postcode of the property.

displayAddress: 18 High Street, Kings Langley, Hertfordshire, WD4 8BH
propertySubType: Cafe, Takeaway, Other, Bar, Restaurant, Leisure
detailedDescription: Cinnamon Lounge is an attractive Grade II Listed brick built 2 storey property under pitched tiled roof. The character property benefits from many original features, exposed timbers and fireplaces. The ground floor is accessed via a central lobby entrance in a reception area for takeaway collection and ordering.   To the left hand side is a ground floor dining area with additional covers accessed via a central staircase to the 1st floor dining room, with bar servery. In total the property can comfortably accommodate over 60 covers. To the rear of the ground floor are customer WC's. Beyond this is an extensive commercial trade kitchen, equipped and fully fitted with commercial extraction. Plus storage areas. Externally there is access to the extensive rear garden. There is no living accommodation on site. Cinnamon Lounge is located in the thriving High Street of Kings Langley surrounded by a variety of shops, delis, bakeries, restaurants and cafes. Kings Langley is a large village located in South West Hertfordshire with a population of 5,215 (Census 2011).  The village lies south of the Chiltern Hills, 23.5 miles (37.8 km) north-west of London.  Hemel Hempstead is situated 2 miles to the north and Watford is approx. 2 miles to the South, with excellent transport links via M25 (Jct 20) and A41 approximately 1 mile due south. We are advised that the building is Grade II Listed (List entry 1100448).  The local authority is Dacorum Borough Council. Planning was granted in February 2019 for a single storey rear extension to extend the restaurant (60 covers).  Planning application can be viewed here: 4/02743/18/LBC | Single storey rear extension to existing restaurant to a grade ii listed building (amended scheme) | 18 High Street Kings Langley WD4 8BH All fixtures and fittings will be included in the sale. The total site area is 0.069 acres.  The total building footprint is 1,271 ft² (118 m²) *All measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping. *Please note there is a flying freehold element with part of the neighbouring hair saloon extending to the rear* ALL SERIOUS OFFERS CONSIDERED DUE TO HEALTH REASONS Unconditional freehold offers invited in excess  of £400,000, exc VAT, if applicable. Rateable value as of 1st April 2023 £10,749.

propertySubType: Public House, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The accommodation provided has a main entrance which provides access to the trading area which has a bar servery to one side. The property was comprehensively refurbished and extended in 2018 to a high standard and provides open plan trading areas for approximately 140 covers on the ground floor. To the rear of the ground floor is a large catering kitchen. A bottle store, glass wash area and disabled WC are also provided at this level. Cellar is provided at basement level. At first floor the property provides ladies and gents WC’s in addition to a manager’s office, staff changing room and storage facilities. Externally the property provides a parking area to the front, with ample free 'off street' parking surrounding the site. Plus a front patio area, side service entrance, rear service yard and access via external staircase to the 1st floor from the rear. The property is located in the affluent market town of Beaconsfield, approximately 25 miles north-west of London and 5 miles south-east of High Wycombe. Road and rail communications are good with the M40 and M25 motorways both being easily accessible and Beaconsfield railway station providing regular services to London Marylebone with journey times from 23 minutes. The subject property is located within the Old Town of Beaconsfield which is full of historic character buildings occupied by other high quality pub operators, restaurant groups and boutique retailers. Occupiers nearby include Browns, Giggling Squid, Brasserie Blanc, Farrow & Ball and Fired Earth. We understand that the property is not a listed building but it does fall within the Beaconsfield Old Town Conservation Area. All further enquiries relating to planning should be directed to  Buckinghamshire Council . All trade inventory, other than kitchen extraction, walk in fridge/freezer and bar servery, has now been removed. (*some photos are shown prior to removal) The property has the following approximate gross internal floor areas.                         Ground Floor  Trading & Ancillary- 4,680 sq ft / 434.9 sq.m First Floor Ancillary - 921 sq ft / 85.6 sq.m Basement Ancillary - 365 sq ft/  34.0 sq.m TOTAL -  5,966 sq ft / 554.5 sq.m * Please note that these approximate areas include extensions made by the occupational tenant. The approximate areas have also been calculated from floor plans so should be verified by the purchaser/tenant prior to exchange of contracts. (Title Number BM182373, with BM275028 excluded) A new lease is available, subject to vacant possession. Alternatively freehold offers may be considered. Rateable Value, from 1st April 2026, £122,000.

displayAddress: 5 George Street, Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, NR30 1HR
propertySubType: Cafe, Leisure, Restaurant, Bar, Public House
detailedDescription: Ground Floor - open plan bar and seating area for c50 customers. Trade fitted kitchen with dry storage area. Ladies & Gents WC facilities. Basement Cellar. No on-site private accommodation. Ideally located in the centre of the thriving seaside tourist town of Great Yarmouth on the Norfolk coast. A population of 38,693 in the 2011 Census made it Norfolk’s third most populous place. Yarmouth has been a resort since 1760 and a gateway from the Norfolk Broads to the North Sea. Throughout the 20th century, Yarmouth boomed as a resort, with a promenade, pubs, trams, fish-and-chip shops and theatres. There is also the Pleasure Beach, the Sea Life Centre, the Hippodrome Circus and the Time and Tide Museum, and a Victorian seaside Winter Garden in cast iron and glass. Close to the railway station and regular bus routes offering links to Norwich and surrounding areas. The location also benefits from ongoing regeneration around the town centre and harbour, making it an appealing choice for those seeking a central setting with coastal character and practical day to day convenience. The property is not listed but is situated within a conservation area.  Main bar area needs complete refurbishment. The trade kitchen still retains a number of working items to include cooker, fridges and extraction unit.  Total Floor Area - 1,238 sq ft *measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping systems. The property is offered as commercial premises only and is available with a minimum lease term of three years. Free of Tie lease at an annual rent of £12,000 pax. Three months rent is required upfront (£3,000) as a deposit, along with a £10,000 agent & legal fee payable by the tenant on application to cover the production of the lease. Ingoing costs of c£30,000 will need to be available to cover legal fees, working capital, agency fee and deposit.  Rateable Value of £5,500 as of 1st April 2026 * Please check with the local council to see if you may be eligible for the Supporting Small Business scheme

propertySubType: Retail, Hotel, Investment, Public House, Alternate Use, Leisure, Bar, Restaurant, Guest House, Land / Development, Other
detailedDescription: A three-storey, part detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The early 19th-century pub has two trading rooms divided by a central bar. The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall, leading to the Lounge bar area with timber bar servery, feature fireplace with stone surround, raised area, free-standing seating for approximately 20. The Public Bar has a bar servery, exposed stone walls, feature fireplace, pool table and darts throw. A rear inner hallway provides access to Ladies (incorporating Disabled) & Gents W.C.s and access to the rear yard. The property has a good sized basement beer cellar. The extensive domestic accommodation located over the first and second floors briefly comprises: 1st Floor –domestic kitchen, lounge, three bedrooms and a shower room/W.C. A further room is located off the Kitchen, although it is not inhabited. 2nd Floor – two additional bedrooms and a large bathroom with shower. To the exterior, the pub has a rear yard which has covered seating for c. 20 and exterior heating. A two-storey brick-built property in the rear yard called “The Stables Bar” is now used for storage.  The Cross Keys is positioned in the historic 200-year-old Market Place, in the Derbyshire town of Belper. A market is still held on the second Saturday of every month excluding January. Belper is the only market town located at the heart of the Derwent Valley Mills World Heritage Site. A popular market town, Belper was acclaimed the Winner of the 2019 Great British High Street Awards. The area expanded during the early Industrial Revolution with Belper becoming one of the first mill towns with the establishment of several textile mills and now forms part of the Derwent Valley Mills World Heritage Site. The town is within the Amber Valley district and is located approximately 7 miles north of Derby, 7 miles north east of Ripley and approximately 12 miles south of Matlock. The town is easily accessible, being close to the A38, which in turn provides prompt access to the M1. The local authority is Amber Valley Borough Council. We are advised that the property is not Listed but is situated in the Belper and Milford Conservation Area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint is 2,262 ft2 and the total site area is approximately 0.054 acres, (measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Rateable Value (RV) of the Cross Keys has been assessed at £9,000. The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

propertySubType: Investment, Bar, Cafe, Land / Development, Guest House, Takeaway, Other, Alternate Use, Restaurant, Retail, Public House, Leisure
detailedDescription: A mid terrace property of stone construction extending to 2 storeys under a pitched tile roof. As you walk into The Black Swan, the division into two trading areas provides different atmospheres for people to enjoy. To the left of the main front door is a lounge bar and dining area for approximately 20 covers, perfect for those seeking a relaxed and cosy environment. To the right, there is a bar room adorned with comfortable seating, an open fire, and a TV, offering a more lively and casual setting for circa 30 customers. The easy access to the catering kitchen and prep area ensures efficient service. Additionally, the outdoor seating area is a great addition for customers to enjoy during nice weather to the rear of the pub. Ladies and Gentleman's toilet. The Black Swan is situated just south of the North York Moors National Park on the A170, midway between Helmsley and Pickering. The town of Kirkbymoorside, in which The Black Swan is located, enjoys a beautiful setting close to the stunning scenery of the moorlands. The Black Swan sits at the edge of the main through road among the local amenities. Kirkbymoorside is a charming market town and civil parish in North Yorkshire, England. Located approximately 25 miles north of York, it is conveniently positioned between Pickering and Helmsley. Nestled on the edge of the North York Moors National Park, this picturesque town boasts a rich history and had a population of 3,040 as of the 2011 census. We are advised that the property is Grade II listed, further enquiries should be made to Historic England. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as beer raising equipment. Total site area is 0.080 Acres with a building footprint of 2,601 Sq Ft. (Measurements Taken From a Digital Mapping System) The April 2023 rateable value has been assessed at £6,000. Small business rates relief may apply and suggest interested parties make their own enquires to Ryedale Council.

propertySubType: Public House, Cafe, Bar, Other, Takeaway, Restaurant
detailedDescription: Split main bar area with fireplace, leading to lounge. Both areas can seat up to 30 covers. Private dining area to the rear with WC's which can cater up to 15 people, which is ideal for special occasions. Function room to rear with servery. Can seat up to 40 covers. Ladies and gents facilities. Basement cellar. Trade kitchen with prep area and walk in fridge. First floor private accommodation consists of 2 rooms with en suits and 3 rooms without, bathroom and kitchen (unfurnished). 2nd floor consists of 2 attic rooms and a WC. External areas consist of a courtyard garden space, with covered patio area and brick built barn, currently used for storage. Car park to rear for c18 cars. The White Horse is located on the A32 through Droxford. The village of Droxford, lies within the South Downs National Park. Bishops Waltham lies under 5 miles to the west, offering extensive facilities. The cathedral city of Winchester and the ancient market town of Petersfield, only 12 miles to the west and 13 miles to the east respectively, provide further shopping, recreational and cultural facilities. National rail service to London Waterloo. The Property is Grade II listed and is situated within the Droxford Conservation Area. The property is registered as an Asset of Community Value (ACV) until 8/11/27 No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. Approximate Total Site Area - 0.2 acres (taken from digital mapping). Total Floor Area - 4,166 sq ft Freehold available with vacant possession. Seeking unconditional offers (save for Vacant Possession) in the region of £450,000 plus VAT. Current rateable value £7,500

displayAddress: 1 St Thomas Road, Derby, Derbyshire, DE23 8RF
propertySubType: Investment, Public House, Land / Development, Restaurant, Alternate Use, Bar
detailedDescription: The Vulcan Arms is a two storey corner property of brick elevations (part rendered), beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The Vulcan benefits from two trading areas over the ground floor, which briefly comprises a front entrance hall leading to the Lounge Bar, with a timber bar servery, perimeter seating and raised stage area. The public bar is accessed from a side door and benefits from bar servery, space for pool table, perimeter seating and darts throw. The inner hallway provides access to the Ladies and Gents W.C.s and rear access door. A  now disused function room is also situated over the first floor.  The Vulcan Arms also benefits from a small kitchenette located between the two bars, store room, boiler room and basement beer cellar. The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and briefly comprises three good sized bedrooms, domestic kitchen-diner with utility space off, lounge and bathroom with separate W.C.  To the exterior the pub has a paved rear patio with picnic bench seating for 12; a rear good sized car park and a private yard and store. The Vulcan Arms is situated within a dense residential area of Derby City. The property is located on a good sized corner plot, within the Normanton area of Derby, on a busy road approximately 1 mile due south of the city centre. The Vulcan is close to numerous local shops with excellent bus routes. Derby is a cathedral city and unitary authority area on the River Derwent. As a unitary authority, Derby is administratively independent from Derbyshire County Council and as of 2024 had a population of 274,149. The city lies approximately 10 miles to the west of the M1 motorway, the A50 and A38 roads skirt its borders to the south and west. Derby is also known as a centre for advanced transport manufacturing, being home to Rolls Royce, Bombardier Transportation and Toyota. The Vulcan Arms is neither Listed nor situated in a Conservation Area. The local authority is Derby City Council and prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items. Ground Floor Footprint - c. 2,820 ft² Total site area – c 0.282 acres (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Rateable Value of The Vulcan Arms has been assessed at £3,000 (2023).The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

displayAddress: Town House Road, Costessey, Norwich, NR8 5BS
propertySubType: Restaurant, Cafe, Alternate Use, Public House, Bar, Leisure, Other
detailedDescription: The Harte is a substantial two storey brick built property under tiled roof with flat roof rear extension. The ground floor is accessed by a central lobby entrance into a traditional bar area with dedicated bar servery, with space for 25 covers, comfortably. To the left-hand side is a further trade area with dual aspect windows, laid out for dining with an additional 30 covers. To the rear is a further trade area, used more as a lounge bar, with an additional 25 covers, plus a large commercial kitchen, wash up area, further storage area and customer WC’s. The first floor provides residential accommodation, comprising two double bedrooms, lounge and bathroom. A substantial cellar is located at ground floor level, along with further storage areas, with delivery access to the front. Externally, there is a substantial outbuilding to the rear, previously used as a function room and takeaway, which has multiple uses +/or development potential (stpp). A rear tarmac car park provides space for 25 cars along with a front parking area, currently used for external seating, plus rear grass trade garden. Costessey sits about 4 miles northwest of Norwich, within the Norwich Urban Area.  Although Costessey officially gained town status in a council decision, many residents cherish its enduring Village-like ambiance. Old Costessey, with its historic cottages and pastoral settings, and peaceful countryside living, lies within a loop of the River Wensum. The area is well-served by primary and secondary schools, medical facilities, shops, veterinary services, and pubs. The Harte occupies a large corner plot in a prominent position at the heart of the village. The property is administered by South Norfolk Council   The Harte is not listed nor is it in a Conservation Area. Planning has already been approved to demolish the substantial rear outbuilding (17/04/2025) (Link) The property is well equipped as a turnkey business with comprehensive trade inventory, included in the sale. The area of the public house site is approximately 0.509 acres. The ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house extends to 581 m² (6,251 ft²), including the rear outbuilding.   Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Freehold offers are sought in Excess of £425,000, subject to vacant possession, inclusive of trade inventory and goodwill. The transaction should qualify as a Transfer of a Going Concern (TOGC), so no VAT should be payable on the sale. Rateable Value as of 1st April 2023 is £11,250 (PH), with rear Shop & Premises (outbuilding) separately assessed at £11,500.

displayAddress: Hogpits Bottom, Flaunden, Hemel Hempstead, HP3 0PP
propertySubType: Public House, Other, Leisure, Restaurant
detailedDescription: Located in beautiful Flaunden, The Bricklayers Arms is a charming detached Grade II Listed, 18th Century Country Inn and Restaurant, with an ivy clad exterior and internal wooden beams and open fireplaces. Over the years it has won critical acclaim from the Michelin Guide, the AA Pub Guide and the Good Pub Guide. The ground floor is accessed via a central entrance to a traditional bar area, with feature bar servery. Flexible and versatile dining areas extend to either side, with a mix of loose and fixed seating with over 80 internal covers in total A substantial rear commercial trade kitchen, wash up, walk in fridge/freezer and dry store is located to the rear, extended over the years, with views over rolling countryside. Customer WC's and basement cellar support these areas. The 1st floor provides residential accommodation comprising 3 bedrooms, office, bathroom and staff room. Externally there is a a large grassed trade garden, and patio with space for c 90 covers, popular with many visiting walkers and cyclists. The Hertfordshire village of Flaunden is set on the southern border of the county, close to the border with Buckinghamshire and on the edge of the Chiltern Hills, 460 feet above sea level and 5 miles east of Chesham. It sits high on a gentle slope looking down towards the valley of the River Chess, it is surrounded by walking trails over the rolling hills of the Chess Valley. The Bricklayers Arms is located within a stone’s throw of the Warner Bros Studios and the Grove Hotel’s Country Estate and within easy reach of many major routes to London and the Home Counties. We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed.  Listing Entry No. 1348451 and lies within a Conservation area. Further enquiries can be made to Dacorum Borough Council The business will be sold as a going concern and therefore comprehensive fixtures and fittings, including tills, flow monitoring equipment (where owned), social media accounts, websites, intellectual property, brand and trading names will be included in the Purchase Price. Stock at Valuation. The area of the site is 0.47 acres with a total floor area of 2,705 ft² (251 square metres) * Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Freehold offers are sought in the region of £600,000 (excluding VAT) to include all fixtures and fittings, goodwill and IP.  Stock at valuation. Rateable Value, as of 1st April 2023, £60,000.

displayAddress: 22 Silver Street, Whitwick, Coalville, Leicestershire, LE67 5ET
propertySubType: Takeaway, Alternate Use, Land / Development, Public House, Cafe, Leisure, Retail, Bar
detailedDescription: The Kings Arms is a two storey detached property of partially rendered brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The internal accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall leading the trading areas. The Bar is split into two areas divided by a central timber bar servery, with fixed perimeter seating, feature fireplace and part tiled and carpeted floor. A separate Games room is located off the rear bar with darts throw and space for pool table. The entrance hallway provides access to the refurbished Ladies and Gents W.C.s . The pub also benefits a basement beer cellar and store rooms to the rear of the property. The domestic accommodation is located over the 1st floor and briefly comprises an open-plan domestic kitchen-diner-lounge, three bedrooms and bathroom. To the exterior the pub sits in 0.247 acres  with a car park to the rear with a tarmac surface providing approximately 20 spaces, a hard standing area used for outdoor drinking with picnic bench seating for c. 24 and brick-built outbuildings.  The Kings Arms is situated on Silver Street in the village of Whitwick. Whitwick is a large, historic, village in northwest Leicestershire, just to the north of Coalville. The population of Whitwick, according to the 2021 census was 8,229. Coalville is a market town in North West Leicestershire, with a population at the 2011 census of 34,575. It lies on the A511 trunk road between Leicester and Burton-upon-Trent, close to junction 22 of the M1 motorway where the A511 meets the A50 between Ashby-de-la-Zouch and Leicester.  The local authority is North West Leicestershire District Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The overall site size is c. 0.247 acres and the property has a ground floor footprint of 2,671 sq ft, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). propertySubType: Retail, Bar, Public House
detailedDescription: The Redemption Alehouse is a two storey end of terrace building of brick and rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. Operating since 2016, the business is a well established and popular micropub operating over two floors. The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance from Ray Street leading into a well laid-out ground floor trading area. The room provides a relaxing environment for approximately 50 covers, with tiled floor, part wood panelled walls and wood burning stove. The timber bar servery has eight regularly changing handpumps, with glazed doors providing visibility of the temperature controlled cool room / cellar to the rear. A dry and bottle store is situated at the back of the cold room. A basement cellar is accessed via trapdoor under the ground floor seating area. The cellar is currently used for storage. A set of stairs to the first floor provide access a further trade area with an additional 22 covers, timber flooring and feature fireplace. The Ladies and Gents W.C.s are also located on the first floor, along with a small kitchenette and a store room/office.  To the exterior, the business benefits from an attractive walled courtyard drinking area with 12 covers, the archway area provides for a covered smoking area with wall mounted heaters and a further 20 covers. An additional area able to seat around 20 is situated within a brick built building to rear of the courtyard. The Redemption Ale House is situated on Ray Street, near to its junction with Market Street (A608) in the centre of the market town of Heanor.  Heanor is located within the Amber Valley district of Derbyshire and lies approximately 8 miles (13 km) north-east of Derby and 9.5 miles (15.3 km) west-north-west of Nottingham. Heanor enjoys good communication links, being just under 2 miles from the A610 link road and its connection with the M1 motorway at junction 26. The town benefits from easy access to Derby, Nottingham and Ripley, with the Derbyshire Dales and Peak District just beyond. There are good rail links to the rest of the country via Langley Mill rail station, approximately 1 mile east, which has regular services to Nottingham, Sheffield and beyond. Regular bus routes also link Heanor with Nottingham, Derby, Mansfield and other towns and cities in the area. The Heanor and Loscoe Parish had a population of 17,352 as at the 2021 census  We understand the property is not Listed or situated within a conservation area. Interested parties should make their own enquiries via Amber Valley Borough Council. Ground Floor Footprint - c. 1,718 ft² Total site area – c 0.047 acres (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Redemption Ale House is available on a new private Free of Tie lease. The lease is a term of 3 years on a Fully Repairing and Insuring basis, with an annual rent of £10,500 per annum.  The Rateable Value of The Redemption Ale House has been assessed at £10,000 (2023).The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

displayAddress: 1 Bamford Street, New Whittington, Chesterfield, Derbyshire, S43 2BA

detailedDescription: The Miners Arms is a two and single storey semi-detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The internal accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall leading the open-plan trading areas with bay windows onto the High Street. The pub benefits from a refurbished timber bar servery, part tiled flooring, feature fireplace and a combination of fixed perimeter seating and freestanding tables and chairs. The Games area is located to the rear with darts throw, pool table and additional perimeter seating, and a door to the rear garden. The Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s are located off the bar areas.  The pub also benefits a commercial kitchen and basement beer cellar.   The domestic accommodation is located over the 1st floor and briefly comprises a domestic kitchen, lounge, bathroom, store room and five bedrooms (one currently used as office and two further currently used for storage). To the exterior, the pub sits in 0.106 acres with a lawned area to the rear, a covered patio with picnic bench seating for c. 30 with wall mounted TV and brick built storage shed.  The Miners has recently been granted Planning permission CHE/24/00690/FUL| for Conversion of a Public House to form a 10 room, 10 person HMOF. Further details can be provided to any interested parties. The Miners Arms is prominently located on the corner of the High Street and Bamford Road in the north Derbyshire village of New Whittington. The village is located in the Borough of Chesterfield in Derbyshire near to Whittington Moor and Old Whittington. The pub is located approximately 3.5 miles north of Chesterfield, 2.5 miles west of Staveley and 8 miles south of Sheffield. The property enjoys good communication links being just 5 miles west of the M1 motorway. In 2011 the Barrow Hill and New Whittington ward had a population of 5,903. The local authority is Chesterfield Borough Council. We understand the Property is neither Listed nor situated within a conservation area. displayAddress: Market Lane, Dunston, Whickham, Gateshead, NE16 4TJ
propertySubType: Other, Alternate Use, Leisure, Public House, Land / Development, Retail, Takeaway, Hotel, Bar, Cafe, Guest House, Investment, Restaurant
detailedDescription: This impressive pub is attractive from the outside – in, set on a huge plot of land, there is parking for easily 100 vehicles, which would complement the overly generous beer garden and outside seating areas on sunny days, including an enclosed children’s play area. On entering the pub you are welcomed in to a fantastic area, with exposed beams, high ceilings and exposed brick throughout. The bar area is centrally located in the heart of the pub which services all areas with a carvery unit to the rear left hand side. Directly in front of you there is mixed and loose seating for those having a drink or a casual bite to eat. To the right of this, separated by a double sided open fire, you will find a raised games area housing televisions for sporting events, a pool table and darts board along with a mixture of high and low seating and tables. To the left of the pub there is a raised dining area which is fitted with loose seating, in ease of accommodating any number of covers. Before reaching the rear trading area there is a kids play zone, to keep them entertained during family meals. The rear trading area can be used for either additional covers for when the pub is busy, however could also be used for private parties and functions as it is separate to the rest of the pub. The private accommodation is located on the first floor and is a very generous size. Three bedrooms, lounge, kitchen bathroom and separate toilet. The Poachers Pocket is spectacularly situated in Wickham just off the A1 , just 4 miles outside of Newcastle City Centre. The pub benefits from the extremely popular Metro Centre being just on the opposite side of the A1. Wickham is a semi-rural, middle class suburban town and former civil parish. Built on a large hill, it overlooks a large part of the northern and western horizon, including a mixture of large suburban housing estates and private streets for the local residents. We are advised that the property is not listed or in a flood zone but does sit in Greenbelt. The Fixtures & Fittings that remain on the premises at the time of completion will be included in the sale. Any third party owned items, such as beer raising and cellar cooling equipment, branded items, gaming machines etc, will be excluded. An inventory will not be provided. The vendors will not be required to remove any such items that remain on the premises. Total site area is 1.434 acres with a building footprint of 4,116 Sq Ft. (Measurements have been provided by a digital mapping tool) The property is in an area administered by Gateshead Council. The 2017 Rateable Value has been assessed at £19,500. We advise any interested parties to make their own enquiries.

displayAddress: Ironstone Road, Rawnsley, Cannock, Staffordshire, WS12 0QD
propertySubType: Leisure, Restaurant, Bar, Hotel, Investment, Alternate Use, Land / Development, Public House
detailedDescription: The Rag at Rawnsley is a two and single storey detached property of brick and rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled flat roofs. The property has been extended and refurbished throughout to a very high standard by our clients providing a traditional but modern English pub-restaurant full of character.  The ground floor accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall leading to a reception area. The Rag has a number of trading areas comprising an L-shaped Public Bar, with timber bar servery, brick-built feature fireplace with log burning stove, beamed ceiling, upholstered perimeter seating and wall mounted TV. A waiting area with bar servery and upholstered perimeter seating provides access to the restaurant area of the property. The Rag Restaurant  has approximately 80 covers, with exposed brick feature fireplace, part wood panelled walls and views of the surrounding countryside. A separate room, which can also be used for private parties, gatherings and meetings, provides an additional 24 covers. The property also benefits from Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s an impressive commercial catering kitchen with walk-in fridge/freezer and a basement beer cellar. Seven wonderfully appointed, en-suite letting rooms are situated over the 1st floor with 6x Double Rooms and 1x Twin Room, along with a laundry room. The Domestic accommodation is also located on the 1st floor and briefly comprises 2x Bedrooms, Lounge, Office, refitted Kitchen and Bathroom. Externally, the pub sits in over1.7 acres in total and the extensive outdoor areas include a terrace to the front and side with picnic bench seating for approx 24; a large car park providing parking for c. 50 vehicles, beer garden with picnic bench seating, timber BBQ hut, with pizza oven, storage shed and further outdoor store that was previously utilised as a microbrewery. The Rag also boasts a crown bowling green (first laid in 2006), with bowling team shed; and 6x caravan pitches with full electrical hook-ups, 2x outside W.C.s and guest showers.  The Rag at Rawnsley nestles on the edge of Cannock Chase in Staffordshire, providing an excellent base for walkers, mountain bikers and visitors to this area of outstanding natural beauty. Rawnsley is an area of Cannock Chase District of Staffordshire. The village is located between Hazleslade and Prospect Village. Rawnsley is a former mining hamlet and was served by the mineral line from Hednesford to Burntwood which carried minerals to the mines around the area. The Rag is easily accessible, is close to all major road networks, the Northern Relief Road is just five minutes away, with easy access to the NEC and Birmingham Airport. The pub is just a 10 minute drive from the Cathedral City of Lichfield, twenty minutes away from Drayton Manor Park & Zoo, and 45 minutes from the Alton Towers amusement park. The Property is not Listed but is situated within a designated Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries with Cannock Chase Council. All trade Fixtures & Fittings (excluding any 3rd party owned items) are included within the sale.  The Rateable Value has been assessed at £41,500 (2023).

displayAddress: Church Street, Blackmore, Ingatestone, Essex, CM4 0RN
propertySubType: Public House, Leisure, Alternate Use, Bar, Other, Restaurant, Land / Development
detailedDescription: The character 2 storey timber framed building under pitched tiled roof, benefits from exposed timbers and fireplaces with many of its architectural features with the property being subject to partial refurbishment over recent years. The property is currently closed and provides an opportunity for a new operator to refurbish the flexible ground floor, which remains largely open plan with exposed timbers and open fireplaces and newly renovated concrete floors throughout. Additional renovation works have been the upgrading and rewiring of electrics, and the central heating system.. To the rear and front are WC's with space for an extensive commercial trade kitchen - this benefits from existing extraction, along with several storage areas, ground floor cellar and prep rooms. The 1st floor has again been partially refurbished and provides a self contained flat, or letting rooms, comprising of 4 ensuite double bedrooms, with storage and bathroom facilities. Externally the property provides a dedicated rear tarmac car park, with access to Blacksmiths Alley, and an extensive grassed trade garden. There are several outbuildings and barns capable of being converted to other uses, subject to the necessary consents. Blackmore is an affluent rural village mid way between Brentwood to the South West and Chelmsford to the North East (approx. 10 miles). It has good road links providing easy access to London and the M25 via both the A414 and A12, both a short, accessible drive from the village. The bustling village provides a primary school and preschool, both rated 'Good' by Ofsted, as well as several local shops and recreational facilities. The Bull is located in the centre of the village and is one of the oldest and most famous pubs in Essex with alleged royal patrons including Henry VIII. We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed (List entry number: 1280959). The property is also registered as an Asset of Community Value but is not subject to any moratorium periods which have elapsed. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries to Brentwood Borough Council on 01277 312500. The property is sold as seen and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser, excluding any third party or personal items. The area of the site, as measured from digital mapping, is approximately 0.38 acres in total, with the ground floor footprint (GEA), including outbuildings being approximately 4,200 sq ft (390 sq m). Offers are invited for the unencumbered freehold interest, sold as seen on a purely unconditional basis. Rateable Value: £17,250 (1st April 2023 to present). Council Tax Band A.

propertySubType: Restaurant, Bar, Guest House, Leisure, Public House, Cafe
detailedDescription: The Angel is a characterful, well presented, Grade II Listed mid terraced property, arranged over two floors under a pitched tiled roof. The primary trade areas are characterised with exposed beams, open fireplaces, wooden and tiled flooring.  The entrance to the pub is on the High Street, via a central lobby which leads to a ground floor trade area with bar area (20 covers) to the right hand side, with wooden bar servery.  To the left hand side is a dedicated dining area providing flexible open plan trade space (c.40 covers). To the rear of the building is a substantial commercial trade kitchen, wash up and storage area, alongside WC's and ground floor cellar.   There is a staircase adjacent to the front door which leads to the 1st floor where there are 2 double bedrooms, 1 single bedroom, bathroom and an excellent open plan kitchen/diner/living room with views of the High Street. There is scope to convert the upper parts into hotel accommodation, subject to the necessary consents.  Externally there is parking area, currently laid to shingle.  Access to this area is via the archway, or internally from the main dining area.  A right of way exists for the adjoining property. Debenham is a thriving historic village and considered to be one of mid Suffolk's most desirable settlements. The Angel is situated in the heart of this bustling village towards the north end of the High Street (B1077).  There are a variety of shops and businesses including a Co-op, butcher's, florist, hardware shop, bakery, a number of cafes, a library and a vets.  The property is administered by Mid Suffolk District Council . The property is Grade II Listed.  The Angel is registered as an Asset of Community Value (ACV) (Expires 15th February 2026). Interested parties are advised to make their own enquiries. The Angel has been closed for over 2 years. The property is ready for fitting out. The area of the site is 0.103 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house extends to 155m² (21,672 ft² ). Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Unconditional freehold offers invited   in excess of £200,000, plus VAT, which will be payable. **A recently commissioned building survey can be made available to genuinely interested parties.** Rateable Value:  £5,750 (1st April 2023) Council Tax:  Band 'A' (£1,477.12) 25/26

propertySubType: Leisure, Other, Restaurant, Bar
detailedDescription: Trinity benefits from a very attractive frontage, situated in a prime city centre location, adjoining The Ivy, on the cobbled streets of central Cambridge. Trinity has recently closed but is presented in excellent condition trading over ground floor and basement.  The turnkey restaurant trades over 2 levels with open plan ground floor trade area (40 covers) with a mix of loose tables and leather banquette seating with under seat storage. All trade areas benefit from feature wood cladding and wooden floorboards. To the rear is a bar servery and coffee station leading to the substantial commercial trade kitchen. The kitchen is fully equipped with 6 ring gas burner, rational, fridges, freezers and variety of commercial appliances, stainless steel racking and counters. To the rear is service entrance for deliveries, additional secure storage, plus bin store. The basement benefits from natural light and provides additional trade areas with mix of loose and banquette seating for a further c. 40 covers.  To the rear are 2 customer WC's, staff changing area, fire escape and further storage areas. Cambridge is a historic university city located on the river Cam. It has excellent network connections and a population of approximately 150,000. Trinity is nestled right in the heart of Cambridge, along Trinity Street and adjoining The Ivy, close to Trinity College and just a short walk from Kings College Chapel and Kings Parade. It is conveniently placed for visits to the various theatres and concert halls in central Cambridge Cambridge’s population is the fastest growing of any city in the country and is the 3rd least deprived city in the country in relative terms. Cambridge residents have the 5th highest disposable incomes nationwide, with Employment rates in Cambridge  close to record highs, with 8 in 10 residents in work. Of those out of work, the majority are full-time students, (Cambridge City Portrait: State of the City 2023). The local authority is Cambridge City Council. Grade II Listed Trinity is fully fitted with well equipped commercial trade kitchen, inclusive of appliances, extensive storage areas and trade inventory, including mix of loose and leather banquette seating for c 80 covers. Assignment of a 15 year lease from 2021, subject to 5 yearly rent reviews. Free of Tie, internal repairing lease, subject to service charge, from Trinity College. Current passing rent is £70,000 pax. Current rateable value is £62,500 (1at April 2023)

displayAddress: 30 Main Street, Stapenhill, Burton Upon Trent, DE15 9AP
propertySubType: Restaurant, Leisure, Cafe, Takeaway, Land / Development, Investment, Alternate Use, Bar, Public House, Retail, Hotel, Industrial
detailedDescription: Believed to have been built in 1858 and originally a Salt’s pub until that brewery was taken over by Bass in 1927, the Barley Mow reputedly housed a Burton Corporation hose-reel station during Edwardian times.  The property is a two and three storey Victorian detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall  providing access to both bar areas. The small public bar has a timber bar servery, feature fireplace and upholstered perimeter seating. The larger lounge bar has a timber bar servery, beamed ceiling, upholstered perimeter seating, timber floor and part wood panelled walls. The pub also has a  function room and separate dining room situated to the rear of the property. The pub also benefits from Ladies and Gents W.C.s, kitchen and basement beer cellar and stores.  The domestic accommodation is situated over the upper floors and briefly comprises : First Floor: lounge, bedroom, office, bathroom with separate W.C. and loft rooms accessed from a mezzanine landing. Second Floor : Two further bedrooms, bathroom and a domestic kitchen-diner. To the exterior, the pub has a lawned beer garden to the side, a large tarmac car park and brick-built storage outbuildings.  The crown bowling green to the side is part of the Barley Mow's demise,  but let to Stapenhill Bowls Club and is subject to a 20 year lease dated 31st March 2006.  The Barley Mow is prominently located on the busy Main Road in the Stapenhill area of Burton upon Trent. Originally a small village owned by Nigel of Stafford as far back as 1086, this ancient parish area has long since been surrounded by new housing developments and gradually absorbed into the Burton urban area. Stapenhill, known for its brickyards in the 18th and 19th centuries, is situated on the East bank of the River Trent.  Burton, is a market town in the borough of East Staffordshire, close to the border with Derbyshire. At the 2021 census it had a population of 76,270.  Burton is located on the  River Trent 11 miles (18 km) south-west of Derby and 20 miles (32 km) south of the Peak District National Park. The local authority is East Staffordshire Borough Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. The pub does not feature on the Authority's current List of Assets of Community Value. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint of the property is 4,628 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.603 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The crown bowling green to the side lies within the Barley Mow's demise,  but let to Stapenhill Bowls Club on a 20 year lease, dated 31st March 2006. The agreement provides the lessee a right of access over the pub's car park and the use of 7 car parking spaces.  Current rateable value (from 1 April 2023) of the Barley Mow has been assessed at £8,800.

displayAddress: 1 North Street, West Butterwick, Scunthorpe, DN17 3JR
