detailedDescription: The Three Horseshoes is a two storey detached property of part stone, part rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs, with a single storey flat roof extension to the side. The ground floor accommodation briefly comprises an entrance porch leading to bar area, with wooden bar servery, upholstered perimeter and loose seating for approx 40, games area with darts throw and space for pool table, two brick built feature fireplaces and ladies and gents W.C.s. There is a room to the rear of the bar, with double glazed doors onto the rear yard, that could be utilised into a small dining room. There Three Horseshoes also benefits from a modestly sized catering kitchen and ground floor beer cellar. The domestic accommodation is located on the first floor and briefly comprises a lounge, domestic kitchen, bathroom and 3 bedrooms. To the exterior the pub has a tarmac car park to either side of the property, with space for approximately 14 cars, a private paved rear yard with access to two brick built storage sheds. The Three Horseshoes is a two storey brick built property situated on North Street in the rural north Lincolnshire village of West Butterwick. West Butterwick is a village and civil parish in North Lincolnshire, lying in the Isle of Axholme, approximately 4 miles (6 km) north-east from Epworth and 4 miles north from Owston Ferry. The village lies on the western bank of the River Trent, opposite its neighbour East Butterwick. According to the 2021 Census West Butterwick has a population of 786 and 884 people live within a 1km radius of the Three Horseshoes. The local authority is North Lincolnshire Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint of the property is 2,028 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.155 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate).  The Rateable Value of the Three Horseshoes has been assessed at £4,750 (2023). The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

displayAddress: Beech House Road, Hemingfield, Barnsley, South Yorkshire, S73 0PF
propertySubType: Restaurant, Bar, Public House
detailedDescription: The Tavern is a two and three storey detached property of rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. Charming features such as stone walls and beamed ceilings create a traditional feel, and this is complemented by quality carpets and good wooden furniture which adds a modern touch. Two large trading areas have room for live music performers, and are serviced by a single bar servery, hosting cask ale pumps as well as international brands. On the first floor a large function room has its own bar servery and can accommodate 40 covers, perfect for private events. With beamed ceilings, tasteful furnishings, and great views, it is worthy of wedding celebrations and these have been a popular stream of income in previous years. Between exclusive hire functions, the room could also double up as a separate dining room, and the large catering kitchen downstairs is equipped to service all trading spaces. The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and comprises two bedrooms, a lounge, kitchen, bathroom and an office.  The beer garden to the side and rear of the pub enjoys lovely views of rolling fields and  a large car park, accommodating over 40 vehicles, is located across the road.  The Tavern (previously known as the Lundhill Tavern) is situated on Beech House Road on the outskirts of Hemingfield.  This destination food pub is located between Wombwell, Hemingfield and West Melton. It has a rural setting albeit within easy driving distance from the surrounding neighbourhoods. We are seeking a new retailer with experience operating food businesses who can drive sales, whilst developing a strong wet trade. The building was originally part of the Lundhill Colliery and still retains memorabilia of the pit. The pub is located in a rural setting between Wombwell and Hemingfield and is within easy driving distance of the surrounding neighbourhoods. It is in close proximity to the A6195 Dearne Valley Parkway to the South East of Barnsley. The local authority is Barnsley Metropolitan South Derbyshire District Council. We are advised that the property is not Listed but is situated within an area designated Green Belt and Flood Zone 2. Prospective tenants are advised to make their own enquiries.  Fixtures and fittings are to be purchased separately at valuation.  The ground floor footprint of the property is 2,864 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.722 acres. (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Tavern is available via the Stonegate Fixed Term Tenancy (FFT) agreement, Key Features include:  A fixed term of 5 years without any landlord break option;  Greater flexibility with the tie – with tie release options across wines, FABs, spirits and minerals in return for a tie fee release; Landlord responsible for all structural repairs, (subject to a repair fund paid by the tenant).  The guide rent is £18,000 pa.  Deposit - The equivalent of three months’ rent is required as a deposit.  From April 1 2026, the Rateable Value of the Tavern has been assessed at £9,600. The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

propertySubType: Alternate Use, Takeaway, Restaurant, Bar, Cafe, Public House
detailedDescription: The Eight Bells is a terraced 2 storey building, with brick elevations under a pitched tiled roof. It is a popular local and has a darts team. The first Eight Bells pub was built on this site as an inn with livery stables, only to be demolished in 1898. This is where the current building stands and it retains many of the handsome timber frames and original embossed windows. The entrance from London road provides access immediately into main bar area. There is a horseshoe shaped servery, and it is traditionally decorated throughout with a fire place. The area can seat approximately 30 customers. The property also includes a trade kitchen and a basement cellar. Private accommodation is located over the top 2 floors. 1st floor consists of a lounge with partition to a main double bedroom, and bathroom. 2nd floor consists of 2 double bedrooms and one single. The external areas consist of an enclosed patio garden to the rear of the pub with seating for approximately 20 customers. There are external WCs   The Eight Bells is a mid terraced property, situated among plenty of chimney pots. It is conveniently located close to Canterbury West train station and is just a few hundred meters from the beautiful Canterbury Cathedral. Steeped in history and surrounded by breathtaking architecture, Canterbury is home to a diverse, creative population with plenty of attractions, events and activities for all to enjoy. Canterbury is perfect for a city break while the wider district includes incredible seaside towns and countryside, as little as 15 mins drive away. The famous seaside resorts of Whitstable and Herne Bay are a must for anyone looking for a coastal break, or escape to the countryside to taste the Garden of England. You can shop at a huge mix of independent and high street retailers, and dine at award-winning restaurants, breweries and cafes.  Just under 1 hour’s train journey from London, and moments away from the stunning Kentish countryside and coast.  The property is not listed but is situated within a Conservation Area. Property type - A3/A4/A5 (now class 'E' Sui generis) Restaurant and Cafes/Drinking Establishments and Hot Food takeaways Those looking to purchase for alternative use are asked to make their own enquiries regarding possible planning via  Canterbury City Council No inventory will be supplied or warranted. The purchase price excludes fixtures & fittings, although the purchaser will inherit any remaining items owned by the vendor at the property on the day of completion. Site Area - 0.043 acres Total Floor Area - 1,819 sq ft *All measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping. Freehold with benefit of vacant possession looking for offers in the region of £250,000 (plus VAT). The property is being 'sold as seen' and all parties are asked to carry out their own due diligence before submitting an offer. Our clients will not consider any offers that are subject to any planning, house or business sales.  Rateable Value - £5,000 as of 1st April 2023

displayAddress: Yorkley Slade, Yorkley Slade, Gloucestershire, GL15 4RX
propertySubType: Public House, Restaurant, Takeaway, Guest House, Hotel, Retail, Other, Leisure, Cafe, Bar
detailedDescription: The Nags Head is a pleasant white-washed rendered building that dates from 1788. It is a single storey building with roof loft. The pub is open plan in layout but solidly traditional, with an L-Shape main bar area (c 30), 2 reception/lounge areas (c 30) and a Ladies and Gents WC. There is also an upstairs area previously used as a skittle alley/bar/function room. There is a trade kitchen with prep area, ancillary storage space and a ground floor cellar. The 1st floor also includes private accommodation, consisting of 3 bedrooms, lounge and bathroom. The access is internal only.  All the areas are tired and in need of refurbishment and restoration. There is an extensive grassed field area to the rear and a beer garden close to the pub (c 100). To the front of the Nags Head is a pleasant enclosed grassed area laid out with bench tables (c 30). There are extensive views to be enjoyed from an adjoining paddock, with a panoramic vista down towards the River Severn and onto the Vale of Berkeley and the hills beyond. The Nags Head is situated in the beautiful rural West Gloucestershire village of Yorkley Slade. Nearby towns and villages can be accessed via the A48 leading into Chepstow, Newport and gives direct access to the M4 towards Bristol and the M5 towards Gloucester, Cheltenham and the Midlands. The pub itself is situated on an elevated position providing breathtaking views of the River Severn and across the Vale of Berkeley. The property is not listed and is not situated withing a Conservation Area. The property is not registered as an ACV. However recent planning for conversion to 3 residential dwellings has been denied by the local authority. Forest of Dean District Council . You can view details under the planning portal - P0862/24/FUL The entire site of 2.911 (area marked in blue on below plans) acres is available for offers in the region of £450,000 (plus VAT). The town contains especially fine ensembles of Regency architecture, particularly in parts of the Parade, Clarendon Square and Lansdowne Circus. Although originally founded around its spa industry, Leamington today has developed into a centre for retail, and digital industries, which has gained it the moniker "silicon spa". In 2023 The Sunday Times named Leamington as the best place to live in the Midlands. In addition, there is private accommodation comprising 2 double bedrooms, lounge, showroom, separate WC and bathroom. Externally there are 2 parking areas, either side of the property with space for deliveries, staff and customer parking for c 30 cars. The Bull is in a prominent corner position in the large village of Pinchbeck, population 6,011 (2021 census). The property is located at the junction of Knight Street & Church Street, 2 miles north of the market town of Spalding, population 35,011 ( 2021 Census).  The bustling village has a newly refurbished Spar as well as various other independent retail shops. External Areas consist of a decorative terrace garden to the front with various 'sea' themed regalia. The area is enclosed by picket fencing and seating for c30 customers. Patrons' car park to the side for approximately 10 cars. Several storage shed units. Enclosed trade garden to the rear with access from the main dining area, with flagstone flooring & raised decking area, quality garden furniture providing seating and tables for c100 customers. This area is an excellent sun trap during the Summer months. Covered trading area with bar servery, pizza oven and BBQ. The village of Trimley St Mary is situated in East Suffolk approximately 1 mile from Junction 59 off the busy A14 and approximately 2.5 miles west of the popular seaside town of Felixstowe. Along with the neighbouring village of Trimley St Martin they have a combined residential population of around 5,000 residents which is currently growing with many new housing developments presently under construction. propertySubType: Public House, Alternate Use, Cafe, Restaurant, Bar, Hotel
detailedDescription: The Angel is predominantly located within Lavenham's main market square. Originally a 15th Century timber-framed and plastered building with cross wings at the north-west and south-east ends, the north-west cross wing now forms part of the property Nos 16 and 17. Tiled roof. Two storeys. A wing extends to the north-east with part of the upper storey jettied at the north-east end. The interior has features including a 16th Century plaster ceiling on the upper storey and earlier wall paintings. The interior has been stripped and requires refitting. Trading areas consist of an open plan main trade area, with a central ‘horseshoe’ servery, large inglenook (wood burner) fireplace. The area could accommodate up to approximately 60 seated customers when fitted out. There is immediate access to the trade kitchen, with prep area leading to the back yard area and garden. Reception room just off main bar, with small office space. Side door access to ladies and gents WC and staircase leading to 1st floor letting rooms. No.7 letting room is located on the ground floor immediately next door to the property, with access from Prentice Street consisting of 1 double bedroom and en-suite bathroom. 1st Floor consists of 8 en-suite letting rooms, with a separate breakfast/function room. Fire escape leading down to main yard. External area consists of a large garden space laid to grass, with several store sheds, as well as an outside wooden bar. The area could comfortably sit approximately 60 customers. There is also a further outbuilding in the main yard that has previously been utilised as a 2nd kitchen area, with full extraction still in situ. The Angel is conveniently situated in the main market square of Lavenham Lavenham is an affluent village located in the heart of the county of Suffolk. Voted ‘Best Village in Suffolk’ by ‘Which’ in 2023 and came 6th in the UK. Picture tiny streets lined with timber-framed buildings, an expansive market square surrounded by iconic Medieval and Tudor halls and a thriving community with independent shops, cafés and restaurants with plenty to see and do. propertySubType: Takeaway, Leisure, Other, Bar, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Curry King occupies a modern two-storey, brick-built building just off the busy thoroughfare of Bridge Street in central Cambridge. The restaurant is located at ground floor and first floor level and is open-plan, with a serving counter to the rear and tables providing in the region of 70+ covers. A dedicated bar servery operates to the rear of the main restaurant on the ground floor and to the rear of the trade area is a well-appointed commercial trade kitchen with commercial extraction. Storage is provided to the front with under stairs cupboards. The 1st floor provides additional dining area for c 40 covers, with vaulted ceiling and dual aspect windows.  Internal staircase provides good fire escape access for staff and customers. A further bar servery and dumb waiter is provided with direct access to the ground floor trade kitchen.  WC's are located to the rear. External storage units are located off Blackmoor Head Yard. WC for customers is provided at 1st floor level along with staff WC.   The Curry King is situated just off Bridge Street, a busy thoroughfare in the heart of Cambridge. It is within easy walking distance of historic colleges, retail centre, vibrant pubs and restaurants. Jordan's yard provides direct access to the newly expanded Park Street Car Park and newly developed Staycity Aparthotel. The redevelopment project includes 229 bedrooms, a public courtyard, and a triple-basement car park with a capacity of 225 spaces, 26 of which will incorporate EV charge points.  The Local Planning Authority is Cambridge City Council.  Cambridge City Council Total building footprint 196 ft². Total site area is .004 acres.  *All measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping systems Rental offers invited in the excess of £55,000 pax.  A new 12-15 year FRI lease, outside the L&T Act, subject to 3 yearly rent reviews with cap & collar index linked reviews (2 & 4%). 6 months’ rent deposit will be required, if under a limited company, or less with a personal guarantee, with rent payable monthly in advance. A non-assignment period for 3-5 years and explicit assignment provisions. The current rateable value is £15,750 (1st April 2023 to present).

propertySubType: Public House, Restaurant, Other, Guest House, Bar, Leisure, Hotel
detailedDescription: Purchased by our client in 2018, The Heron underwent a complete restoration and refurbishment, making it fit for the modern era. Great attention has gone into the detailing, from the Heron wallpaper to the usage of natural materials to include flagstone flooring, an oak bar, and wooden beams in the light and airy new restaurant space. The trade areas consist of a main bar (26), with snug area (12). Main restaurant and function room with bar servery (65) with side conservatory and access to garden and decking area. Ladies and Gents facilities. Extensive trade kitchen with separate prep area and wash up space. Fully equipped ground floor cellar.  First floor consists of 2 double en-suite letting rooms. Also self contained 2 double bedroom private accommodation with kitchen, bathroom and access to roof garden. External areas comprise of paved refuse and storage area, with purpose built dry store. The current owners have extended the external seating areas to now include a decked area overlooking the Great River Ouse with a well maintained grassed area (80). Pontoon (area owned by Environmental Agency) with 12 mooring points. There is an extensive field (c0.8 acres) adjacent to the property currently used by those visiting in caravans with 6 hook up points. This area could be considered for further letting accommodation subject to suitable planning. Large car park for c30 cars.  Stowbridge lies between The Great River Ouse on one side, and the man-made Relief Channel on the other, The Heron is nestled between the two rivers; giving a peaceful and tranquil location. The Pontoon allows plenty of people to moor up and stop for a pint! The pub is also only a short distance from Woodlakes Park, and approximately 4 miles from the market town of Downham Market. Both the North Norfolk Coastline and Thetford Forest Park are around half an hours drive away. The A10 lies just 2 miles away with links to King's Lynn, Ely and Cambridge. We are advised that the property is not listed, nor does it sit within a conservation area. The property is administered by Kings Lynn & West Norfolk District Council The pontoon is situated on land owned by the local Environment Agency, Kingfisher House, Goldhay Way, Orton Goldhay, Peterborough PE2 5ZR There is an overage clause in place for the field adjacent to the pub for a 20 year period from 2018 entitling the previous owner to 25% on any uplift for any domestic dwellings built on the site. Total building footprint is 3,902ft² (363m²). The total site area is 1.174 Acres (measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). Freehold offers are sought in the region of £575,000 (ex VAT), inclusive of comprehensive trade inventory, IP & goodwill. The property is open and trading and sale will be a transfer of a going concern (TOGC), TUPE will apply to all contracted staff.   Rateable Value as of 1st April 2023 £25,000.

propertySubType: Alternate Use, Public House, Bar, Land / Development
detailedDescription: The Village Gate is a two storey brick built public house with single storey extensions to the side and rear. It was formerly the Marquis of Granby and can purportedly be traced back to the 16th century.  Sadly, much of the fabric of the building was badly damaged in a major fire in August 2019. Our accompanying photos evidence the extent. We are advised that the vendor has made the building safe, but they will not undertake any further restorative work to the property and it will be sold as seen. Please note that for safety reasons only a very limited part of the building is available for internal viewing.  The Village Gate is located very prominently on the B4009 0.5 miles north of Wendover, Buckinghamshire. Aylesbury is 3.8 miles to the north. The pub lies equidistant between the M40 (14.5 miles to the west) and the M1 (14.5 miles to the east). A large Dobbies garden centre is located just to the north of the Village Gate, which also houses a green grocers, Costa Coffee and other retail outlets. The property is not Listed nor is situated in a Conservation Area. It is not nominated or registered as an Asset of Community Value. We are advised that the property neither falls within Green Belt nor the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty which surrounds most of Wendover.  The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third-party items such as any remaining beer raising equipment.  The pub sits on a large plot of 0.6 acres (approximately) over-looking the Buckinghamshire countryside.  Rateable Value (subject to re-assessment): £52,300.   The government is introducing a business rates holiday for retail, hospitality and leisure businesses in England for the 2020 to 2021 tax year (18 March 2020).

displayAddress: 43-45 Doncaster Road, Goldthorpe, South Yorkshire, S63 9HJ
propertySubType: Cafe, Land / Development, Public House, Takeaway, Alternate Use, Retail, Restaurant, Leisure, Bar
detailedDescription: The Rusty Dudley is a two storey end of terrace property of stone and rendered elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The entrance from Doncaster Road provides access to the trading areas which briefly comprise two separate bar areas, serviced by timber bar serveries on either side. upholstered perimeter seating and wooden flooring. The Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s are located to the rear of the main bar. A basement beer cellar and bottle store is accessed from behind the bar and a hallway to the rear of the second bar provides access to a kitchen area (not currently of commercial specification), store room and rear access door. The domestic accommodation is situated over the 1st floor and briefly comprises a double bedroom, two further bedrooms interconnected via an archway, lounge, domestic kitchen and private bathroom/W.C.  Externally, the pub has a small, covered small rear yard. The ground floor footprint of the building measures 2,137 sq ft and the overall plot is 0.067 acres. The Rusty Dudley is located in the centre of the main shopping area of Goldthorpe village. Goldthorpe is a village in the Metropolitan Borough of Barnsley in South Yorkshire. The area is now commonly referred to as the Dearne Valley and was a major coal mining area. The community sits in a triangle bounded by Doncaster, Barnsley and Rotherham. The pub is located approximately 4 miles west of the A1, 7 miles west of Doncaster and 8 miles east of Barnsley. Historically part of the West Riding of Yorkshire, the village is in the Dearne North Ward of Barnsley MBC and had a population of 6,051 at the 2011 Census. The local authority is Barnsley Metropolitan Borough Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint measures 2,137 sq ft and the overall plot is 0.067 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The current Rateable Value has been assessed at £8,250 (2023). The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

displayAddress: 275 Sheffield Road, Glossop, High Peak, SK13 8QY
propertySubType: Retail, Leisure, Land / Development, Guest House, Cafe, Bar, Alternate Use, Other, Takeaway, Investment, Public House, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Royal Oak is a three and single storey detached property of stone elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The building is believed to have been built in 1818 as a public house to cater for the trade going over the Snake Pass Turnpike road. The ground floor accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall leading to the trading areas. The main bar to the rear has a large timber bar servery, tiled flooring and various loose tables and chairs. The front bar has fixed perimeter seating and a feature fireplace; pool room with fixed perimeter seating and tiled floor. The rear dining room has a feature fireplace and part timber panelled walls.  The property also benefits from Ladies and Gents W.C.s, commercial kitchen, fridge/freezer store and dry store room; and ground floor beer cellar. The spacious upper floors briefly comprise 5 rooms, office, domestic kitchen, with door to rear roof terrace, and bathroom over the first floor. The loft is accessed via folding steps on the first floor landing and the 3 loft rooms offer potential to convert into additional accommodation.  To the exterior, the Royal Oak benefits from a timber decking area to the front, providing an outdoor drinking terrace; an enclosed drinking patio to the side, and a tarmac car parking with approximately 10 spaces.  The Royal Oak is a large pub, located on the very western side of Glossop on Sheffield Road, the main A road which goes over the Snake Pass towards Yorkshire. The site is located in a sustainable location close to the edge of the built up area boundary as well as the Peak Park boundary. The centre of Glossop (taken as junction of Sheffield Road and Norfolk Street) is 1450m away. Glossop is a market town in the borough of High Peak, Derbyshire. Glossop lies approximately 15 miles (24 km) east of Manchester, 24 miles (39 km) north-west of Sheffield and 32 miles (51 km) north of Matlock. Near Derbyshire's borders with Cheshire, Greater Manchester, South Yorkshire and West Yorkshire, between 150 and 300 metres (492 and 984 ft) above sea level, it is bounded by the Peak District National Park to the south, east and north. In 2021, it had a population of 17,825. The local authority is High Peak Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. An inventory will not be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint of the property is 3,765 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.362 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Property is held on 2x Long Leasehold / Virtual Freehold titles (DY250639 & DY268662). The Leases are for a term of 999 years from 25/03/1919, with approximately 892 years unexpired. Current rateable value (from 1 April 2023) of The Royal Oak has been assessed at £8,000.

displayAddress: Main Street, Thorpe Langton, Leicestershire, LE16 7TS
propertySubType: Public House, Leisure, Bar, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Bakers Arms is a two-storey detached property of painted brick elevations beneath a thatched roof, believed to date back to 1851. The property has a substantial single storey extension beneath a flat roof to the rear. The ground floor accommodation comprises an entrance hall leading to the trading area, which is full of traditional character and includes a timber bar servery, brick feature fireplaces, beamed ceiling and brick tiled floors. The trading areas have space for approximately 50 covers in total. The Ladies and Gents W.C.s are accessed off the main bar-restaurant area via an inner hallway. A commercial kitchen is located to the rear of the bar, with a preparation room and fridge/freezer store, and an area used as ground floor beer cellar. The first floor accommodation comprises an office/bedroom, bathroom and two connected rooms which have been largely knocked through. The upper floor rooms are currently used for storage, office and staff changing. To the exterior, the rear beer garden can be accessed from the dining-bar area. The beer garden is an attractive, well-maintained space with lawn and mature shrub borders and seating for approximately 20. A path leads from the beer garden to the rear car park, which accommodates around eight vehicles. The Bakers Arms is situated to the centre of the south Leicestershire village of Thorpe Langton. Thorpe Langton (derived from the Anglo-Saxon word for an enclosure, meaning "long town"), is a village and civil parish in the Harborough district of Leicestershire, a few miles north of Market Harborough. The parish had a population of 171 according to the 2001 census. Ten years later, in the 2011 census, the population had grown to 200, and risen again to 231 at the 2021 census. Thorpe Langton is the home of the Baker's Arms pub and St. Leonard's church, but is otherwise solely residential. The property is administrated by Harborough District Council. We understand the property is neither Listed nor situated within a Conservation Area. The Fixtures and Fittings may be available via separate negotiation.  The total site area is approximately 0.18 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) extends to 2,858 ft2. Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Rental offers are invited for a new Free of Tie commercial lease. The new lease will be either 10 or 20 years, on a Fully Repairing and Insuring basis, with 5 year rent reviews to OMV and annual RPI uplifts capped at 5% and collared at 2.5%. The Lease may be assigned after the end of the first two years. The equivalent of six months’ rent is required as a deposit. A contribution to Landlord's legal fees of £1,500 will be payable. The current Ratable Value of the property is £20,000.

displayAddress: Cornish Hall End, Finchingfield, Essex, CM7 4HF
propertySubType: Cafe, Bar, Restaurant, Public House
detailedDescription: Main Entrance from car park leads into a beautifully presented bar area with exposed wooden beams. Long bar servery. Large wall mounted TV. Plenty of table seating boasting a comfortable lounge area. Main bar can seat around 30 customers. Ladies and Gents WC. Restaurant area is adjacent to main bar with wood burner and access to patio garden. Can seat approximately 60 customers. All areas are tastefully decorated oozing rustic charm. Benefits from a main trade kitchen, which is fully equipped with prep area and dry storage. Ground floor cellar.  Private accommodation on the 1st Floor - consisting of 3 bedrooms, lounge, bathroom. There is a disused room and conservatory (currently used as an office and storage) on the ground floor which can easily be used as part of the private accommodation, as this also has access to a private garden. External Areas - Gravel car park at the front for approx 25 cars. Covered patio seating to the front of the pub for c30 customers. Enclosed beer garden laid to grass with picnic style bench seating for approx 60 customers. Ideal for outdoor events. Private garden laid to grass at the rear of the property. There is a large field to the back of the property, which is owned by the Parish Council, and we are led to believe that a handful of pub events could be held here, with permission.  The Horse and Groom is located in Cornish Hall End an Essex village on the B1057 just outside of the beautiful village of Finchingfield and 4 miles (6 km) south of Steeple Bumpstead in the Braintree district of Essex. Despite its peaceful rural setting, the property is well positioned for commuters, with Stansted Airport approximately 14 miles away, Saffron Walden 11 miles, and Haverhill just 7 miles, providing convenient access to surrounding towns and transport links. Finchingfield is a picturesque village that feels like stepping into a timeless English postcard. With charming thatched cottages, peaceful green spaces, and the iconic duck pond, it’s a serene escape from the bustle of modern life. Whether you’re sitting with a picnic on the green, enjoying a meal at a traditional pub, or exploring the surrounding countryside with your dog, Finchingfield offers a unique blend of rural beauty and warm community spirit. Perfect for a quiet getaway, or more permanently, this idyllic village is where history, nature, and tranquillity come together.  All of this coupled with the local primary school, modern doctor’s surgery, Post Office, Recreation grounds, with a newly refurbished tennis court, and petrol station. The property is not listed and is not situated in a conservation area.  Permitted use as a Public House within use class Sui Generis (old A4). Extensive working trade inventory is included in the premium price of £30,000. An inventory can be provided.  Site Area - 0.6 acres Total Floor Area - 3,778 sq ft *all measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping systems Held on an existing 20 year lease, expiring 1st July 2038. Free of all ties. Private Landlord. Current rent of £53,000 pax. Full repairing and insuring lease. Rateable Value of £8,750 as of 1st April 2026.

propertySubType: Land / Development, Investment, Alternate Use
detailedDescription: This parcel of land is situated directly off Houghton Road (A1123). The open parcel of land provides dropped kerb to the highway and space for around 30 car parking spaces. The land benefits from a central tarmac covering and is measured as 48m long and 13 m wide.  The land has existing boundaries with walled bricked wall, fencing to the side and concrete bollards to the front. The plot size is estimated at 0.146 acres. (All measurements are taken from digital mapping and are provided as an estimate and guide only) St Ives (population circa 15,000) is a market town on the bank of The River Ouse, approximately 15 miles North West of Cambridge and easily accessed from the A14. The parcel of land is situated to the west of the Shell Garage and to the rear of the Seven Wives Public House, with direct access obtained off Houghton Road. Adjoining owners include various other commercial uses, car showrooms, MOT and Bodyshop Units, offices, churches and residential properties.   We are advised that the site is not situated within a Conservation Area. Freehold offers invited, subject to vacant possession only. Currently not applicable. Interested parties should make their own enquiries with the relevant local authority.

propertySubType: Investment, Retail, Leisure, Cafe, Land / Development, Bar, Restaurant, Alternate Use, Public House
detailedDescription: The Wellington is a two-storey brick-built detached property of painted elevations beneath a pitched tiled roof, with single storey brick-built flat roof extensions to the rear. The property briefly comprises front entrance porch providing access to the open plan single Bar, with wood panelled bar servery, upholstered perimeter seating, fireplace with wood-burner and seating for approximately 60. The Ladies & Gents W.C.s are accessed from the trading area. The property also has a semi-commercial catering kitchen situated to the rear of the servery, a basement beer cellar and an exterior store room. The domestic accommodation is located on the first floor and briefly comprises a large lounge, domestic kitchen, an office leading through to 2x double bedrooms, 2x further bedrooms and bathroom. To the exterior, the pub sits in a quarter of an acre plot encompassing an outside seating area to the front with picnic bench seating for 48, a 5-space customer car park area to the rear, a rear beer garden with picnic bench seating for c.20, and a private rear yard with off road parking and garage. The Wellington is prominently situated on Nottingham Road in the centre of the Nottinghamshire town of Eastwood. Eastwood is a former coal mining town and civil parish in the Broxtowe district of Nottinghamshire, located approximately 8 miles (13 km) northwest of Nottingham and 10 miles (16 km) northeast of Derby on the border between Nottinghamshire and Derbyshire. Mentioned in Domesday Book, it expanded rapidly during the Industrial Revolution. The town is known for being the birthplace of the Midland Railway and novelist of D. H. Lawrence. The population within a 1 km radius of the pub is 12,140. The local authority is Broxtowe Borough Council. We understand the Property is not Listed and located outside of the Eastwood Conservation Area. The Wellington does appear on the Local Authority’s AVC Register. It was entered onto the list on 6th January 2023. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser, excluding any third party items. Ground Floor GEA - c. 2,784 ft² Total site area – c 0.258 acres Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Offers are invited for the Freehold Interest. Leasehold Option is also available.  Rateable Value – Public House: £20,000 (2023).

displayAddress: Old School Lane, Upware, Ely, CB7 5ZR
propertySubType: Guest House, Restaurant, Land / Development, Hotel, Public House, Bar, Cafe
detailedDescription: Main front entrance leads to main bar with large servery. Leading round to the Sports Bar (with separate servery) and Restaurant to the other side, To the rear is an extensive conservatory area with views across the garden and the River Cam. All areas can seat approximately 250 customers. Stairs by the entrance to 1st floor provides access to a function room with prep kitchen. The room can seat approx 60 covers or 150 standing. Extensive and fully equipped trade kitchen with separate prep area and several storage areas for chest freezers, walk in fridge and dry store. External areas consist of split car park for approx 50 cars. Spacious garden laid to grass, with outside bar and covered seating building. Currently able to seat 150 customers on picnic style bench seating. There are several guest moorings available on the River Cam for paying customers. Our clients also own land further to the South, which has 4/5 permanent mooring at an income of approx £4,000 per annum. They also own the strip of vacant land on the other side of the river, directly opposite the pub. This land is included in the sale price. Five Miles From Anywhere No Hurry Inn is located in the Hamlet of Upware, just outside the ancient City of Ely – a 15 minute drive along the A10, with Cambridge 35 minutes away. The coffee machine is on a lease agreement. displayAddress: Ancient Shepherds, 5 High Street, Fen Ditton, Cambridgeshire, CB5 8ST
propertySubType: Guest House, Leisure, Public House, Bar, Cafe, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Ancient Shepherds is a charming detached Grade II listed building, predominantly arranged over two stories and has recently been refurbished, with the benefit of 5 newly built ensuite letting rooms. The ground floor has a number of interconnecting trade areas, with period features, open fireplaces, exposed beams and stripped wooden floorboards. There are 3 principle trade areas providing a lounge bar and 2 dining areas, currently sparsely laid out for fine dining, with potential for 70/80 covers in total.  Access is via the front to the main bar, or to the rear, via an entrance porch from the car park, providing access to male, accessible and female toilets. An open theatre kitchen with canopy extraction is provided, with wash up, office and a various ground floor storage areas. The basement cellar is accessed from behind the bar. On the first floor, the private accommodation comprises a well-presented and light two bedroom apartment, with living/dining room, kitchen, office and three-piece shower room. Externally 5 ensuite letting rooms have been newly built to a high specification, providing 2 large twins and 3 double bedrooms. Externally, there is a rear grassed trade garden which is predominantly laid to lawn and patio area with space for 30+ covers, as well as further seating. The dedicated car park provides off-road parking for c. 15 vehicles, with additional unrestricted parking on High Street. The Ancient Shepherds lies at the centre of the village of Fen Ditton on the edge of Cambridge. The property sits on High Street, just off the B1047 (Horningsea Road), north east of central Cambridge, on the banks of the River Cam, with easy access to A14 (jct 34). The Ancient Shepherds lies within a short cycle ride to the new communities at Marleigh & Springstead Village  in this fast developing area of north east Cambridge adjoining Marshalls and Cambridge Airfield. We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed and situated within a Conservation Area. There is a TPO on the walnut tree in the trade garden. The property is listed as an Asset of Community Value. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries to South Cambs District Council The area of the site, as measured from digital mapping, is approximately 0.28 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) extends to 232m² (2,497ft²). propertySubType: Alternate Use, Other, Restaurant, Public House, Bar, Leisure, Guest House
detailedDescription: The Berkshire is a substantial two storey detached building with single story rear extensions. The front bar is accessed from Abingdon Road and provides a mix of loose and fixed seating for 30 covers along with customer WC’s. The middle trading area provides a feature bar servery, wooden flooring and flexible open plan trading space with a further 30 covers, with access from Vicarage Road. To the rear is a further trade area, again with fixed and loose seating, for a further 30 covers, with access to the rear patio garden via french doors. To the rear a single storey extension houses a commercial trade kitchen, with commercial extraction, and access to the side alleyway for deliveries, storage and bin areas. A ground floor cellar is situated behind the bar servery. The first floor provides 6 bedrooms.  Rooms 1 & 2 provide ensuite double bedrooms with shower rooms. Room 3, 4, 5 & 6 provide 4 further double bedrooms with shared bathrooms, WC’s, domestic kitchen, plus additional kitchenette. Externally provides a block paved patio area, secure and secluded, with space for 60+ covers. Oxford is a internationally renowned city in central  England, famed for its prestigious University containing 38 Colleges. Oxford has a population of 160,021 (2021 Census).   The Berkshire sits in a prominent roadside position at the corner of Abingdon and Vicarage Road, a short distance from Oxford city centre. The property is predominately residential in nature,  popular with many students residing in Oxford, and approximately 7 million visiting tourists annually ( Oxford CC ). The property is not Listed. displayAddress: Bury Road, Market Weston, Suffolk, IP22 2PD
propertySubType: Other, Cafe, Restaurant, Takeaway, Guest House, Alternate Use, Retail, Bar, Public House
detailedDescription: Striking white brick and flint faced inn standing at a crossroads on the main B1111. Front and side car park entrance leading to traditionally decorated main bar with wooden top servery, carpeted throughout. Supplemented by a separate dining area. All areas can seat 50 covers comfortably. The areas benefit from a wood burner and open fireplace. Ladies and Gents WC's. Access to rear beer garden. Fully equipped trade kitchen with extraction and separate wash up/prep area. Basement cellar (bar servery hatch) with necessary beer raising and cooling equipment. Internal access to private accommodation on the 1st floor consisting of three bedrooms, lounge, bathroom and kitchen.  External areas - Large car park for c25 cars, facilitated by 2 separate entrances. Enclosed beer garden laid to grass with patio area (50). External utility/store room. Large brick built outbuilding, currently split into 3 sections, one acting as a garage and the rest for general storage. This could considered for letting accommodation. The Mill Inn is located in the sought after West Suffolk village of Market Weston on the borders of Suffolk/Norfolk. Nearby villages include Hopton and Barningham. The popular market town of Bury St Edmunds is found 12 miles to the west, whilst Thetford lies respectively 9 miles north west and Diss is to the east .The village has good vehicular access to the main A143 (Suffolk Coast) and A1066 (Diss) via the B1111. The Mill Inn is the only pub in Market Weston, with the closest pub being the Royal George at Barningham approximately 1 mile away. The property is not listed but is situated within a Conservation Area. Those looking at development options or change of use will need to make their own enquiries with West Suffolk Council - https://www.westsuffolk.gov.uk/.  There is an overage clause for a period of 25 years years at 25% of any uplift achieved on the land or existing building for residential use. Subject to contract. All trade fixtures and fittings are included in the sale price. An inventory can be provided. displayAddress: 10 Middle Street, Nether Heyford, Northampton, NN7 3LL
propertySubType: Leisure, Other, Bar, Public House, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Olde Sun is a very attractive detached stone built Grade II Listed building.   The ground floor provides a number of interconnecting, characterful trade areas with tiled, wooden flooring and exposed timbers. To the front is a traditional communal bar area with central bar and space for 40+ covers with access directly off the front car park. To the rear is a secondary trade area with space for 30+ covers, with a further bar servery leading to the back areas, which has a raised dining area and direct access to the commercial trade kitchen with flagstone flooring and space for 30 covers. Supporting these areas is a commercial trade kitchen ground floor cellar and storage, plus customer WC's. The first floor provides substantial domestic accommodation, including a double ensuite bedroom, storage room, lounge, double bedroom, three-piece bathroom and sizeable kitchen/diner. Second floor provides a large open plan self-contained studio flat with bathroom and kitchen. Externally the property provides a dedicated car park (20 spaces) as well as a service yard and large grass trade garden with space for 80+ covers The Olde Sun is situated in the heart of Nether Heyford, a semi rural village in West Northamptonshire within close proximity to the M1, A5 and A45. The pub occupies a prominent trading position and is located approximately 6 miles west of Northampton, 19 miles northwest of Milton Keynes and 34 miles south of Leicester. The thriving village has a sizeable resident population of approximately 1,700, and is popular with walkers throughout the year. It has one of the largest village greens in the country. The local planning authority is West Northamptonshire Council . The Olde Sun lies within the Nether Heyford Conservation Area. It is not listed as an ACV (Asset of Community Value). Approximate total site area - 0.447 acres (taken from digital mapping). Total Floor Area - 3,194 ft ( 297m sq). Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate.   The property is available by way of a new, 20-year 'free of tie' lease, seeking rental offers in excess of £37,500 per annum, exclusive of VAT. There is no premium payable for the benefit of the new lease. The new lease will be on a Full Repairing and Insuring basis with Annual RPI increases (min 2.5% / max 5%) and 5th year open market rent reviews. Ingoing rental incentives may be offered, subject to the tenant’s assessed covenant strength and overall business plan. These may include rent free and stepped rent. Applicants must have sufficient capital available to cover 3 months' rent, along with building insurance, standard £1,750 legal fees contribution and working capital. Proof of funding and a business plan will be required, along with a deposit equivalent to 6 months rent + VAT. Rateable Value - £13,500 ( April 2023 to present).

propertySubType: Leisure, Public House, Alternate Use, Restaurant, Bar, Retail, Investment, Land / Development
detailedDescription: Reputed to be the oldest pub in Loughborough, the Windmill is thought to be of 16th Century origin, although the facade is mostly 19th Century. The Windmill is a two storey timber-framed painted rendered property, with the gable end rebuilt in brick. Internally, the accommodation briefly comprises an entrance leading from Sparrow Hill, to an L-shaped main bar area, with bar servery, open feature fireplace, upholstered perimeter seating, beamed walls and ceilings. A raised middle section has a small timber bar servery, feature fireplace and access to an internal hallway and snug bar with feature fireplace and small hatch servery.  The pub also benefits from a basement beer cellar and store and commercial kitchen. Over the first floor the Windmill has four bedrooms, lounge, bathroom with separate W.C. and a domestic kitchen.  Externally, a brick built flat roof outbuilding houses the Ladies & Gents W.C.s, and a storage room.  A brick paved patio to the rear of the pub has picnic bench seating for approximately 20 and an enclosed car park, laid to tarmac, wraps around the rear of the pub. The Windmill is located on the edge of Loughborough town centre next to the picturesque All Saints Church , the 14th Century Anglican church that attracts tourists to the area. Loughborough is a popular market town in the Charnwood Borough of Leicestershire.  The town, which is located between Nottingham and Leicester, is the second largest  built-up area in the county and is home to the well-established Loughborough University . The population of Loughborough is circa 60,000 plus a significant university population in the town during term time. Loughborough University is a world renowned centre for sports-related subjects  and consistently ranks in the top 10 in the Complete University Guide. The town is close to the Nottinghamshire border and short distances from  Leicester, Nottingham, Derby, the M1 motorway and East Midlands Airport. We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed (List Entry Number : 1361170) and is situated within the Loughborough Church Gate conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The overall site size is c. 0.122 acres and the property has a ground floor footprint of 2,208 sq ft, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). Rateable Value of the New Inn has been assessed at £11,500. The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

propertySubType: Public House, Retail, Other, Leisure, Takeaway, Cafe, Investment, Restaurant, Alternate Use, Bar
detailedDescription: Occupying a prominent position on the High Street amongst other Public Houses, Bars and Night Clubs is this large open plan public house over ground and first floors, the ground floor is furnished with booth style seating, high stools and tables with additional standing areas and a large bar servery to the right hand side, there are a number of TV's throughout showing live sport. Towards the rear of the bar area is a pool playing area and further seating. The first floor consists of a split level trading area and having the benefit of its own bar servery for ease of operation over the 2 floors. Ladies and Gentleman's toilets. Ancillary areas include Beer Cellar and additional storage areas.  The property is located on the High Street in the seaside town of Redcar. The surrounding area is made up of other licensed properties, bars, nightclubs, takeaway outlets and other retail outlets. Redcar has a strong all year round trade which can peak in the summer months with tourists visiting the area We understand that the property is not a listed building or in a flood risk area. All further enquiries relating to planning should be directed to Redcar and Cleveland Council. All trade fixtures and fitting are owned by the current tenant. displayAddress: 21 Main Road, Dyke, Bourne, Lincolnshire, PE10 0AF
propertySubType: Guest House, Public House, Bar, Restaurant
detailedDescription: Believed to be over 300 years old, the Wishing Well is a two and single storey, brick-built detached property with mainly painted, rendered elevations beneath both pitched tiled and flat roofs. The Premises has two customer entrances, one straight off Main Road and the primary entrance to the rear through a conservatory. The characterful trading areas briefly comprise: the Bar area with stone-built bar servery, inglenook fireplace with log burner, exposed stone walls, beamed ceiling, the brick-built well from which the Premises takes its name and free-standing seating for approximately 40. The rear Restaurant area has approximately 60 covers, with waitress station, oak flooring, exposed stone walls, beamed ceiling and inglenook fireplace. The rear Snug bar provides an additional 18 covers of easy-chair seating, with a stone-built corner bar servery, wooden flooring and exposed stone walls, with darts throw area. The Wishing Well also benefits from Ladies and Gents W.C.s, a well equipped commercial kitchen supplemented by a preparation area and fridge/freezer store. A rear dry store area leads to a small ground floor beer cellar and spirit store. A small reception/office is located at the end of the bar. The pub benefits from number of letting rooms situated over the first floor. A total of nine ensuite rooms are currently in operation, comprising seven double rooms and two single rooms. An additional three rooms that have previously been let out are currently utilised as a staff changing room, office and store room. The domestic accommodation is also situated over the first floor. The private accommodation briefly consists of three bedrooms, a lounge/diner, domestic kitchen, bathroom and office. The Wishing Well benefits from a good-sized car park at the rear, laid to gravel with spacing for c. 24 vehicles. An overflow carpark situated immediately to the rear of the car park provides an additional 10 spaces. To the rear of the restaurant is a covered patio area with seating for c. 16, with steps up to the lawned beer garden with picnic bench seating for approximately 28. Adjacent to the lawned area is a paved patio area with seating for approximately 36 and an additional hardstanding area with picnic bench seating.  The Wishing Well Inn is located on Main Road in the centre of the Lincolnshire village of Dyke. Dyke is in the South Kesteven district of Lincolnshire, situated less than 1 mile (1.6 km) east from the A15 road. Dyke is within the Bourne civil parish. The name Dyke arises from its lying on Car Dyke, a once much larger Roman ditch, which runs along the western edge of The Fens. The section of Car Dyke between Dyke and Bourne is a scheduled ancient monument.   Bourne is a market town and civil parish in the South Kesteven district of Lincolnshire. The town lies on the eastern slopes of the limestone Kesteven Uplands and the western edge of the Fens, 11 miles (18 km) north-east of Stamford, 12 miles (19 km) west of Spalding and 17 miles (27 km) north of Peterborough. The Property is situated under the jurisdiction of South Kesteven District Council. The Property is not Listed nor situated within a Conservation Area. Rental offers in the region of £35,000pa (plus VAT), are invited for a new private Free of Tie commercial lease. Terms are flexible but the new agreement will ideally be 5 years, on a Fully Repairing and Insuring basis with annual RPI increases. The Rateable Value of The Wishing Well has been assessed at £25,000 (2023).

propertySubType: Takeaway, Public House, Bar, Leisure, Cafe, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Crown, whilst currently closed, has been recently been trading as a contemporary venue with an alternative, industrial-style vibe.  The ground floor is accessed directly off High Street into a largely open plan trade areas with lounge are to the front (c 15+ covers), leading to a central feature bar servery, with loose seating and bar stools (30+ covers).  To the rear is further seating area, DJ booth and customer WC's. The bar can cater for 75+ internal covers. To the rear is a ground floor patio leading to the 1st floor roof terrace and outside bar servery, via a self contained external staircase. This feature outside space caters for over 60 covers with dedicated bar servery and decking. The 1st floor provides a commercial trade kitchen, with dumb waiter to the ground floor, plus storage. In addition there is an office, kitchen and bathroom. The 2nd floor provides 2 double & 1 single bedroom. A substantial cellar is located on basement level with drop to High Street. The Crown is situated on High Street in a prominent position in terraced row of commercial properties with parking to the rear at Matthew Street Car Park. The bar’s central location and close proximity to other shops and amenities ensures high levels of passing footfall. The property is situated in a densely populated area, with 22,420 adults living within one mile, with Central Bedfordshire College a short walk away. The property is not Listed and administered by Central Bedfordshire Council The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house extends to 213m² (2,293 ft2).  Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. propertySubType: Land / Development, Other, Guest House, Bar, Investment, Cafe, Alternate Use, Leisure, Restaurant, Takeaway, Retail, Public House
detailedDescription: The Britannia Public House which was originally at 4 Church Street and later merged with the attached 6 and 8 Church Street is a three, two and single storey end of terrace property. The property has a main elevation to Church Street with a curved corner elevation that wraps around the eastern corner of the building, returning southwest along a narrow access laneway between the Britannia and the site of the former fish market to the southeast. The internal accommodation briefly comprises an entrance porch via the curved doorway, leading to the main bar and trading areas. The trading areas are split into sections with a single bar servery, pool room, a lower-level area with DJ booth and wooden floors; and a rear room, with AWP and boxing machines and access to the riverside terrace. The pub also has Ladies and Gents W.C.s and two further rooms to the rear of the pub, that are used for storage. The domestic accommodation is situated over the upper floors and briefly comprises a lounge, bathroom (with separate W.C.) over the first floor, with stairs up to a domestic kitchen. A separate staircase provides access to two additional rooms on the second floor. To the exterior, there is a small terrace to the rear of the pub, overlooking the river. A storage shed, housing a boiler, is accessed from the terrace. The Britannia Public House is located in the historic core of Boston, on the northeast side of the River Witham, just off the market square. Boston is a market town and inland port in the borough of the same name in the county of Lincolnshire. It lies to the south-east of Lincoln, east of Nottingham and north-east of Peterborough. The Haven in Boston flows about 5 miles away to the Lincolnshire coast at The Wash, a bay between Lincolnshire and Norfolk. Boston's most notable landmark is St Botolph's Church, colloquially referred to as 'The Stump', the largest parish church in England. According to the 2021 Census, the population of Boston is around 70,815. This is 9.1% higher than the 64,600 reported in the 2011 Census.  The local authority is Boston Borough Council. The site is located within the Boston Conservation Area and the building itself, comprising 4, 6, and 8 Church Street, is Grade II Listed. The property benefits from planning permission granted 11 March 2025 (Application Reference: B/24/0336) :Listed Building Consent for proposed conversion into 3 no. apartments and associated works. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment.  The total site area is approximately 0.058 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) extends to 2,044ft2. Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. The Rateable Value (RV) has been assessed at £14,750.

displayAddress: Worthenbury Road, Shocklach, Malpas, Cheshire, SY14 7BL
propertySubType: Cafe, Bar, Land / Development, Public House, Investment, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Bull at Shocklach is an attractive country pub believed to date back to 1850. The Bull is a two and single storey brick built detached property of painted rendered elevations pitched tiled roofs.  The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall providing access to the largely open plan bar area, with approximately 44 covers, with a single timber bar servery, two feature fireplaces, an attractive patchwork floor of hand painted tiles, part wooden flooring, beamed ceilings and part wood-clad walls. The 'Long Room' is a dining room accommodating c. 30 covers, flagstone flooring and beamed ceiling; and a rear conservatory room provides an additional 28 covers and access hall to the rear garden and car park.   The Bull also benefits from Ladies & Gents W.C.s, basement beer cellar, a commercial kitchen with separate wash-up area, dry store with walk-in chiller and boiler room. The domestic accommodation is located over the 1st floor and briefly comprises a lounge, domestic kitchen-diner, bedroom, office/2nd bedroom, box room and bathroom. To the exterior the pub sits in a plot of 0.37 acres. The pub benefits from a car park to the rear providing approximately 24 spaces; a paved terrace and lawned beer garden to to the rear. The Bull is situated in the attractive Cheshire village of Shocklach. The village is in the civil parish of Shocklach Oviatt and district in the Cheshire West and Chester district.  Shocklach village is in the southwestern corner of Cheshire, approximately 1 kilometre (0.6 mi) from the border between Wales and England, the River Dee. The village lies between Wrexham 10 kilometres (6 miles) to the west, and Nantwich 21 kilometres (13 miles) to the east. The rural village is very close to the village of Malpas, located right in the heart of historic Cheshire. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated within a Conservation Area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. The overall site size is c. 0.37 acres and the property has a ground floor footprint of 2,878 sq ft, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). propertySubType: Public House, Retail, Alternate Use, Bar, Restaurant, Leisure, Land / Development
detailedDescription: Believed to have been built in 1939, on the site of an older building that was also a pub of the same name, the Pheasant is a two storey semi-detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall leading from Market Street providing access to the trading areas. The public bar has a timber bar servery, brick built fireplace, upholstered perimeter seating and darts throw. The games room to the left has space for pool table and darts throw and the rear lounge bar has a small bar servery and upholstered fixed seating.   The pub also benefits Ladies and Gents W.C.s, which are located off the bar areas, a kitchen, bottle store and ground floor beer cellar. The Pheasant is located in the centre of the busy market town of Newtown in Powys. Newtown stands on the banks of the River Severn within the picturesque Powys countryside some 8 miles from the England/Wales border. It's located astride the main A483 and its junction with the A470, which is commonly seen as the gateway to the West Wales coast from the Midlands. Its train station is located on the Shrewsbury to Aberystwyth line which is serviced by transport for Wales. The town is approximately 13 miles Welshpool, 22 miles Llandrindod Wells, 32 miles Shrewsbury and 44 miles Aberystwyth.   The local authority is Powys Council. displayAddress: Evesham Road, Iron Cross, Evesham, Worcestershire, WR11 8SH
detailedDescription: The Queens Head is a two and single storey detached property of painted brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The attractive trading accommodation briefly consists of an entrance hall leading to the bar area with bar servery, wooden flooring, feature fireplace, beamed ceiling. The delightful restaurant area comprises a hot food servery, part flagstone and part wooden flooring and feature inglenook fireplace The dining area provides approximately 40 covers in total. The Queens Head also benefits from letting accommodation over the first  floor. The five letting rooms, all with ensuite facilities, briefly comprise 2x Family Rooms, 2x Double Rooms and 1x Single Room. The pub also benefits from Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s, a good sized commercial kitchen with walk in cold store and wash up area; and a basement beer cellar.   The domestic accommodation, situated over both the ground and upper floors, comprises a domestic kitchenette, shower room and 2x bedrooms on the ground floor; and 3x further bedrooms over the upper floors. To the exterior the pub benefits from an enclosed paved and lawned beer garden with picnic bench seating for c.40, and a good sized car park to the side providing space for 20 vehicles. A private yard to the rear with lawn and access to cold and dry stores. Queens Head Inn is located in the hamlet of Iron Cross, in the 'Vale of Evesham', close to Salford Priors near the North Cotswolds. Salford Priors is a rural, agricultural village and civil parish about four miles south-west of Alcester, Warwickshire.  The population of the civil parish as taken at the 2011 census was 1,546. It is on the Warwickshire border with Worcestershire. The village is eight miles from the popular tourist town of Stratford upon Avon, the birthplace of William Shakespeare, and the River Avon runs near to it. Evesham lies seven miles to the south-west and is an important agricultural centre and soft fruit-growing area. The population of the Salford Priors ward – which includes the communities of Abbot's Salford, Dunnington, Iron Cross, Pitchill, Rushford and Mudwalls – was 1,492 at the 2001 census. The local authority is Stratford-on-Avon District Council. We are advised that the property is not Listed but prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. The new lease will be either 10 or 20 years, on a Fully Repairing and Insuring basis with 5 yearly upward only reviews and annual RPI increases. The Lease may be assigned after the end of the first two years. Deposit - The equivalent of three months’ rent is required as a deposit. Interest is payable upon this. displayAddress: City Road, Radnage, High Wycombe, Bucks, HP14 4DW
propertySubType: Guest House, Leisure, Public House, Restaurant, Bar
detailedDescription: The Crown is a substantial detached two storey building, presented in excellent condition. The ground floor bar is accessed by a central doorway, as well as from the rear, providing a bar servery, wooden flooring, open fireplaces and space for around 50 covers in total. To the rear is a well equipped commercial trade kitchen, as well as customer WC and ground floor cellar. The 1st floor provides residential accommodation, again in excellent condition, comprising, 1 x Studio flat, plus a further 1 bed flat, including lounge, kitchen, 1 double bedroom and bathroom. The trading areas continue towards the first floor where there is a separate function room/restaurant space which has the ability to accommodate an additional 40 covers; this space also benefits from its own dedicated servery. Ancillary trade areas comprise customer W/Cs, commercial kitchen with prep room, cellarage and associated storage areas. Private accommodation is spread across both the first and second floor and comprises 3 double bedrooms, kitchen, living room, bathroom and storage spaces. Externally and to the rear of the property is a small decked and benched beer garden suitable for outdoor drinking, in addition to a smoking solution situated to the left hand side of the property upon entrance. propertySubType: Cafe, Land / Development, Bar, Public House, Guest House, Restaurant, Takeaway, Leisure, Alternate Use, Investment
detailedDescription: The Duke of Bridgewater is a three storey detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall leading to an open plan trading area with timber bar servery, part wooden flooring, perimeter seating, feature fireplace pool area and darts throw. A disabled W.C. is situated off the pool area and steps lead to the Ladies & Gents W.C.s. The pub also benefits from a commercial kitchen space and a spacious basement area incorporating beer cellar, bottle store and further store rooms. The accommodation above the pub is located over the upper floors and briefly comprises over the 1st Floor : domestic kitchen, office, bedroom, shower room and separate W.C. and one room that has been partially subdivided into two separate rooms. A set of stairs lead to the 2nd Floor, with two large double bedrooms. A further set of stairs provide access to two attic bedrooms. To the exterior the pub has a rear garden with lawned area and covered paved seating area.  The Duke of Bridgewater is prominently located at the junction of Wistaston Road (A532), Edlestone Road and Oak Street (A5078), in the Cheshire town of Crewe. The pub is situated a short walk from Crewe town centre. Crewe is a railway town and civil parish in the unitary authority of Cheshire East. The civil parish of Crewe had a population of 55,318 in the 2021 census. The larger Crewe built-up area, which also covers parts of the adjacent civil parishes of Willaston, Shavington cum Gresty and Wistaston, had a total population of 76,437 in 2021. Crewe is perhaps best known as a large railway junction and home to Crewe Works; for many years, it was a major railway engineering facility for manufacturing and overhauling locomotives, but now much reduced in size. From 1946 until 2002, it was also the home of Rolls Royce motor car production. The Pyms Lane factory on the west of the town now exclusively produces Bentley motor cars. Crewe is 158 miles (254 km) northwest of London, 28 miles (45 km) south of Manchester, and 31 miles (50 km) southeast of Liverpool city centre. The local authority is Cheshire East. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint of the property is 2,029 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.199 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). propertySubType: Public House, Guest House, Bar, Leisure, Other, Investment, Hotel, Restaurant
detailedDescription: Front entrance leading directly into the main bar, which is beautifully decorated in a traditional theme with exposed beams and large inglenook fire place and stunning period features throughout. The bar area can set approx 40 customers, including bar seating. The main bar leads round to the restaurant area (the other side of the fireplace) and can seat up to 60 customers. Fully equipped trade kitchen with prep/wash up area. The kitchen also benefits from a walk in fridge/freezer. Ancillary storage and laundry room space both internally and externally as well as a ground floor cellar which is accessible from behind the bar. 1st floor owners accommodation consisting of  2 double bedrooms, spacious lounge, kitchen with dining area, bathroom. 2nd floor one room, which could be used for storage or a third bedroom. There is also an office and storage room.  Letting Accommodation - The accommodation is a separate, two storey building which includes 8 separate rooms which are available to book 7 days per week. This unit includes just over 2,000 sq ft of floor space, with 4 double bedrooms with en-suites on the ground floor and 2 double bedrooms with en-suites on the first floor. There is also a family bedroom and a single bedroom which share a bathroom on the first floor. External areas consist of a large car park to the front and side of the pub for 50 plus cars. The property boasts one of the largest beer gardens in the area (200 + on bench seating), with a children's play area. There is also a hard standing covered pagoda space with wall mounted TVs, ideal for those wanting to watch live sports in the warmer months. The large space lends itself ideally for various events throughout the year such as music events and beer festivals.   The picturesque village of Barham is located 8 miles northwest of Ipswich, 22 miles from Bury St Edmunds and  40 miles southwest of Norwich.  Having excellent commuter links to London (under 90 minutes by train from Ipswich) or by car just over 2 hours using the A12. The Essex city of Colchester to the south is only 30 minutes drive away. The Sorrell Horse Inn is conveniently located in the centre of this charming village setting, immediately off the Norwich Road. juat 2 miles from the  A14 and A140 juntion. We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed, Listing number 1033250. For further information please contact the Mid Suffolk District Council https://www.midsuffolk.gov.uk/   The total area for the site is 1.046 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house extends to 439 m² (4,728 ft²). Rent deposit of 3 months of headline rent. Stock at valuation. Rateable Value from 1st April to date are £42,000.

The town is known for Beverley Minster, Beverley Westwood, North Bar (a 15th-century gate) and Beverley Racecourse. Beverley is a county town of the East Riding, located 8 miles north-west of Hull, 10 miles east of Market Weighton and 12 miles west of Hornsea. detailedDescription: A traditional coaching inn, the Griffin dates back to the early 18th Century and is a 1.5 storey, timber-framed and plastered building with 3 dormers to the attic at the front. The detached property had been modernised several years ago but retains many period features such as a large bay window and sash windows. The ground floor has an attractive central bar servery and a variety of loose and fixed seating for c 60 internal covers in total. Refurbished male and female WC's and an extensive cellar and storeroom are located at ground floor level.  A commercial kitchen, with extraction, is located behind the bar area. On the first floor, there is a well presented manager's flat which comprises a large double bedroom, domestic kitchen/diner and lounge, along with a large bathroom with shower and bath, plus storage areas. Outside, there is a patio trade garden enclosed by fencing with picnic tables catering for c. 50+ covers.  An extensive dedicated car park provides plenty of car parking to the rear with access from Parsonage Street. The town of Halstead is situated in north Essex, within the Braintree district, around 6 miles north of Braintree and 13 miles west of Colchester. It has a population of c. 11,906 (2011 census). The Griffin is located in the oldest part of the town on Parsonage Street, a short walk from the River Colne and the town centre. We are advised the property is Grade II Listed but does not fall within a conservation area. The relevant local authority is Braintree District Council https://www.braintree.gov.uk/   The property will be sold subject to an overage clause for new residential development (excluding conversion of the existing) for a period of 10 years, with 20% of any uplift in value payable to the vendor for the first 5 years, dropping to 10% for the remaining 5 years.
