Substantial private accommodation is provided at 1st floor level. This comprises master bedroom with walk-in wardrobe, three-piece bathroom, single bedroom, additional double bedroom with fitted wardrobes, domestic kitchen and large lounge with adjoining office, or 4th bedroom. Lamarsh is a small rural village in northeast Essex, close to the Suffolk border.  It lies just seven miles northeast of Halstead, five miles south of Sudbury and within an easy walk of Bures, giving it a distinctly agricultural, tranquil character with long views across farmland. The Lamarsh Lion is set on Bures Road the main road through the village so it is easy to find.   The pub has stunning views across the beautiful Stour Valley (where both Gainsborough and Constable painted).  There has been an Inn on the site for over 700 years and it is a focal point for locals and visitors alike, serving food, ales and hosting events in an attractive rural setting. We are advised that the property is neither listed nor situated within a Conservation Area.  The area is subject to an application as an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries to the local authority Braintree District Council , or by telephone on 01376 552525. The business is fully fitted with comprehensive trade inventory, including commercial trade kitchen. The area of the site, as measured from digital mapping, is approximately 2,952m² or 0.73 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) extends to 296 m² (3,185 sq ft), excluding the smoking shelter. Areas are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. While rent is subject to negotiation, rental offers are sought in Excess of £22,500 pax for a new 'free of tie' FRI lease. Terms to be negotiated to include an incoming fee (to cover the fixtures & fittings etc), stock, rent deposit, plus rent in advance. Rateable Value (1 April 2023 to present) £9,000.  Future Rateable Value (from 1 April 2026) £9,500. (EXEMPT)

displayAddress: 3 High Street, Rippingale, Bourne, Lincolnshire, PE10 0SR
propertySubType: Public House, Bar, Restaurant, Guest House
detailedDescription: The Bull Inn is a two storey detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs, with single storey additions to the side and rear.  The entrance hall leading from High Street provides access to the two front bar areas. The lounge bar has a timber bar servery, an open feature fireplace with brick surround and timber flooring. The public bar also boasts a timber bar servery, wooden flooring and a brick-built feature fireplace. An internal hallway provides access to the rear and Ladies & Gents W.C.s. A restaurant area situated to the rear of the lounge bar can accommodate c. 30 covers; with access to a function room/restaurant overflow with wooden floor and doors to the rear patio. The pub also benefits from a fully equipped commercial kitchen with prep room and fridge/freezer store room, and sunken ground floor beer cellar.  The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and briefly comprises a lounge (which has been converted into a games room with pool table and darts throw), office, two bedrooms (one being ensuite), refitted domestic kitchen and bathroom.  The pub also benefits from five letting rooms located in a separate single storey block to the rear of the pub. The letting rooms comprise 1x Family room, 1x Single room, 2x Doubles and a Double Suite. All the rooms are tastefully appointed and benefit from ensuite facilities.  To the exterior, the pub sits in a large plot of 0.619 acres with a spacious and picturesque beer garden, with mature shrub boarders, with picnic bench seating and childrens' play equipment. A paved patio to the rear of the function room with seating for c. 20 and a further outdoor drinking patio outside the rear entrance. A good sized car park is situated to the side and rear of the property, with two brick-built outbuildings providing additional storage space. The Bull Inn is located in the centre of the Lincolnshire village of Rippingale. Rippingale is an attractive village and civil parish in the South Kesteven district of Lincolnshire. The population of the civil parish was 942 at the 2021 census. The village is situated just off the busy A15 approximately five miles north of Bourne and 15 miles south east of Grantham.  Bourne is a market town and civil parish in the South Kesteven district of Lincolnshire. The town lies on the eastern slopes of the limestone Kesteven Uplands and the western edge of the Fens, 11 miles (18 km) north-east of Stamford, 12 miles (19 km) west of Spalding and 17 miles (27 km) north of Peterborough. The Property is situated under the jurisdiction of South Kesteven District Council. The Property is not Listed nor situated within a Conservation Area. Rental offers in the region of £25,000pa are invited for a new private Free of Tie commercial tenancy. Terms are flexible but the new agreement will ideally be 6 years, on a Fully Repairing and Insuring basis with annual RPI increases. An initial rental concession may be available for the successful operator. VAT will be applied to the rent. Rateable Value of teh Bull Inn has been assessed at £11,750 (2023).The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business

displayAddress: 9 Abbey Street, Ickleton, Saffron Walden, Essex, CB10 1SS
propertySubType: Public House, Leisure, Other, Bar
detailedDescription: The Ickleton Lion is a charming detached largely 2 storey building with single storey side extensions, under pitched tiled and slate roof. The ground floor provides a traditional bar with exposed timbers, tiled and wooden flooring, log burners and wood paneling. There are a number of interconnecting trade areas with a Snug centred around a large brick fireplace with access to the central bar servery (8/10 covers). This leads onto a further bar area to the front, as well as to the rear, divided by exposed timbers, with direct access to the trade garden and bar (c 30/35 covers).  To the side is a vaulted dining area with a mix of loose and banquette seating with space for 25/30 covers. Serving these areas are male & female WC's, ground floor cellar and separate wine store with direct access to Abbey Street. To the rear is a substantial commercial trade kitchen with extraction, leading onto a storage area and wash up area. The upper parts comprise  4/5 bedrooms.  The 1st floor comprises office/single bedroom, 2 double bedrooms, lounge, dining area, domestic kitchen and 3 piece bathroom.  The 2nd floor comprise 2 further single bedrooms. Externally the public house boasts a dedicated shingle car park, as well as a walled grassed south west facing trade garden with ample space for 60/80 covers, as well as pétanque piste, gazebo and patio areas. To the front is a useful storage shed and bin store. The Sanger Centre, home to the Wellcome Trust’s Genome Centre, is less than one mile away, undergoing rapid expansion. As well as nearby Imperial War Museum Duxford and Audley End House. Communications from the village are excellent with access to the M11 just a mile away.  Both the A1 (northwards) and the A14 (east to Ipswich, west to Birmingham) can easily be reached from the M11. The Cambridge – London, Liverpool Street railway line runs to the east of the village from Great Chesterford station (1 mile), Whittlesford (2 miles) and Audley End (5 miles). We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed. Listing entry 1330972. The local authority is South Cambs District Council  The property has been register as an Asset of Community Value (ACV) with the Full Moratorium expiring on 24th September 2024. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as beer raising equipment. The total site area measures 0.288 acres.  The ground floor footprint of the public house is 2,423 ft2 .  Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate.   Freehold available with vacant possession. The property is being sold as seen, seeking unconditional cash offers in the region of £475,000 (ex VAT). Business Rates as of 1st April 2023 are £14,000. Council Tax:  Band B

propertySubType: Public House, Leisure, Restaurant, Other, Bar
detailedDescription: The Sun is a very attractive detached stone built detached property, presented in excellent condition throughout. The ground floor provides a number of interconnecting trade areas including bar, lounge and dining areas, in a traditional style, with space for around 60 covers in total, serviced by a central bar servery and customer WC's. To the rear is a fully fitted commercial trade kitchen, with commercial extraction, plus wash up and storage areas. A substantial cellar and storage areas are situated at ground floor level. Extensive residential accommodation is above including, 2 double bedrooms, kitchen/diner, bathrooms and dressing room. Externally the property provides a rear grassed trade garden, service yard & patio. To the front is a dedicated car park, utilised for trading, with decked area and heated pods (c 60+ covers). An ongoing programme of repair and maintenance has been undertaken including repairs to the ground floor cellar and rethatching the entire roof during covid. Kislingbury is an attractive village in Northamptonshire, located about 4 miles (6 km) west of Northampton town centre, and close to junctions 15A and 16 of the M1 Motorway. There is a good mix of old and new houses in the village which is surrounded by open countryside and the River Nene which runs through it. The area has seen significant housing development in recent years. In 2024,  West Northamptonshire Council  (WNC) and  North Northamptonshire Council  (NNC) approved the development of 2,282 homes and flats, just in large planning applications of parcels of more than 50 properties. We are advised that the Sun Inn is Grade II Listed (Listing Number: 1371550) All enquiries can be made to West Northamptonshire Council . The property is fully fitted as a turnkey operation, including wholly owned comprehensive trade inventory and kitchen equipment.  Stock will be payable in addition on completion. The area of the site, as measured from digital mapping, is approximately 0.201 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) extends to 240 m² (2,586 ft²). Freehold offers, inclusive of trade inventory, IP and goodwill are sought in excess of £350,000 (plus VAT). SAV in addition. Rateable Value, as of 1st April 2023, is £6,500. (NO BUSINESS RATES PAYABLE) Council Tax Band A

displayAddress: Smithy Lane, Bowland Bridge, Cumbria, LA11 6NN
propertySubType: Guest House, Other, Cafe, Alternate Use, Hotel, Public House, Investment, Restaurant, Bar
detailedDescription: On entering this charming pub, to the left you are welcomed with a comfy snug with cosy fixtures and fittings, complete with an open fire place which is exceptionally popular on the cooler days and this area is serviced by the delightful bar slightly to the right. To the right of the pub you will find the dining areas which are split into four sections which could easily accommodate a large number of diners at a time. There are 5 en-suite letting bedrooms located on the first and second floor, all of good quality with fully fitted bathrooms. There is a fully fitted commercial catering kitchen with separate wash up are and extraction. Outside the pub, the beer garden embraces the building in a horseshoe manner, with picnic benches to the front and side and a dramatic garden to the rear with phenomenal and uninterrupted views of the surrounding countryside with the benefit of an outside bar which has previously been used in the summer months. There is a large car park approximately 20 yards from the pub.  There is no living accommodation unless a couple of letting bedrooms were converted. Bowland Bridge is a small, idyllic hamlet set among rolling hills and quiet countryside on the edge of the Lake District. Surrounded by farmland, woodland and scenic walking routes, it offers a peaceful rural escape. Despite its rural feel, Bowland Bridge is well positioned for exploring the wider Lake District with Kendal, Windermere and Ulverston all within easy reach. We are advised that the property is not listed or in a flood zone but does sit in the National Park. The Fixtures & Fittings that remain on the premises at the time of completion will be included in the sale. Any third party owned items, such as beer raising and cellar cooling equipment, branded items, gaming machines etc, will be excluded. An inventory will not be provided. The vendors will not be required to remove any such items that remain on the premises. Total site area is 0.629 acres with a building footprint of 3,226 Sq Ft. (Measurements have been provided by a digital mapping tool) The property is in an area administered by South Lakeland Council. The April 2026 Rateable Value has been assessed at £41,000. We advise any interested parties to make their own enquiries.

propertySubType: Hotel, Public House, Restaurant, Bar
detailedDescription: The Golden Ball could be described as being the perfect country pub and if you visit this Cambridgeshire gem it’s hard to argue otherwise! The clean yet rustic bar with high barn vaulted ceiling makes it a very unique building. The property boasts a traditional bar area that leads to a good-sized lounge & restaurant with a total of 100 covers and two delightful ‘snug’ areas that can be used for private dining and/or small meetings. Ladies, Gents and Disabled WCs. The catering kitchen is well presented with an excellent selection of commercial catering equipment, and the beer cellar is off the back of the bar. The private accommodation comprises two bedrooms, a small kitchen, lounge and a bathroom with over bath shower. The site also benefits from 10 en-suite letting rooms in a separate 'Hotel' block, with reception area.  External areas consist of ample parking for c30 cars. A well maintained and enclosed beer garden, laid to grass.  The Golden Ball occupies a superb position in the affluent hamlet of Boxworth just 2 miles from the A14. The Golden Ball is in a prominent position on the road from Papworth Everard to the A14 Junction 24 via Elsworth. The Pub is 5 miles north of Cambourne and 10 miles west of Cambridge and with St Ives and Huntingdon a mere 8 & 10 miles away. Sitting in and surrounded by the affluent villages of Boxworth, Elsworth, Conington and Dry Drayton. The property is Grade II Listed and is situated within a Conservation Area.  An extensive trade inventory (including kitchen equipment) is available to purchase at an agreed price.  Total Floor Space of 3,983 sq ft Total Site area of 1.033 acres  *all measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping  New 'Free of Tie' lease available at either 10, 15 or 20 years. Nil Premium at an annual rent of £66,000 (exc VAT). Business plan and guarantors will need to be provided.  3 months deposit requested at £16,500. Rateable Value - £32,000 as of 1st April 2023.

propertySubType: Restaurant, Public House, Bar, Takeaway, Alternate Use, Other, Cafe
detailedDescription: The Loddiswell Inn is a traditional pub occupying a corner plot right in the centre of the village. There are two interlinked trade areas both served by an attractive bar area, with open fires and a secondary raised seating area that is ideal for functions and Sunday lunches. Ladies and Gents facilities. Basement cellar. There is a well-equipped commercial kitchen and a lovely cosy patio area. The Loddiswell Inn is a versatile property with much to offer the new owners. The Loddiswell is exactly what you expect to see when walking into a traditional cosy village pub. When walking through the trade area, there is a well appointed and fitted out ladies and gents toilets and a passage way through to the well equipped trade kitchen. The kitchen is fitted out in stainless steel with a range cooker, oven, double fryers, many items of equipment and fully equipped with small catering effects. Outside of the pub, there is a well built smoking shelter and a small grassed area with some pub benches. Please note that the front seating area is currently owned by the village and not the pub. The well sized private accommodation consists of two double bedrooms. It benefits from a domestic kitchen, large and well appointed lounge and a family bathroom. The village of Loddiswell is located in the heart of the beautiful South Hams area of Devon. To the north is Dartmoor National Park (8 miles), to the east the borders of Torbay (20 miles), and the west of Plymouth (18 miles). This area has some of the most unspoiled coastlines on the south coast, including the promontories of Start Point, and Bolt Head. The building is not listed and is not situated within a Conservation Area. The property is registered as an Asset of Community Value (ACV) until 18 July 2028. Please note that the grassed area to the front of the pub does not form part of the existing title and is under separate ownership. Those seeking alternative use are asked to make their own enquiries via South Hams District Council -  https://www.southhams.gov.uk/planning Total site area - 0.051 acres Total Floor Area - 1,970 sq ft (all measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate) Freehold with benefit of vacant possession looking for unconditional offers in the region of £195,000 plus VAT. The property is being sold as seen and all parties are asked to carry out their own due diligence before submitting an offer.  Viewings arranged through sole agents- Everard Cole Rateable Value from 1st April 2023 - £5,000

propertySubType: Investment, Land / Development, Other, Alternate Use, Cafe, Guest House, Leisure, Public House, Restaurant, Bar, Takeaway, Retail
detailedDescription: The Railway Inn is a two and single storey detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall leading from Station Road which provides access to two bar areas. The main L-shaped lounge bar area, has a large timber bar servery and seating for approximately 30. The public bar has it's own timber bar servery and seating for a further 24. A pool room to the rear, with quarry-tiled flooring connects the two bar areas.   A rear hallway provides access to the Ladies and Gents W.C.s and the outdoor trade area to the rear of the property.  The Railway also benefits from a small commercial kitchen, basement beer cellar and bottle store. The first floor can be accessed by two staircases and briefly comprises three bedrooms, large lounge, office, domestic kitchen and bathroom.  To the exterior, the enclosed rear area comprises a paved patio area with picnic bench seating for 24, an artificial grass area and a two and single storey brick built outbuilding which provides additional covered outdoor seating and storage.  The Railway is prominently located on Station Road, the A511, in the centre of Hatton. The pub is adjacent to the entrance of the large Nestlé' factory, which is a major local employer. The factory has received multimillion pound investment in recent years and developed into a major coffee producer being the sole UK facility producing the Dolce Gusto range, and also Nescafe. Hatton is a village and civil parish in South Derbyshire. The village is close to the A50 road which links the M1 and M6 motorways and is located 5 miles (8.0 km) north of Burton Upon Trent, 10 miles (16 km) south-west of Derby and 24 miles (39 km) south-east of Stoke-on-Trent. The population of the civil parish as of the 2011 census was 2,785. The local authority is the South Derbyshire District Council. We are advised that the property is not Listed but is situated within a Flood Zone 3. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment. The ground floor footprint of the property is 2,640 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.096 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Rateable Value of the Railway Inn has been assessed at £6,500 (2023). The premises may qualify for Small Business Rates Relief in which case the non-domestic rating liability may be nil subject to the ratepayer occupying only one property for the purposes of business.

propertySubType: Public House, Bar, Investment, Alternate Use, Retail, Takeaway, Leisure, Restaurant, Guest House, Cafe, Other
detailedDescription: A mid terrace property extending to 3 storeys under a pitched slate roof. The bar area occupies the entire ground floor of the property with booth style seating and high and low tables with addition standing areas. To the rear of the bar area is a large well kitted bar servery. The current trade is 100% wet sales but historically has served food and has a commercial catering kitchen ready to go and there is a proven demand for food. The first floor comprises of a managers flat, staff room and additional storage. The second floor is occupied by our client as their offices and is of good size and currently consists of multi room office accommodation that could be converted to  residential accommodation.  The property is located on the High Street in the seaside town of Redcar. The surrounding area is made up of other licensed properties, bars, nightclubs, takeaway outlets and other retail outlets. Redcar has a strong all year round trade which can peak in the summer months with tourists visiting the area. We understand that the property is not a listed building or in a flood risk area. All further enquiries relating to planning should be directed to Redcar and Cleveland Council. All trade fixtures and fitting are owned by the current tenant. Total site area is 0.043 Acre and total floor area extends to 7,556 Sq Ft (702 Sq m). Please note that measurments have been taken from a digital mapping platform. Rateable Value, as at 1st April 2023, £32,500.

displayAddress: 274-276 Crimicar Lane, Lodge Moor, Sheffield, South Yorkshire, S10 4EP
propertySubType: Restaurant, Bar, Public House
detailedDescription: The property is named after the Royal Navy ship, HMS Sheffield. The ship was nicknamed the "Shiny Sheff" because it carried many fixtures and fittings (particularly stainless steel), manufactured in Sheffield. The pub is a large two and single storey detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. The accommodation briefly comprises a large open plan trading area with zoned areas including a bar with darts and pool, lounge and dining areas.  Two timber bar serveries allow service on ether side, with pool and darts throw areas, perimeter seating and raised dining area. The entrance hallway provides access to the Ladies and Gents W.C.s and the conservatory provides access out onto a timber decked outdoor drinking terrace.   The Shiny Sheff also benefits from a commercial catering kitchen with walk-in chiller, a ground floor cellar, with store room and staff room. The good sized, three-bedroom domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor. To the exterior the Shiny Sheff enjoys a large car park to the front and side rear, with approximately 35 spaces; a raised decking terrace offers an elevated view over the Peak District, and private rear yard. The Shiny Sheff is prominently located at the corner of Crimicar Lane and Redmires Road in the Lodge Moor area of Sheffield. Lodge Moor is a popular suburb of Sheffield to the west of Fulwood. It lies on the edge of open countryside and is home to a large golf course. Sheffield is a city in South Yorkshire, situated 29 miles (47 km) south of Leeds and 32 miles (51 km) east of Manchester. It is the largest settlement in South Yorkshire and the third largest of Northern England.  The city is in the eastern foothills of the Pennines and the valleys of the River Don with its four tributaries. Sixty-one per cent of Sheffield's entire area is green space and a third of the city lies within the Peak District National Park and is the fifth-largest city in England. We understand the Property is neither Listed nor situated within a conservation area, but prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries with Sheffield City Council The overall site size is c. 0.563 acres and the property has a ground floor footprint of 5,023 sq ft, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate) Rental offers are invited for a new Free of Tie leasehold interest. The agreement will be a Free of Tie, full repairing and insuring lease, for a term of years to be agreed. The equivalent of 3-6 months’ rent is required as a deposit. A contribution to Landlord's legal fees of £1,500 will be payable. Rateable Value of the Shiny Sheff has been assessed at £17,000 (2023).

displayAddress: Pastures Lane, Mexborough, South Yorkshire, S64 0JJ
detailedDescription: The Pastures Lodge Pub-Restaurant is an extensive, two and single storey property of stone elevations beneath pitched tiled and flat roofs. With a ground floor footprint of over 20,000 sq ft, the Pastures Lodge has over 400 covers and offers a relaxed, family-focused dining experience with a menu featuring pub classics. The pub is divided between an adults only area,  with extensive timber bar servery and c. 200 covers; and a family dining area with c. 270 covers. Ali Bongos Indoor Play area is located off the family dining area, with 50 covers, extensive play equipment and access to an enclosed lawned garden, providing a fully equipped exciting indoor play space for children to play and burn off energy in a safe environment. The Stuart Suite, a large, dedicated, self-contained function room is located within the Lodge and is ideal for weddings, conferences, and gala events. Boasting its own reception foyer and modern facilities, Wi-Fi, PA system, projector, air conditioning, and screens. Licensed for civil ceremonies and tailored to significant occasions. The Lodge also benefits from extensive commercial kitchen facilities with wash-up area, walk-in fridge and freezers, separate function room kitchen, dry store, large ground floor cellar, staff W.C.s and office.  The Lodge also boasts an impressive managers' accommodation over the first floor. The spacious accommodation briefly comprises three bedrooms (master with ensuite), large lounge, kitchen-dining room, family bathroom and utility room.  Located in a separate, purpose built, two storey stone-built property, Pastures Hotel boast 60 well-appointed and spacious en-suite letting bedrooms. The front entrance leads to a bright reception area with easy chair seating for c. 20 and an office to the rear of the reception desk. The bedrooms are a mixture of cosy standard rooms, spacious family rooms, executive rooms and suite rooms. All rooms offer premium linens, soft pillows and comfortable mattresses. All rooms offer high speed Wi-Fi, premium toiletries, hairdryer, 42” smart TV, premium teas and coffee with biscuits in room. Reeds restaurant is a restaurant-function space located within the hotel, just off the reception. Reeds is a bright, contemporary room that seats c. 100; with bar and breakfast serveries, and commercial kitchen with dry store and fridge-freezer store. Reeds has AV facilities, a PA system, and adaptable lighting, and is popular venue for weddings, private dinners, or corporate events. The Castle Suite is situated on the first floor at the Pastures Hotel, above the Reeds Restaurant, and is a mid-sized conference-meeting room venue for up to 100 guests.  To the exterior, the Pastures Lodge and Hotel sits in an extensive plot of 4.266 acres, with an extensive 175 space car park in between the two venues.  The Pastures Lodge in located in a semi-rural setting near the River Dean on the edge of the market town of Mexborough town which has a population of over 15,000. Mexborough is situated seven miles southwest of Doncaster, six miles north east of Rotherham and ten miles south-east of Barnsley in South Yorkshire. Within the one-mile catchment area the population increases to 11,325 and 61,000 at three miles. The 20-minute off-peak drive time covers a wide area including parts of Doncaster and Rotherham with a total population of over 450,000. The local authority is Doncaster Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area, but does lie within a flood zone. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries.  All trade fixtures and fittings are included in the sale with the exception of the EPOS System which is linked to our clients head office and will be removed on completion.  The total site area is approximately 4.266 acres. The ground floor footprint (GEA) of Pastures Lodge extends to 20,355 ft2 (1,891m2) and Pastures Hotel to 14,571 ft2 (1,354m2). Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate.  The property is held freehold under Land Registry Title Number SYK288307. Current rateable value (from 1 April 2023) of Pastures Hotel has been assessed at £72,000. The rateable value (2023) of the Pastures Lodge has been assessed at £212,000.

propertySubType: Other, Cafe, Public House, Takeaway, Bar, Retail, Alternate Use, Restaurant
detailedDescription: This character, period 15th Century property oozes history from its extensive exposed wooden beams, oak panels and stained glass windows. In fact the timber frame of the west side and south front of the building contains many bullet holes from the fighting during The Siege of Colchester between the Royalists and the Parliamentarians during the reign of Charles I. The property has the benefit of trading across 2 floors, both with their own bar servery. The ground has a front and side entrance, as well as a rear entrance through the patio garden. The area has several split seating areas due to the timber frames and can seat approx 60 covers. A beautiful wooden staircase leads to the first floor, with a fully equipped trade kitchen with prep and storage areas off the landing halfway up the stairs with an open pass area. First floor can seat up to 80 customers but is split with a private dining room and four separate areas, which makes the space ideal for private parties or small conferences and meetings. The areas also boast 4 open fireplaces.  On the 1st floor is a large 2 bedroom flat, consisting of a kitchen, lounge and bathroom facilities. External areas consist of an enclosed patio garden with furniture and outdoor heaters. Seating for up to 60 customers. Car park for up to 17 cars. The Old Siege House is prominently located on East Street, leading directly into Colchester City Centre, with it's array of shops, eateries, bars, and local attractions, which is about a 10 minute walk. Colchester benefits from being located just off the main A12 with links to London and Stansted, as well as other major towns and cities in the East and rail links to London Liverpool Street. We have been advised that there is a notable house building project within 2 miles of the property with potential development of over 200 houses, as well as plans in the pipeline for another 7,500 homes in the Tendering and Colchester Border garden Community. The Colchester Siege ( 12 June 1648 – 28 August 1648) took place during the reign of Charles I and was part of the war between the Royalists and Parliamentarians. The Old Siege House is in close proximity to Colchester Castle and at the time of the Siege, this restaurant was actually on the road which was once used in the main route to the castle. The building was situated next to the bridge which crossed the river surrounding the town and castle. Grade II* Listed and is situated within the Colchester Conservation Area. Currently no existing planning, however we have been advised that there has been historic consent to convert the building into flats and residential status. Those seeking change of use will need to make their own enquires with Colchester City Council in the first instance, as we hold no plans or details. All trade fixtures and fittings are included in the purchase price, save for a few third party personal items. An inventory can be provided. Site Area of 0.164 acres and total Floor Area of 5,468 sq ft.  Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Freehold available seeking offers in the region of £650,000 (no VAT). The purchase price includes all trade fixtures and fittings.  The property is now closed and will be available with vacant possession. Rateable Value £41,250 as of 1st April 2023. Council Tax Band 'A'

displayAddress: 10 Lower Bond Street, Hinckley, Leicestershire, LE10 1QU
propertySubType: Guest House, Retail, Public House, Restaurant, Cafe, Leisure, Bar, Industrial, Alternate Use, Takeaway, Investment, Land / Development
detailedDescription: The Duke of Rutland is a two and three storey semi detached property of painted brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. Entry through the main front door, provides access to the trading area with timber bar servery, open feature fireplace and perimeter seating. A raised area provides further perimeter seating and part wood panelled walls.   A small rear snug room provide a further 10 covers and allows access to the basement beer cellar and kitchen. An internal hallway leads to the Ladies and Gents W.C.s and a rear pool room.  The domestic accommodation is situated over the upper floors and briefly comprises a lounge, two bedrooms and family bathroom over the first floor. Stairs from the first floor landing provide access to a large bedroom over the second floor. To the exterior, the pub has a small enclosed yard to the side.  The Duke of Rutland is prominently situated on edge of Hinckley's town centre. The property enjoys a bustling location amidst a densely populated residential area, boasting a local community of 24,000 within a one-mile radius. The pub is conveniently surrounded by housing and local businesses, with the added advantage of being close to Hinckley campus, making it a focal point for both residents and students alike. Hinckley is the third largest settlement in Leicestershire, and lies approximately halfway between Leicester and  Coventry.  The town borders Nuneaton in Warwickshire and forms an urban area with the village of Burbage, directly to the south. The local authority is Hinckley and Bosworth. We are advised that the property is not Listed but is situated in a conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. The ground floor footprint of the property is 2,025 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.050 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). Current rateable value (from 1 April 2023) of the Duke of Rutland has been assessed at £3,000.

propertySubType: Hotel, Leisure, Cafe, Land / Development, Retail, Guest House, Investment, Public House, Bar, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Black Lion Hotel is an extensive Grade II Listed two and three storey property with sections believed to date back to the Tudor era. The  accommodation briefly comprises an entrance hall leading to a comfortable lounge to the right of the entrance with two small snug areas leading towards the restaurant to the left. The 'Tudor Bar' is full of character with an ornate timber bar servery, timber flooring, open fireplaces and original wooden beams. Part of the lounge bar wall is an unusual glazed curved panel which originally came from Chirk Castle. A sports bar is at the rear, accessed via a hallway with a timber servery.  The restaurant room has a timber floor with raised area and seating for approximately 40. A further restaurant/ function room is located over the first floor, with timber bar servery, pool area, darts throw and dumb waiter from the Kitchen.  Several letting rooms are also located over the first and second floors. Three double letting rooms are situated over the first floor with ensuite bathrooms. A further five rooms on the second floor (all in a partially developed state). The Black Lion also benefits from a commercial kitchen with wash-up/prep room and walk in fridge, an extensive basement beer cellar, office and various store rooms. The domestic accommodation is also located over the first and second floors, which briefly consists of a lounge, domestic kitchen, bedroom/2nd reception over the first floor and four bedrooms and bathroom over the second. Externally there is an outside courtyard area with a raised decked seating area, a car park which is accessed from Victoria Street to the rear, and numerous brick built store rooms.  The Black Lion is a landmark site situated in the centre of the delightful Shropshire town of Ellesmere.The Lion has a long history as a Coaching Inn, evidence of which still can be seen outside and in the car park. The attractive market town stands on the banks of the charming Llangollen Canal and enjoys an idyllic location next to The Mere, an enchanting lake which is part of ‘Shropshire's Lakeland'. The A495 and A528 roads cross at Ellesmere. The latter runs 15 miles south-southeast from Ellesmere to the county town,  Shrewsbury. Ellesmere is situated near the English/Welsh border, close to Wrexham and Oswestry. the town is popular with tourists with four caravan parks within a 5 mile radius; the mere canal plus lots of outdoor pursuits with Chirk Castle and Whittington Castle nearby.  The local authority is Shropshire Council. We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed (List Entry Number: 1055483) and is situated in the Ellesmere Conservation Area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries. No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items. The ground floor footprint of the property is 8,388 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.356 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate). The Rateable Value of the Black Lion has been assessed at £21,000 (2023).

propertySubType: Cafe, Leisure, Industrial, Restaurant, Other, Retail, Alternate Use, Land / Development, Public House, Bar, Investment, Takeaway
detailedDescription: The Harry Hotspur is a substantial two storey detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The entrance hall provides access to the large open plan trading area with timber bar servery and glass wash up area to the rear; an elevated seating section, upholstered perimeter seating, exposed brick walls, two darts throws and pool area. The pub also benefits from Ladies, Gents and Disabled W.C.s, a ground floor beer cellar, bottle store, store room and staff W.C. and changing room.  The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and briefly comprises four bedrooms, lounge, domestic kitchen, bathroom and separate W.C. To the exterior the pub benefits from a good sized tarmac car park with 33 spaces, single garage, a paved patio to the site and lawned areas to the front and rear, with picnic bench seating for c.40. A rear yard and bin storage area. The Harry Hotspur sits on the outskirts of Shrewsbury Town Centre, in a prominent neighbourhood location with easy access roads in and out of Shrewsbury. The property sits prominently between the Harlescott residential estate that sits behind the pub and the Benbow Business Park, an industrial-retail estate, to the front.  Shrewsbury is a market town and civil parish in Shropshire. It is the county town of the ceremonial county of Shropshire, located 9  miles east of the England-Wales border.  Shrewsbury serves as the commercial centre for Shropshire and  parts of mid-Wales, with a retail output of over £299 million per year  and light industry and distribution  centres, such  as  Battlefield  Enterprise Park on the outskirts. The A5 and A49 trunk roads come  together as the town's by-pass and five railway lines meet at  Shrewsbury rail station.  It is sited on the River Severn, 33 miles  northwest of Wolverhampton, 15 miles west of Telford, 31 miles  southeast of Wrexham and 43 miles west of Birmingham. At the  2021 census, the parish had a population of 76,782. The local authority is Shropshire Council. We are advised that the property is neither Listed nor situated in a conservation area. Prospective purchasers are advised to make their own enquiries.  No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as games machines or beer raising equipment The ground floor footprint of the property is 4,407 sq ft and the overall site measures c. 0.566 acres, (Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate) Current rateable value (from 1 April 2023) of the Harry Hotspur has been assessed at £15,750.

displayAddress: 56 Long Lane, Aston End, Stevenage, SG2 7HD
propertySubType: Leisure, Cafe, Public House, Retail, Bar, Restaurant
detailedDescription: The Crown is a very attractive detached brick built freehold, under pitched slate roof, in a rural location on the edge of the fast growing town of Stevenage.  The scale of the operation provides space for 80/100 internal covers and 200+ covers externally, the latter set amongst a stunning landscaped garden area. The ground floor provides largely open plan trade areas with timber flooring, wood panelling, exposed brickwork and open fireplaces.  A very well equipped theatre kitchen provides atmosphere for customers, with full extraction and wholly owned inventory. Customer WC's and cellar support these areas along with storage areas and walk-in fridges. The 1st floor provides a function room or private dining room with space for c 30-40 covers. Adjoining this is a studio apartment with plumbing, currently used as office and storage space.  Externally the property excels providing enviable trade areas with patios, covered areas, fixed and loose seating, raised pergola areas and grassed trade gardens.  The gardens have been extensively refurbished by designers and comfortably accommodates 200 covers, with BBQ and cooking areas.  In addition there is a large shingle car park with 40-50 spaces. The Crown is situated in the peaceful hamlet of Aston End, which lies one mile south of the village of Aston, located on a ridge between Stevenage and the Beane Valley. The Crown is on the outskirts of Stevenage, a fast growing town strategically positioned by the A1(M), with excellent road and rail links to London and the North, with population approaching 95,000. This building is not listed.  The local planning authority is Hertfordshire County Council. Lapsed planning exists to extend the trading areas further:-  3/15/1511/FUL | Extension to existing public house to provide additional restaurant seating with three bed and breakfast suites to the first floor - revised plans | The Crown PH 56 Long Lane Aston Stevenage Hertfordshire SG2 7HD (eastherts.gov.uk) The property is fully fitted with substantial commercial trade kitchen, trade inventory and extensive garden furniture, all presented in excellent condition as a turnkey opportunity. The total ground floor footprint is 3,500 sq ft (VOA).  Measurements taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Freehold with vacant possession, expected to qualify as a TOGC, seeking offers in excess  of £650,000, plus VAT if applicable. The rateable value is £34,000 as of the 1st April 2023.

detailedDescription: Detached property of stone construction under a series of pitched slate roofs. Inner entrance porch leading through to a multi section bar area which oozes in character having stone floors, exposed ceiling beams open fires and cast iron wood burning stoves. A quirky layout providing seating for approximately 60 persons in total on fixed perimeter seating low stools and an assortment of chairs. Central bar servery with direct access to the beer cellar. There is a former catering kitchen that hasn't been used for a period of time and would need to be fully refurbished. Ancillary areas briefly comprise of Ladies and Gentleman's toilets, beer cellar and bottle store. Externally there is a smoking shelter to the front of the property and a lovely picturesque beer garden to the rear backing onto the River Yarrow. Across the road from the pub is a car park for approximately 25 vehicles. The living accommodation is located on the first floor and briefly comprises of 3 bedrooms, lounge, kitchen, bathroom and office.  Situated in Heath Charnock backing onto the River Yarrow approximately three miles south-east of Chorley Town Centre. The property is located in an attractive semi-rural location close to the M61 Motorway for ease of access.  We are advised that the property is not listed but does sit in a flood zone. The Fixtures & Fittings that remain on the premises at the time of completion will be included in the sale. Any third party owned items, such as beer raising and cellar cooling equipment, branded items, gaming machines etc, will be excluded. An inventory will not be provided. Externally the property has a patio area leading through to a lawned beer garden furnished with picnic style benches. The is also a detached outbuilding which is currently used as a sports bar showing live sports and accommodating approximately 20 persons. Located opposite the property is a large car park. The living accommodation is located on the first floor and briefly comprises of 3 Bedrooms, Lounge, Bathroom and a shared kitchen with the pub. The property occupies a picturesque setting in the small village of West Mickley on the southern fringes of Northumberland some 20 miles west of Newcastle Upon Tyne and 13 miles east of Hexham. propertySubType: Public House, Cafe, Bar
detailedDescription: Cromwells Bar & Cafe is a double fronted 2 storey property in a central position in Huntingdon town centre. The public house/bar provides versatile, largely open plan ground floor trade areas accessed via a central lobby entrance. The glazed frontage provides two light trade areas either side of the lobby overlooking High Street (25 covers). To the rear are a number of interconnecting trade areas, dance floor, dj booth, with space for 60+ covers. Complimenting these areas is a substantial commercial trade kitchen with extraction, storage, ground floor rear cellar and rear delivery access, leading to a rear entrance to the trade garden. Male and female WC's are located via an internal staircase to the 1st floor.  In addition there  is a self contained 1 bedroom flat with large lounge, separate domestic kitchen, bathroom and storage, adjoining the rear plant room. Externally the property provides a sizeable trade garden and rear patio, shed and bin storage, directly onto Trinity Place, where there is public parking and vehicular access. This historic riverside market town with charming churches, Cromwell Museum and markets offers a thriving town centre with major multiple retailers including TK Maxx, Next, M&S Food Hall, Sainsbury's, Boots, WHSmith and Magnet in Chequers Shopping Centre. Cromwells is located in a prominent position on the pedestrianised High Street, in a central position with Trinity Place car park to the rear. The property is Grade II Listed (entry no. 1128619). Administered by Huntingdonshire District Council The property is ready for fitting out by a new tenant.  The purchase price excludes fixtures & fittings, although the purchaser will inherit any remaining items owned by the Vendor at the property on the day of completion. The ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house extends to 4,241ft² (394 m²) with a Site Area of 0.138 acres (approx). The ground floor extends to 3,750 ft² (NIA). The property is being 'sold as seen' seeking unconditional offers in excess of £450,000, plus VAT if applicable. Alternatively a new FRI lease may be considered to strong and experienced candidates, with or without, an option to purchase the freehold interest. Rateable Value- £29,750, as at 1st April 2023 to present.

To the exterior the pub has a drinking area laid to tarmac at the side with picnic bench seating for 8.  The County Tavern is prominently located at the corner of Charles Street and Francis Street in the city centre of Hull. With a population of 267,014 (2021), Hull is the fourth-largest city in the Yorkshire and Humber region. We understand the Property is neither Listed nor situated in a Conservation Area. propertySubType: Bar, Public House, Other, Restaurant, Leisure
detailedDescription: The Unicorn is a characterful detached brick built public house with notable single storey extensions and trade garden to the rear.  The main bar area with exposed timbers, wood flooring and log burner provides a feature bar servery and space for 20 covers. Flexible restaurant/dining space is provided in a number of interconnecting areas with space for over 40 covers. To the rear is vaulted function room, also used as an overflow dining area and for events & private parties (c.40 covers). The impressive vaulted commercial trade kitchen is well positioned and comprehensively fitted, with prep rooms, wash up areas and ample storage.  Newly refurbished customers WC's and basement cellar support these areas. 1st floor comprises 2 double bedrooms, kitchen, bathroom and lounge. Externally the property provides a dedicated tarmac car park to the front (20 spaces), service yard, rear patio and trade garden, with petanque pitches and children's pay areas (100+ covers). The Unicorn occupies a central roadside position in the heart of the affluent village of Cublington in the delightful Aylesbury Vale in Buckinghamshire, boasting a 15th century church, two tennis courts, a cricket club and also a trout and coarse fishing lake. The County Town of Aylesbury (c 7 miles) provides Mainline Rail connection to Marylebone 60mins, together with a wider range of shopping, leisure and educational facilities including excellent schools .   Leighton Buzzard is 6 miles away with Mainline Rail services to Euston in 35 minutes. The property is Grade II Listed, Entry Number 1219167. The property is registered as an Asset of Community Value (ACV) which expires 9/6/2026. All ACV and planning enquiries can be made to Aylesbury Vale District Council . The total area for the site is 0.422 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house extends to 274 m² (2,947 ft²). All measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. propertySubType: Bar, Alternate Use, Cafe, Restaurant, Public House, Takeaway
detailedDescription: The outside of the pub is in good condition and consists of 2 separate trading areas, one at the front, and one at the rear. As you enter, there is the main drinking area with an L-shaped bar. The second area is more of a lounge or perhaps an eating space, for up to 25 covers with access to rear garden, served by another small bar which connects to the main one. There is a set of toilets in between both which are in good condition. Trade kitchen and basement cellar. Externally, the Cherry Tree has a car park with around 12 spaces and also has two areas for alfresco drinking and dining. The front area has benches to enjoy the sun and the rear has a lovely decking and faux grass area with enclosed booth seating. The private accommodation (internal access only) consists of two bedrooms, lounge and private bathroom. The Cherry Tree is situated in the seaside town of Brightlingsea, Essex, just a 15 minute stroll from the harbour and beach towards the top of the town in a quality residential area. A picturesque location on the River Colne between Clacton and Colchester, Brightlingsea has a population of around 8,500 people, making it a popular place for commuters and visitors. This is a smart town with an abundance of history, culture and scenic beauty. Boasting a wealth of commercial ventures it has plenty of local unique shops as well as bigger stores in the town centre with Victoria Place hosting many local businesses. With varied food and drink in abundance coupled with a fantastic combination of coastal and inland walks, Brightlingsea is an idyllic place to live and take holidays to. Colchester is the closest city, 10 miles south east of Brightlingsea, accessible by the B1029 and it has plenty of art galleries, historic buildings, a popular university and a very famous zoo. The property is not listed and is not situated within a Conservation Area. Those seeking change of use are requested to contact Tendring District Council in the first instance.    No inventory will be supplied or warranted. The purchase price excludes fixtures & fittings, although the purchaser will inherit any remaining items owned by the Vendor at the property on the day of completion. Total site area is 0.208 acres. propertySubType: Cafe, Bar, Restaurant, Takeaway, Public House
detailedDescription: A popular pub in the heart of the North Norfolk coastal town of Heacham. The property is located over Ground Floor and 1st Floor under pitched tiled roof.  Front and side entrance leading directly into the main bar. Traditional and cosy decoration. U-Shape wooden topped servery, with partition. Carpeted throughout. Benefits from 2 wood burners and wall mounted TV. Pool Table in situ, which will be removed. Therefore seating space for c30 customers in main bar. Leading to Dining Room. Wooden floor, with access to rear patio garden. Seating for approx 30 covers. Ladies, Gents and Access WC. Fully equipped trade kitchen with dry store. Ground floor cellar with all necessary beer raising and cooling equipment.  1st Floor - Consisting of 4 double bedrooms, Office (which could be converted to another bedroom), Lounge, Bathroom and Kitchen. External Areas - Beer garden, laid to grass c80 seats on picnic style bench seating. Car park for c15 vehicles. Front seating patio area c50. Separate Pavilion/Function Room to the rear, with large open trade space, bar servery, kitchenette, ladies and gents WC. The area is currently used for storage and needs to be reinstated. Micro Brewery Shed. Fully equipped and fully functioning (available by separate negotiation).  Heacham is a thriving village in north-west Norfolk, approximately 2 miles from the popular seaside town of Hunstanton and around 12-miles from Kings Lynn, where there is a direct trainline into London Kings Cross, via Cambridge. The renowned North Norfolk coastline is only a short drive along the A149; whilst Burnham Market is around a 20-minute car journey away. Heacham enjoys a wide range of amenities including schools, pubs, restaurants, a golf club and various shops, as well as a lively village hall and social club. The village is also a popular holiday destination, with several miles of beaches and other tourist attractions. Heacham is one on Norfolks largest villages, with a population of c5,000. The number significantly increases due to the holiday trade between April and October.  The property is not listed and is not situated within a Conservation Area.  All trade fixtures and fittings are included in the premium price. Save for the Pool table and some personal 3rd party items.  The micro brewery equipment is available at a separate cost, to be agreed.  Total Floor Area - 4,197 sq ft - to include the pavilion/function room to the back and Micro Brewery building..  Site Area - 0.4 acres *all measurements are approximate and taken from digital mapping systems New 'free of tie' lease. Term to be agreed. Experienced operators only. Full repairing and insuring lease. Rent £30,000 pax. 3 months rent security deposit requested. Five yearly rent reviews. Business plan and credit checks will be required. A Guarantor will be required. Estimated ingoing costs of £30,000, without any refurbishment costs. Proof of funding will be required.  Rateable Value - £23,500, as of 1st April 2026. We are advised that the business currently benefits from 100% rates relief.

propertySubType: Public House, Restaurant, Bar
detailedDescription: Slingers is an extremely prominent corner bar, 1-3 Station Road, trading over ground and basement levels. The ground floor provides a central island bar via a lobby entrance. To the left hand side is a bar area, with raised seating area.  To the right hand side is an open plan bar areas, recently partitioned to include a number of interactive darts boards. To the rear are male, female and accessible customer WC's.  In addition there is a well equipped commercial trade kitchen, with newly fitted extraction (2017), wash up area, prep and storage areas. The basement is accessed by a feature metal spiral staircase providing further trade areas with a mix of loose and fixed booth seating. There is additional storage, cellar and office, along with the necessary fire escape routes to the rear. Externally there is a dedicated bin store and access for rear deliveries. Slingers is located in a prominent corner position at the corner of Hills Road and Station Road in central Cambridge. Station Road, and the Rail Station has seen wholesale redevelopment over recent years. Cambridge Station is a short walk and provides excellent transport links, including a mere 45-minute commute to London. Station Road is now host to some of the world’s best-known businesses including Microsoft, Amazon and Mott MacDonald. Slingers is situated opposite Botanic Place, Railpens development of 333,000 sq ft (NIA) office space, set to be completed in 2028. Slingers is fully fitted, turnkey bar, including comprehensive trade inventory, commercial kitchen with extraction, rationale, ovens, grills, dishwasher, ice machine, wash up station, walk in fridge, air conditioning and island bar servery with numerous fridges.  The wholly owned trade inventory is included in the asking Premium for an incoming operator. displayAddress: 162 High Street, New Whittington, Chesterfield, Derbyshire, S43 2AN
propertySubType: Public House, Alternate Use, Retail, Land / Development, Bar, Restaurant, Leisure
detailedDescription: The Wellington is a two and single storey detached property of brick elevations beneath pitched tiled roofs. The property briefly comprises an entrance hall from the High Street leading to a lobby with Ladies & Gents W.C.s off and access to the Public Bar, with timber bar servery, perimeter seating, darts throw and pool area. The Lounge Bar is to the rear of the property and also accessed from the lobby, with timber bar servery, upholstered perimeter seating and beamed ceiling.  The Wellington also benefits from a basement beer cellar and commercial kitchen, which is just off the lounge bar.  The domestic accommodation is situated over the first floor and briefly comprises a lounge, domestic kitchen, single bedroom/office, three double bedrooms and bathroom.  To the exterior, the pub benefits from an enclosed rear beer garden with concrete hardstanding with picnic bench seating, a raised covered decking smoking shelter and a L-shaped lawned area. The pub also has an area of car parking to the side which also provide return access onto Wellington Street.  The Wellington is prominently located on the High Street in the north Derbyshire village of New Whittington. The village is located in the Borough of Chesterfield in Derbyshire near to Whittington Moor and Old Whittington. Lovely enclosed beer garden to the rear and large car park. The Punch Bowl occupies a prominent position in the centre of the quaint sought after, affluent village of Marton Cum Grafton. The village is located a stones throw off the A168 giving easy access to the A1M north and south and just 3.5 miles south of Boroughbridge and 7 miles north east of Knaresborough.  We are advised that the property is Grade II Listed and sits within a Conservation Area. The Royal Oak is located on Queen Street, a side street just off the town centre of Uppingham. The property is situated within easy access of the transport networks with the A1, A47 and A15 all close by providing easy access to nearby Peterborough, Corby and Leicester. Uppingham is a market town in Rutland, just off the A47 between Leicester and Peterborough, 6 miles (10 km) south of the county town, Oakham. Uppingham had a population of 4,745 according to the 2011 census, estimated at 4,853 in 2019. A picturesque and sought-after town, Uppingham was named best place to live in the Midlands in 2022. Uppingham has a town centre with central shopping and market area and several well acknowledged and highly sought-after schools. propertySubType: Bar, Public House, Cafe, Restaurant
detailedDescription: Belong is a premium bar-restaurant in the Cathedral Quarter of Derby. A brick built two storey property the venue benefits from a major refurbishment project has seen the building transformed into a modern, inviting and opulent space. The property has been refitted and refurbished throughout to create a fantastic contemporary bar-restaurant, with a total capacity for around 150. The wonderful trading space briefly comprises a doorway leading from Old Blacksmiths Yard, into the open-plan ground floor bar area, with large, tiled bar servery with exposed brick back-bar, timber flooring, part steel plated wall fixtures, wall and ceiling mounted lighting units and a range of contemporary table and chairs. The Snug Area is just off the main bar with easy chair seating and wooden flooring. Stairs to the first floor lead to an additional trading area, again boasting a warm, contemporary feel, with wooden flooring, exposed brick walls and feature wall mounted lighting. The refurbished Ladies and Gents W.C.s are also situated on the first floor.  The fully equipped commercial kitchen, with preparation area, is also situated over the first floor with an open 'pass'.  The lease also includes a separate two storey building on the other side of Old Blacksmith's Yard, comprising a ground floor store room with stairs to the first floor office.  To the exterior, the business benefits from a cobbled yard to the front providing a delightful outdoor space, with timber topped, metal framed seating and benches for approximately 24. A private yard used as a bin store is also located to the side of the premises.     Belong boasts a prime central Derby location, situated within the ever-popular Old Blacksmiths Yard in the Cathedral Quarter area of the City. The area, once previously occupied by a farrier named Samuel Palfree housing several cottages, is now an integral part of the local nightlife. Situated just off Sadler Gate, the venue is located amongst Derby's most notable bars, pubs and restaurants and adjacent to the Market Place and close to the Derby Market Hall.  Derby had a population of 248,700 at the 2011 census and is a centre for advanced transport manufacturing, being home to Rolls Royce, Bombardier Transportation and Toyota. The local authority is Derby City Council. We understand the property is not Listed but is situated within the Derby City Centre Conservation Area.  All trade fixtures and fittings are included within the sale price.  The Property is let on a 15 Year FRI Lease from 2022 with an annual rent of £30,000. The rent is payable quarterly. The Lease is with the Landlord & Tenant Act 1954 and provides for Tenant only breaks every 5 years. The current Rateable Value has been assessed at £12,750.

detailedDescription: The Greyhound is a partly rendered, two-story brick-built building under a pitched tiled roof which is believed to be formerly known as The Railway Tavern. The business has been closed for several years and the new landlord is in the process of completing a full restoration of the ground floor including a new bar servery. The ground floor trade area is divided into two areas, with the main bar area located at the front of the building and games room to the rear. An accessible toilet is located to the rear, with male and female toilets located at first floor level. The back of house comprises a commercial trade kitchen with extraction, ground floor cellar and keg store, along with two storage rooms, one of which is sizeable.  The landlord is retaining the 1st floor to offer as letting accommodation. The landlord is happy to discuss possible joint business opportunities in conjunction with the pub and the rooms. The letting accommodation can be accessed without entering the pub trading areas.  Outside, there is gated vehicular access to a dedicated car park, with spaces for c. 10+ vehicles. The garden is enclosed by brick wall, partly laid to lawn and partly paved, sheltered by a prominent mature willow tree. The outside area may be carved up to allow a garden space for those staying in the letting rooms on the 1st floor, as well as retaining a certain number of parking spaces. Landlord happy to review options for garden space to be used by the tenant on the ground floor as a trade garden for the business.  Bury St Edmunds is an attractive Suffolk market town. The East to West A14 main road allows quick and easy access to Cambridge, Newmarket Racecourse, and the nearby Ely Cathedral. Within 45 minutes of Stansted Airport, 30 minutes from Cambridge, with rail connections to London Liverpool Street and Kings Cross. The Greyhound occupies a substantial site to the north of the commercial centre along Eastgate Street, a predominantly residential area, close to the junction with Barn Lane. The immediate area also contains a number of independent businesses, as well as an entertainment complex for indoor bowling, pool and snooker. The property is not Listed but is situated in Bury St Edmunds (Town Centre) Conservation Area. A new tenant will be required to furnish all areas as the property is being let in a shell condition. GROUND FLOOR ONLY - Offering a new commercial lease, with term to be agreed, for suitable uses (stp), free from any purchasing obligations. Headline rent of £35,000. Internal repair and decorating lease. Guarantor requested for those seeking to operate under a New Co. Interested parties will need to demonstrate funds to cover all in-going costs to include, deposit, legal fees, stock, working capital and refurbishment. displayAddress: Silver Street, Wakefield, West Yorkshire, WF1 1UY
propertySubType: Restaurant, Leisure, Other, Retail, Takeaway, Public House, Investment, Bar, Alternate Use, Cafe
detailedDescription: Entrance to the pub is located between a shop and a bar/restaurant. A small courtyard passage leads to the main entrance. Once inside the lobby area, you can take the door to your left or the door straight ahead; both doors lead into the one-room, open-plan, galley-style operation. To the left, you’ll see the bar and DJ booth. The bar, with its complete mirrored wall, is stocked with premium drinks and cocktails, perfect for this late-night venue. A few steps down to a lower level, you’ll find a raised stage to the right, a dance floor, and two booth areas with high backed bench seating and mood lighting to enhance the atmosphere. The main area opposite the bar features a mix of bench seating areas and low-level tables and chairs. The combination of the mirrored bar, tiled walls, and wooden floor, balanced with wallpaper and dark paint, is designed to give the venue a trendy, chic late-night feel. At the end of the room, patio doors lead to a small enclosed paved courtyard with tables and chairs, perfect for alfresco drinking. The private accommodation, accessed via a separate entrance is of a good size. It consists of three bedrooms, open plan living room, kitchen, bathroom and office over two floors. Wakefield is a cathedral city in West Yorkshire located on the River Calder. This industrial, market town is steeped in history and has many tourist attractions around the city. With a population of 325,837 and serviced by excellent transport links via car (M62 &M1), regular bus and train services it is easy accessible to locals and tourists visiting the area. The Black Swan is a town centre, late night venue, centrally located in the town. Surrounded by shops, bars and restaurants it truly is the hub of the night time circuit and is attractive to people of all ages. We are advised that the property is not listed or in a flood zone No fixtures and fittings will be warranted with this sale and an inventory cannot be provided. The property is being 'sold as seen' and any items left on the day of completion will be inherited by the purchaser excluding any third party items such as beer raising equipment. propertySubType: Other, Restaurant, Leisure, Bar, Public House
detailedDescription: The Warwick Street Social (previously Warwick Arms) is a well fitted detached freehold property on a prominent corner position to the south west of Norwich City centre. The ground floor provides a largely open plan contemporary trade area with central bar servery, presented in excellent condition. To the front is the main bar area along with side seating with space for 40 covers. To the right hand side is a separate bar area with darts board and space for an additional 20 covers. The building benefits from exposed brickwork and wooden flooring throughout and is particularly light given its triple aspect position. Serviced by customer WC's to the rear, basement cellar and ample storage areas. The 1st floor, accessed internally, provides an additional trade area used for private functions and overspill at busy trading times, with space for 60+ covers.  Adjoining this is the commercial trade kitchen with pizza oven. Externally the property benefits from a large rear patio garden with covered smoking shelter (80 covers) along with front grassed garden. Both accessed from the front and rear pub entrances. Warwick Street Social is located on a prominent corner site in the South Western suburbs of Norwich. The population of Norwich City as estimated by the 2021 census is 144,000. The Golden Triangle is within walking distance of the city centre and also close to the University of East Anglia. The area has good bus routes across Norwich. Many people choose to live in The Golden Triangle because of the variety of shops on Unthank Road and nearby streets, including supermarket express stores, restaurants, pubs, and fast food outlets. The local authority is Norwich City Council   The property is not listed and does not fall within a conservation area. The Fixtures & Fittings at the premises remain under the ownership of the outgoing tenant and may be available by separate negotiation.  The area of the site is 0.204 acres and the ground floor footprint (GEA) of the public house, extends to 202m² (2,173 ft² ). Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. The property is available by way of a new, 20-year 'free of tie' lease with an initial rent of £67,500 per annum, exclusive of VAT. There is no premium payable for the benefit of the new lease. The new lease will be on a Full Repairing and Insuring basis with Annual RPI increases (min 2.5% / max 5%) and 5th year open market rent reviews. Ingoing rental incentives may be offered, subject to the tenant’s assessed covenant strength and overall business plan.  Applicants must have sufficient capital available to cover 3 months' rent, along with building insurance, standard £1,750 legal fees contribution and working capital. Front entrance into main bar area with 'mariner' theme decoration with large horseshoe servery with extensive back bar display. Open plan space with wooden flooring throughout and open fireplace. can seat approx 50 customers. Upstairs can seat approximate 30 customers. Ladies and Gents facilities. There is also access to a 'minstrel gallery' overlooking the bar below. The Coast Inn is located in the bustling Essex island of Mersea over looking the Blackwater Estuary. The area has a wonderful supportive community and has a number of holiday parks and tourism that visit the Country Park and beaches. propertySubType: Hotel, Bar, Cafe, Public House, Leisure, Restaurant
detailedDescription: Dating back to the 17th century, the Swan Hotel is a sizeable building of immense character and charm. It is predominantly arranged over three storeys, with long two-storeyed wings forming two sides of the rear courtyard. The building includes an array of period features throughout, such as high ceilings, exposed timbers, sash/leaded windows and inglenook fireplaces. The ground floor entrance lobby opens into the guest lounge and provides access to the first floor hotel rooms, front meeting room (c. 10), basement cellar and main bar. Heavily timbered, the main bar features a superb inglenook fireplace and a part-brick bar servery, catering for c. 40 covers. A store room is located to the back and toilet block to the front, with Male, female and accessible WCs. Beyond the bar is the restaurant dining room for c. 25 covers, fireplace and doors opening onto the delightful 'secret' trade garden. A hallway leads to the commercial trade kitchen, replete with a range of equipment and generous in size, with ancillary storage and prep areas. To the rear is the sizeable function room with carvery and bar, capable of accommodating over 100 covers and including male and female WCs. Completing the ground floor is a further meeting room, which is currently let and operating as a pop-up shop. The letting rooms are located on the first and second floors and comprise 12 double/twin rooms plus 2 family rooms, all of which are en suite. There is a further owner/manager's room, which is also en suite. Outiside, there is a sizeable dedicated car park to the rear which is accessed via Swan Lane and has space for c. 30 vehicles and three garage which are tucked away in the rear corner. A courtyard provides an outdoor trading area and includes a sheltered area with tables for c. 12 covers.  Harleston is a picturesque and historic market town with a population of c. 5,067. It is located to the south of Norfolk, close to the border with Suffolk and the river Waveney. Harleston is a bustling market town due to its array of independent specialty shops, mostly locally owned. The town also notably hosts a market every Wednesday, a tradition which dates back to 1259. The Swan Hotel occupies a large site at the heart of the town, fronting the main retail and leisure pitch. We are advised the building is Grade II* Listed and falls within a conservation area. The relevant local authority is South Norfolk District Council https://www.southnorfolkandbroadland.gov.uk/ All trade fixtures & fittings are included in the sale, save for a few personal items which will be pointed out upon viewing. The vendor will warrant not to remove any items they own. Stock will be bought in addition, at valuation, on completion. The area of the site is 0.5 acres and the ground floor area (GEA) of the building extends to 855m² (9203ft²).  Measurements are taken from digital mapping and are approximate. Offers are sought in the region of £600,000 for the benefit of the freehold interest, trade inventory and goodwill. Business Rates:  £14,221.50 per annum (Based on a Rateable Value of £28,500)
